description:
We annually splurge on a joint birthday dinner and this year I chose New Korea House in SF J-Town. It was my first time at a Korean BBQ and this place was wonderful!  We ordered Dinner B; Kalbi, Sang Sun Jun, Jap Chae, Man Du Guk, Pan Fried Tofu and Dried Seaweed. All this on top of the array of ban chan (and rice). Dinner for two was enough to feed a family of five. Staggering! There was a mound of kalbi and it was cut differently than I expected; the bones were cut out and the meat was sliced thickly. The excellent house marinade made the meat absolutely delicious grilled. The rest of the food was good, but it all seemed to be there to add contrast to the wonderful kalbi.

Manager Tony was extremely attentive and helpful (without being obtrusive) during our meal, ably backed up by our server, Kim.

I adore the slow food style of eating; leisurely cooking, tasting, drinking and resting with conversation. This place was perfect for people with a lot of time, it's practically an event!

The place is clean, but the decor, etc. is a little dated and too bright to be romantic. Ir's more of a "friends and family" sort if restaurant. Excellent meal, but next time we'll bring along another couple to share our dinner for two.
author: Toki N.

description:
Very nice service here.  Great food and clean environment.  

Stepped in here and asked for the restroom and responded kindly.

I paid for the food through my card - totaling roughly $25.  Tipped $10 in cash.

I highly recommend.
author: Stanley T.

description: 3.5 stars. Nice service. Clean environment. Cooked / prepared properly. Samgyetang (Ginseng Chicken Soup) was home made and soothing. May be one of the best in SF. That said, I was not really into the quality of their meat but you get what you pay for. (I age selected beef from specific farms in my temperature, humidity, airflow, bacteria/fungus controlled dry aging chamber in my basement. I also only eat air chilled birds at home)
author: Chie J.

description:
If you're looking for good Korean BBQ, I'd pass on New Korea House. In summary- mediocre items at a higher price point that just isn't worth it- and I won't be back again soon.

Across the street from Japantown, it's definitely a convinient location to attract a lot of people into getting Korean food. Came with a date and we were both attracted by the 'KBBQ' sign out front, and the fact I was in the mood for Korean. And boy, did that KBBQ sign deceive me. First off, it's not AYCE. Secondly the meats that they do offer are just eh, and for the price tag it's at, I expect MUCH better.

BBQ Bulgogi ($22) - I mean this was fine for what it is. Good bulgogi for what it is, but not super mind blowing or amazing. But if you happen to be here getting KBBQ, I'd choose this over the next menu item I got.

BBQ Kal bi ($29). The Kal Bi was dry. Like there was no actual moisture/taste left in the meat, and on top of that there were a couple of fat bones on top thrown in. I mean I don't know about you, but I can't eat just a solid bone, so that was odd. Definitely would not recommend getting this.

Also they were VERY insistent that they do the cooking for us at the grill, which I guess was a polite gesture but the lady who ended up cooking for us slightly overcooked the meats somewhat and it left them a lot drier than what I would have liked. I would have wanted to cook the meats ourselves but she was VERY insistent that she did it, so in the end we let her do her thing.

Service was alright. It could be much better though. The old woman who helped us was nice.

I'd give New Korea House a very, VERY, very weak 2. The only reason why it's not a 1 at this point is that it wasn't the worst thing I've had, but I can't really recommend it here nor will I be back. If you're in the mood for some good Korean food, try another spot instead.
author: Allison O.

description: AYCE Korean food. They have an iPad where you can check your name in on the waiting list. We were the 8th name when I walked in and wait was probably about 50 mins long on a Friday night. Food was good and service was good
author: Jeannette C.

description:
this is nothing to do with food but i got charged for dinner last week and we were not there.  We had lunch few month ago in July.    

I called but the person could not help me with the bill so I had to just call my credit card company to stop/refund the amount.

the problem is that i had to get new card because the credit card company put this as fraud.  what a hassle!

I will just use cash from now on this place, I would recommend other to do the same.
author: Mason C.

description:
They tried to serve me spicy pork with out the spice. They were too lazy to marinate it. Was like a dry steak. 
Then the cold spicy noodles were just spicy. No flavor. They never served the cold icy broth.  No refills on the side dishes. Will not come here again. Looking for another place to "finish" my lunch. Going down the block.
author: Maria P.

description:
We decided to come here for lunch over the weekend for my friend's birthday. It opened pretty early and could accommodate a large group of people and takes reservation. 

I was a little frustrated with the service. I felt the servers didn't really pay attention to us even though there weren't many people in the restaurant. 

What I did really love was the Mount of side dishes that they brought out. And you get a set of side dishes for every 3-4 people, which was definitely nice.

I ended up ordered the vegetable Dolsot. I loved the flavor of the dish and that it's loaded with all sorts of vegetables and mushrooms and tofu. But when I got to the bottom of my bowl, something tasted really vinegary/sour so I stopped eating. 

In general, the food was okay. The service could have been better. Maybe it's because we were a large group (10 people) but it felt like we were missing orders and having a hard time getting servers to come to our table.
author: Andrea G.

description:
We arrived at 10am and they only had 3 items available for breakfast.
Beef (gomtang) soup was horrible. Had a funky smell & taste. It had tripe in the soup and it was almost like it wasn't cleaned good enough.
Cabbage soup (haejang gook) was meh. Wasn't bad but wasn't good either. I had to add more salt to it.
Side dishes were meh too. Nothing special about it.
We were served water at the end of our meal.
Will not be back
author: Soyeon J.

description:
Nice Korean restaurant across the street from the Japan Town complex.

We stopped in for lunch on a Saturday afternoon and were quickly seated. The wait staff was friendly and courteous. 

We ordered a variety of dishes including the beef hot pot, noodles as well as beef to grill.  The food we ordered was accompanied by a large number of complimentary side dishes that typically comes with korean BBQ.  Our food arrived quickly and was tasty.  

We had a very tasty and enjoyable meal.

If you're in the area and have a taste for korean food, this place is worth giving a try.
author: Marshall W.

description:
For dinner last Sunday, May 22nd, the roommate and I decided to order delivery from New Korea House. We ordered via DoorDash. Placed our order at 8pm and it arrived at 8:56pm. I live in Outer Richmond.

*Kimchi Chigae: A hearty kimchi and pork belly broth stew served in a stone pot ($15.50)
*Hae Mul Soon Dubu: Spicy silk tofu stew with seafood ($16.50)
*Grill - Kal Bi: Marinated beef short rib fillet ($34.50)
*Grill - Daeji Bul Go Ki: Thin slices of pork in spicy red pepper marinade ($24.50)
*Jogi Gui: Pan fried yellow croaker ($18.95)

They gave us a good amount and variety of banchan which I adored since I love a bunch of side dishes. They also provided a bunch of rice which the roommate appreciated. He loves his rice! I was really looking forward to their stews since I love soup. But they were pretty bland. I love my korean stews super savory and spicy, so these were kind of a let down. Especially the kimchee jjigae. It was a little watered down. The bbq, taste wise was good. But the roomie did comment on how small the portions were. In particular, the galbi. The fish had good flavor, but was a touch overcooked for me, so a little dry. Probably because of the delivery time, so not really the restaurant's fault.

Most of the dishes were pretty good, but they need to step up their stew game. Korean stews should be super flavorful, not bland. 3 stars.
author: Elena N.

description:
I just can't rate this place any higher.  I'm not positive if it's because they were closing in 45 min or also that we had a big group, but somehow I found it hard to communicate with the servers and the service was just OK.  Lunch food portions are on the skimpy end.  I opted for the bowl skillet which, thank goodness (1 star) I did because it was just the right size.  Most of the folks in our group ordered a lunch portion "meat"  item and they seemed pretty hungry still.  

The place is located near japantown and down the way from our team building event, so a plus for convenience (1 star), but other than that, not impressed with the food or service here.  Not sure if I even want to come back and do another review.  Paaassss....
author: Viclaire S.

description: Looks authentic and a bit run down. But overall ok. Fast and friendly service. Had lunch menue Bul Gogi (Ki) for $15.95. Came with delicious 7 variantions of ban chan. Meat well seasoned and tender. Served Korean tea for free. Great lunch apot, will come back!
author: Tim J.

description:
Extraordinarily nice, quick, and attentive service. They serve a variety of banchan. My only complaint is that dinner prices are a little on the high end for Korean food.

We ordered the dolsot bibimbap (~$17) which was full of crispy rice, vegetables, and beef. The hae jang guk soup (~$15) was delicious and hearty. There were tender pieces of beef although I wish it came with more and tons of soft cabbage. It comes with a bowl of rice. The serving sizes were pretty filling.
author: Linda X.

description:
We have not eaten here for years now. The location has moved slightly but the food is as good as ever. The number of banchan seem to have decreased. But otherwise we loved our visit. 

Besides our usual daeji bulgoki (spicy pork bbq) and the dolsot bibimbap (beef and veggie rice bowl), we got our favorite, yuk hwe (essentially Korean steak tartare). This was the best we've ever had. The spicing was out of this world. Truly amazing. 

Service was super friendly and attentive. I love Korean food!
author: Nobbi L.

description: This place is alright. It's very quiet, very peaceful. The BBQ meat portions are startling small for the price (you're looking at high $20s to mid $30s), and they all err on the side of a sweeter marinade. Pan chans were standard, and dolsot bibimbap was really good. The dumpling and rice noodle soup was really lacking... kind of bland, and had an off sour taste. Overall, not the best Korean BBQ, but definitely not too bad, especially if you don't want to wait in line and have a more intimate experience.
author: Ke C.

description:
We went here because it was the only restaurant open after 2pm on a Friday. Service is okay, but waitress(s) have poor front of the house experience. They don't talk, just come if you need something. They are like "get the short rib cuz it's better than the spic pork". Obviously, it's more expensive right? Right where we were sitting was a cleaning cart full of plates with food still left on it. It did have a leftover smell. They could of put it away from the dining area.

The first thing we got were the rice and your typical Korean condiments. They only gave 6 condiments, your typical kimchee, sprouts, potatoes, but no greens....boring selection and it didn't taste clean. Next we got our entree and soup. The short rib we ordered was okay, but the portion was very small (for one person). Most other places we been to is good amount of meat for two people. It's overpriced at $16. The vegetable beef soup we got had barely any meat, mostly just vegetable and just enough for two bowls. Again, other places would have enough for a Third bowl.

I've been to many Korean BBQ restaurants. The good ones will have at least 8 to 10 condiments and more generous amount of food for what you pay for.  Quantity and service could be improved here. I wouldnt consider coming back here again.
author: Food C.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant for many years -- mainly bc it's close to home. I never thought the food was great but it's not terrible either. It works when I'm craving Korean. 

I think the dol-sot bibimbap and kalbi tang are pretty good. The banchan assortment is good -- especially the white kimchee. Don't order the mul naeng-myun.  I was super disappointed with their mul naeng-myun-- I can tell the broth was not made from scratch. It smelled and tasted like the frozen/instant kind that you buy at the Korean market. Bad.
author: Esther L.

description: Got the bul go gi for lunch and it was very dry. Also they pre cooked it and was off the bone which was unfortunate. Lastly I paid $25 for a very average lunch . Never again.
author: Martin L.

description:
It was another cold SF summer evening, and my friend was craving soon tofu. I was crossing my fingers for a good experience after having really bland Korean food in Haight Ashbury last month. And New Korea delivered with a flavorful vegetarian soon tofu, and crispy beef and veggie pancake. Banchan portions were plentiful. They gave about 8 little bowls for the 2 of us. The pancake dipping sauce had that nice soy sauce saltiness with sesame seeds and minced garlic. 

Don't wear your best clothes or decide to go dancing after eating here, however. You can cook BBQ here, and it smells like smoky meat heaven. So if that's what you consider your eau de toilette, then by all means go dance and sweat your ass off.
author: Thomas L.

description: We were visiting San Francisco for the first time and were very excited to try the food scene in Japan Town. We arrived very early and were very hungry. Not many places were open at the time we arrived and this was one of the choices we had. First the people weren't very welcoming and they only had one food to serve at that time which is understandable but we could tell right away from the smell that it wasn't fresh just-made food. But we gave them the benefit of the doubt and ate the food anyways (I know stupid on our part). Soon after we left, I started feeling horrible and had stomach ache beyond imaginable; I felt nauseous and I sweated like crazy. I am sure we were served something old from the day before. The bad food plus the rude waiter who gave the absolute worst customer service made it the worst dining experience I ever had. Will definitely not recommend to anybody.
author: Melody S.

description: I had dinner here on thanksgiving day. Service was good. I had the fried fish and it looked and tasted not so fresh. However I ate anyway since it didnt taste spoiled or bad. My girlfriend had the tofu stew. Right after dinner I had stomach problem.
author: Vu N.

description:
I had pretty high expectations for something in Japantown. I know Korean food is not the same as Japanese, but I was thinking anything Asian in an Asian part of town should be amazing. I wasn't that impressed, though. Not the best KBBQ I've had.

I DO like that it's only 2 min for bbq at table instead of the entire party, like several other places I've visited. The bulgogi grill at table was the best - not too sweet, like it usually is for me. Strange though because the bulgogi lunch special (which is cooked in the back) tasted differently. That one was too sweet. The pork belly grill at table tasted like a healthy version? I don't know how else to explain it, but it was not that good. 

BUT she did split checks for every one of us in our party of 11. So I'm flipping back and forth between a 2 and 3. Let's go with 2.5. rounding up to 3.
author: Acelyn B.

description:
One of my lil sisters has been dying to get her hands on some authentic Korean food. 
Originally we were supposed to go to Oakland and roam around, but ended up here because it was close proximity to Japantown. 

We can in around 3:30 in the afternoon and there was no now in the restaurant, but we were seated quickly and the waiter was really nice.
I am pretty unfamiliar with this food, but my sister pretty much knew what everything was. 

We got three entree: a soft tofu soup with pork (Soondubu Jjigae), another soup with shredded beef and glass noodles (Yuk Gae Jang), and a rice dish with chicken (Dolset Bimibap). and for Apps we got Dumplings (Mandu) and a beef scallion pancake (Pajeon). 

It happened to be a lot of food in the end, because beside what we ordered, we got a ton of sides (banchan), all of which were pretty darn tasty. Our lil sister was with us and she's a pretty picky eater, but she liked everything. 
The soups were both hearty and very filling. My soup was actually a family style dish and the tofu one was more of a single person serving.
The apps were freaking awesome! I would seriously have the pancake or the mandu as a meal, and the dipping sauce that accompanied them was really good. 

The dolset bimibap was pretty good from what I tasted, and my sister loved the chicken that was in it. I tried to get her to mix the whole thing (which is what you're supposed to do), especially because it was served in a hot stone to crisp up the rice.

Overall the meal was filling and tasty, i think with all the food we ordered you could have fed a table of 6 rather than 3, lol. 

This place will be seeing me again soon.
author: Em C.

description: Went early for dinner around 5pm. Found street parking and walked over. No wait at all. 2 days after Christmas and the decorations were still up, liked seeing them still hung. Kpop and popular English songs played from the speakers. Ordered the kimchi pancake, a bi bap, and a soup. All tasted good. Whenever I needed anything and caught the attention of a server (2 on duty), got things right away. Would recommend for friends, family, or date outing with delicious Korean food. Just didn't like the occasional fly I had to show away from the table. Good all around.
author: Thurston W.

description:
I stopped by for a take-out, and the older lady server (possibly the owner) very kindly recommended the $30+ Galbi & Bibimbap, so I ordered these two dishes, plus a mackerel. Thus far, I felt good from the kindness of the lady & the trust I gave her recommendations. Galbi was very tough to chew and its taste was, well, as if I was chewing pieces of cloth. Bibimbap, too, tasted so bad that all the ingredients didn't contribute any flavor - even the spicy sauce ('Gochoojang') didn't help at all. And the mackerel was so dry and not tasty at all. At this point, I and my wife keep asking "How can they (or anyone) ruin the natural taste of all these individual ingredients, even if they tried?".  There's more - the bean sprouts side dish was stale (as if they used old/yesterday's left-over).
Don't go here. Nothing against the young servers/employees, but the older lady (possibly the owner) is very questionable.
author: Leo K.

description:
This is a really decent Korean restaurant. As someone who lived in Korea for a year and a half I can also say it is traditional. It is expensive so not a place I would go often. The Korean pancake was good as was the kimchi soup. I would have expected more side dishes be provided as is traditional in Korea. The side dishes were limited to kimchi, Ming beans and tofu but at the price there should be some more.
The service was good and the guy working there was helpful.
author: Ddc C.

description:
Went here on a cold foggy SF day and the spicy tofu soup, surely hit the spot!

Their Banchan, side dishes, was of a fair variety.

Their Bibimbap was decent - it didn't have that rice crunch on the bottom as much as I would have liked.  Also, they didn't provide the rice barley tea that I ideally prefer to add when finishing up my Bibimbap. 

Their Seafood Pancake had too much of a thick cut green onion to it and not enough seafood pieces in the pancake itself.

The meal was generally pricey ($60 for 2) for mediocrity, but it filled my craving for spicy soup!  Service was attentive, but can't say to that much because it was only about 3 tables that they were serving.

Ultimately, it sufficed!  Where to next?!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
This is a solid Korean restaurant in SF. 

The banchan tastes almost homemade and I was a huge fan of the beef soon dubu. It was really good as leftovers! The grilled mackerel was good and I also recommend trying the dolsot bibimbap. 

Service is decent and good luck finding parking in Japantown :)
author: Michelle K.

description: Insanely slow service. Other people had came in after me and they had their order taken and all the sides placed on their table before I even got my order taken. I've been here before and it was slow but never this slow. There was maybe 8 people in the whole restaurant and they couldn't even bother to take my order until 10 minutes after I sat down. The ladies stay in the back so you can't wave them over to get anything. Trying to get the check...omg...it's like pulling teeth. I just can't come back here
author: L N.

description: Tasty food even tho I dislike Korean food. Parking on street near impossible. Park in garage across the street. Service was excellent. Restaurant was clean and floors carpeted. Many small dish salads per usual Korean restaurants. Free hot Chinese tea which I prefer over the Korean teas.
author: Clifford W.

description: Bad service n they zap u 18% for six ppl or more....even if the sixth person is a small child!
author: mimi l.

description:
Had a lunch with family
We had lunch special ( kalbi tang- beef short rip soup, hae jang gook- beef and vegetable soup)
Both of them were good
But seafood pancake..so disappointed
Not worth to pay $20
Dont order it..dont waste your money
Side dishes were good..looked fresh
Will go back to try bbq on the table soon
author: Jane K.

description:
Visited on a Sunday afternoon, not terribly packed but halfway through our experience, the restaurant filled up! Nonetheless, service was still attentive.

We originally wanted tabletop cooking but upon seeing the price and minimum order of 2, we opted not to.  My husband ordered the bulgogi and I had the soon dubu jigae.  The bulgogi was on the sweeter side, the jigae was good but not brothy enough.  Both were good but pretty pricey, so we felt it was ok.  For the price charged, we expected it to be a little more exciting.

Overall, an ok visit.  Will try others before coming back.
author: Alice T.

description:
Spent our Xmas lunch/dinner meal here. It was quite pricey but has its perks. I would say it is $$ to $$$. 

For those who want to be budget conscious tofu soup is always a safe bet. Korean food comes with small dishes and rice. As long as you aren't afraid of asking for refills on the small dishes, you can really eat a feast. And the tofu soup is for getting some protein, spice and good eaten with rice.

We didn't use the DIY BBQ option on the iron grill because the meat is expensive but we ordered a soup that fends against cold winter (a full chicken and very edible! this is more worthwhile consider it has similar price to other dishes), BBQ short ribs (not sure what it is called, but not your typical short rib but more like rich and delicious meat chunks and a couple very large ribs. It was a bit hard to talk to the people as we don't speak korean) a la carte because my friends love it but don't want to DIY BBQ. Those are pricey but high quality. 

The soup that shields against cold winter (Asian cultures have special names for these soups meant to be drunk on cold days or winter solstice), was quite impressive. It uses a full chicken ginseng chestnuts slow cooked rice and a giant date. Not many restaurants serve that. Big plus for a holiday meal
author: Dilys S.

description: Very lively atmosphere even late at night. Fun experience too. Ordered a ton of meat which was mostly good, did not care for the red sauces chicken much. The flavors just didn't meld well. Garlic chicken was great and of course the beef was too! Even tried the squid! Next time would order a lot more veggies. Meat is awesome and all, but I still need my greens!
author: Briana A.

description: Service was good and prompt! Appetizers flavorful. Food was pretty authentic. pricy but worth every penny! Good place to have dinner with your loved ones very quiet great atmosphere. We will definitely come back for more.
author: Tommy Rainier C.

description: The lunch special is perfect! I don't know why no more guests for order and eating at noon? We tasted it so delicious,we will come back next time.
author: LI F.

description:
10/10/13. Dinner

It's a fact that there isn't enough competition or demand to drive down the prices of Korean BBQ down in San Francisco. There are well-established Korean restaurants in town but they are not in the league of the ones I have in LA.

So...you just have to own up to the choices you have here without spend an arm and leg. New Korea House serves very decent BBQ for the prices they charge. The menu is almost identical to that of Seoul Garden in side the Japan Center.

My BF never had Korean BBQ so this time we only ordered meat. Their appetizers are pretty good. The Haemul Pajon ($19.95) is a savory pancake with shrimp, squid, and clam is my favorite. If you want something of a smaller portion, get the Mung Bean Pancake ($3) and nosh over Soju.

For the evening we tried beef and chicken. At New Korea House, you can BBQ yourself with two or more orders of meat.

*Bulgogi ($20.95): very tender and tasty marinated ribeye. I recommend bulgogi for first-timer. Beef sliced very thin with a tiny but of fat on the edge, making the grill sizzle when you cook. It takes only a few minutes to BBQ half a batch. Eat with rice or wrap the beef with the lettuce.

*Ro Su Gui ($20.95): this is the same sliced beef but not marinated, served only with sesame oil and salt. If you're getting the bulgogi, try to eat the unmarinated beef first.

*Dak Gui ($19.95): lackluster compared to the beef. Boneless chicken breast strips marinated with soy. Since chicken has to be fully cooked, after bring BBQ on the grill for a while, chicken became dry. BF agreed we can skip the chicken next time!

The overall meal was very sumptuous, with all-you-can-eat ban chai. Kimchi, sweet potato, pickled radish, bean sprouts, glazed nuts, seaweeds and jasmine rice. Service is attentive enough. Price is reasonable.

They don't take reservation, so get there early on weekends. We were the first party for dinner at 7 on Friday night but the place filled up quickly about halfway through our meal.
author: Matt Y.

description:
3.5 stars. The bbq and little side dishes are all pretty good. Kind of pricey though. Expect dinner entrees to be around $25-30 a person. Dinner is do-it-yourself grill at the table. So you will smell like bbq afterwards. I recommend the bulgogi (bbq beef), pork belly (almost like bacon, to be dipped in sesame sauce), bbq chicken and tofu soup. Portions could be bigger, but we got a second bowl of rice in order to be full. No wait for a seat on a Saturday night.

They offer lunch specials on weekday afternoons. Lunch is cooked in the kitchen.
author: Ali F.

description:
I stopped by here on an afternoon looking for Tofu Soup. In hindsight, probably not the right place for soup.. Most people were ordering the barbecue and it did look and smell pretty delicious. I will have to come back and see how it is. 

The soup was ok.. It seemed a little small, and a little short on non-tofu.. but the flavor was good. The banchan was pretty good. I left feeling a little hungry.. and still wanting a fried fish.. (Tofu soup shops will usually provide a fried fish appetizer for the soup).
author: James S.

description:
TERRRRRIBLE!! Don't ever like to leave a bad review but this place was awful! Should have known walking through the door at 8pm on a Saturday night and it not even being half full! 
We ordered the Kalbi and the pork to grill ourselves. The Kalbi was probably the worst meat I've ever had! So chewy I had to spit it out! The pork had ZERO seasoning on it. 
Service was fast which was nice but completely lacked any personality. 
STAY AWAY!
author: Jodi E.

description:
I'm not sure if I was in the Old Korea House or the New Korea House, but sure enough, it was the Old Ed that came here along with Jamie W., who picked the place because he used to come here with his long-time bud Ed, who must be Old Old Ed, or maybe that makes me the Spanking New Ed. Pause for beaming. Anyway, old or new, Korea House strikes me as a rather bland place. The Korean barbecue places out in the Richmond make you reek of smoke, and you can count on some guy in a wife-beater carrying a bucket of coal to your table.

Here at Korea House, it feels downright suburban, a family-friendly place like a Denny's in downtown Seoul or a Soulless Denny's, take your pick. I noticed no one was getting their fire hole lit up here probably because it's a safety hazard with all the toddlers running riot. We went predictable. Jamie ordered the standard-regulation $13.95 Bi Bim Bop, which mixed slices of marinated ribeye, veggies and an already fried egg on top of rice (see photo). It was a mistake because it came lukewarm. For only a dollar more, I got the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bop, which came with the same ingredients in a sizzling stone bowl (see photo).

The egg was raw, which I prefer, and the crust that develops on the rice at the bottom is worth savoring. As a starter, we ordered a couple of the $3 Bean Dae Duk, which are mung bean egg pancakes that came with a sweet dipping sauce (see photo). Given how bland the pancakes were, they tasted better with the red chili paste. And as with any Korean restaurant worth its salt, we were served ten little dishes of banchan, bite-size appetizers of just about everything that can be pickled (see photo). Service was nothing to complain about. They were attentive despite the growing number of tables that were filling up. Popular place.

FOOD - 3 stars...standard Korean with no stand-outs
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...pretty generic as Korean places go
SERVICE - 4 stars...very attentive
TOTAL - 3 stars...bi bim bop goes boom
author: Ed U.

description:
SF severely lacks in good Korean restaurants.  However I think this may be one of the better choices for dolsot bibimbap in this city when heading to the Southbay is too far of a drive for just a quick Korean dinner. 

First off they far exceeded my expectations when our server turned out to be friendly, smiley and pleasant. From my experience you aren't given the best service in Korean restaurants. 

Banchans were served immediately after ordering and my piping hot bowl of dolsot veggie bibimbap arrived in no time. It had very good flavoring and the bowl was hot enough to brown and crisp up the rice at the bottom. That tends to be my favorite part of any dolsot bibimbaps.

I'm sure ill be back to try their other dishes.
author: Esther A.

description:
We ended up at New Korea House since the wait at YakiniQ was extremely long. It was 8PM on a Sunday and we were starving!

I've had my share of Korean food and unfortunately this place just wasnt up to par with the rest. We ordered our usual: kalbi, grilled chicken and green onion pancakes. The kalbi was pretty expensive ($28.95) and the portion/taste just wasn't adequate. The grilled chicken was really salty and the green onion pancakes were only average.
author: M W.

description:
My experience here was ok. I think if you're Asian/Asian descent/look somewhat Asian you'll get good/better service here. 

The waitress got my order wrong and then clearly didn't understand what I ordered. Proven when they still got it wrong the second time around and I just gave up trying because I was quite hungry at that point.

Food wise it was alright. Nothing amazing but if you're looking for Korean food this can kill the craving.
author: Asa R.

description: Quality meat, but not a large serving size. The sides served were very good and the service was helpful.
author: Fernilla S.

description: No one working the front.  the sign in sheet I didn't even notice.  Service was alright it was only two people working for a packed restaurant. Food was good. The seafood pancake is a must!
author: Dyana P.

description:
Terrible, the grill looked clean, when we wiped it with a paper towel, it was dirty. The meat was also not well prepared. This place used to be crowed with people, I understand now why there are no customers. The taste is bad, and overpriced. 

I mention to the server the meat looks different, and he says "you probably got the wrong restaurant" 

It was better many years ago when the waitresses did not spoke a word of English.
author: David L.

description:
We have been eating at the New Korea House a few years ago. When we came back we were very surprised about the renovations they have done to the restaurant. We liked it even more than before. Great atmosphere, very nice service and great food.

We had the Bibim Bap and it was great. They were generous with extra vegetables and Kim Chi.

I do recommend this place, I think it's great.
author: Guido W.

description:
Very Disappointed. It was either between here or the next door KoreanBBQ. Apparently my boyfriend and I made the wrong choice. 
Were from Fresno so there's not a lot of Korean BBQ places there, so every opportunity we go out of town we find one. We came to this one and will not be returning ever again. 
First of all, we came in and no one was in sight to help. We stood there like idiots. Then finally this guy comes and sat us down. He gave us our menus and walked away. No one noticed if we were first timers (which we were) or not, so we were confused about the menu but we figured it out anyways. Took 10 minutes for us to get the waiter's attention.
We ordered the dinner special for 2 (dinner A). And he said OK. We waited an extra 10 for the first part of our food. Then added on another 15 mintues for our meat and the rest of our order to come out. 
The raw meat was VERY bland. Not even salt on it, we had to put our own table salt on it. The only good thing was the stir fry clear noodle, dumpling soup, and the kimchi radish. Funny cuz they're side dishes. Anyways, poor service. No one came to ask us how we were doing and I had chase down this lady for a glass of water. The water was in a little glass cup. Also, the waiting line grew longer and it took 30 or more minutes for anyone to notice those people waiting for a table. This place is just horrible. 
I thought the food was bad but my bill came even worse. I understand things are pricey but this meal was the most priciest Korean BBQ I've ever paid for . If you're reading this and thinking about dining here, don't waste your time. Take my advice.
author: Jessie C.

description: If you're craving authentic Korean, this is your place. I couldn't have been happier with all the food. Kimchi quality was fantastic.
author: Nathan N.

description:
My review is entirely for the service we got. We went here for lunch on a Sunday. It wasn't so crowded then, maybe with 7 tables open. We love to go to New Korea House during special occasions, this time it was my mom's birthday. Everything went fine, we ordered our usual, food is great! We then asked our server, a guy with glasses, to take a picture of us, and he's like "No, I'm busy" It's a special day, and we wanted to just preserve a memory, pretty sure it won't take a minute! We understand if it's busy, but he could have said, "it's busy now - and maybe later?" Anyway, when we were talking about it within our family at our table, the guy server gave rude replies about how we cannot comment on it. When we asked another server, what the guy's name is, she said she does not know. Completely covering up for him. She gave us some sweet rice dish as a compensation for what happened, maybe? But meh.

Overall, food is good, flavorful but a bit pricey. Check them out especially if you want a rude waiter!
author: Robyn P.

description: The Rib eye was very good. Some sides were more to my taste then others but overall a good korean spot to possibly hit up uf your in town. The meat was cooked in the kitchen instead of in front of me, I prefer in front of me but if you dont mind its ok.
author: Roger M.

description:
It serves breakfast, which is great in this area.
Very nice attendant! Service is good.
author: David L.

description:
The mak jang..totally disappointing..u'll get high blood pressure from this. Not only did this come in a smaller pot, it was half full, no tofu..hardly any broth..n sodium up the ass...they need a warning for this..seriously..

although #4 was a lot better, it was bigger, had tofu, not as salty..

 like the side dishes as this is the first place that had tofu as a side..two types of bean sprouts..i like the lighter one..

service was eh..they weren't even busy..maybe one other customer..all that was $33 bucks..not worth it..well at least for mine..i was so disappointed..
author: Minerva L.

description:
Korea House is decent. The dolsot bi bim bap is perfect! The menu selection, however, is not. Instead, what you'll find is merely the SF-Korean status quo. This means there aren't a whole lot of amazing banchan and it's certainly not going to blow you away like you'll find in SoCal.

Korea House has normal prices, but it's fairly expensive if you order a la carte. Approximately $20 per meat, with a minimum 2 dish order if you want to self-grill. Kinda pricey when you compare it to the $19.99 all you can eat next door at YakiniQ.

The service here is slow because there aren't enough servers. Maybe I'm hyper-sensitive but they have a sliiight tinge of an attitude
author: Calvin W.

description:
Quality of meat = good

Flavors = missing.  Daeji bulgogi was boring.  How is that possible?!? 

Prices = expensive.  They've jacked up the prices and no longer offer the AYCE style. 

Overall, I won't be bringing anymore friends here.  

What a sadness....
author: Fannie S.

description: Ordered bibimbaq, nothing surprising, just average. Price a little higher than what I would pay for.
author: Hansen L.

description:
Stopped by for lunch with a friend that lives in San Fran. The lunch menu was a bit limited but had enough variety. We both ordered the Dot Sol Bi Bim Bap in the sizzling bowl.  

The flavors were nice but pretty standard. My mistake was digging in too fast before the rice could get really crispy. 

The wait staff was friendly and grandma brought out extra Kim chee and sides for us. Overall not a bad choice.

There is a parking garage nearby and the added bonus of exploring Japantown after you eat.
author: Trisha G.

description: I have tired Kalbi there.  It came with soybean paste soup.  The meat was tough and the soup was super salty.  I know SF is not the capital of korean food like LA.  But even with low expectation, I was disappointed.
author: June K.

description: five stars for me because its delicious and its the first place I've found that offers a vegetarian version of their tofu soup!  The service has always been prompt, the place is clean and did i mention its delicious?
author: Stephanie M.

description:
My parents are pretty predictable, and usually when I visit them in SF they suggest we go out to a Korean meal together. That's fine with me since although I live in LA, I rarely make it out to Koreatown to get some authentic cuisine from the motherland. 

This time around we came on a Sunday evening and the place was still pretty empty at about 7pm. I came starving so I dove right into the banchan, which was fresh and tasty... and the waitress was generous about offering us more of any of it that we wanted. 

I had the dolsot bibimbap and the dduk gook, which for you not in the know is rice mixed with meat and veggies (and an egg, yum) in a stone pot, as well as a yummy beef broth soup with little rice cakes floating inside. Two of my faves, even if they're not necessarily very original orders. Both were delish! 

I'd say the prices are a bit higher than what I'm used to seeing at Korean restaurants, but my mom assured me that this was normal as 'Korean food is so cool now.' Oh, parents!
author: Christina P.

description:
We came here as a big group and it was a lot of fun.  We ordered a ton of food - including kalbi, bulgogi, pancakes, tofu, japchae, and more, so we were all stuffed by the end.   The food does take some time to come out (plus you then have to BBQ), so don't take too long to order.  

The wine selection generated a lot of amusement - you basically choose red or wine and then they come out with a couple of (seemingly random) bottles for you to choose from.  This was definitely hit or miss.  Our first bottle was bleh, but our second bottle was actually decent.  (We were split as to whether that was because we had already finished the first bottle and were not nearly as picky, but never mind that).  At the other table in our group, both bottles were below par.   Probably safer to stick with beer.  The wine glasses also come out in different shapes and sizes, and they're all chilled and frosted.  Very curious.  

Overall a fun evening and prime location to go to Karaoke afterwards!
author: Vivian W.

description: Average Korean food, including uninspired ban chan. Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description: Unlike others, service was decent but food was terrible. We had the seafood pancake, beef soup, and pork belly. They told us if we order one plate of meat we couldn't grill it in front of us and they would have to cook it. We agreed but these came as dry as rubber. For like 8 slices of rubber that had mild bacon flavor, 20 dollars is a bit ridiculous. Pancake was mediocre and not memorable. The best was the beef broth, but it's not good enough to come here just for that.
author: Rowena N.

description:
I came here with my friend Lilly who does live in SF. I don't live in SF. I honestly wish I did but anyway. 

I didn't really know there were any Korean restaurants, but Im so glad my friend Lilly introduced me to this place. I really love their bimimbop! The portions are huge and I barely was able to finish it. 

I will definitely come again when I came back to SF to visit my friends and family :)
author: Sandy T.

description:
We haven't been back to this restaurant in years, back when it was in another building nearby and you had to go up the stairs.
I was reticent about dining here due to some of the poor reviews but was pleasantly surprised that the food isn't as bad as folks say.  
Since it was BFF's hubby's birthday dinner pick, we all tried dinner #B, it was about $40/per person which is pricey.
There was a total of about 8 tiny dishes, 2 sprouts, turnip, tofu, kim chee (mild), soy dipping sauce, etc.  
The meal came with 2 short ribs and slices of meat per person, 2 dumplings in soup per person, a dish with 4 each: tofu slices and a cod egg pancake-like dish (comparable to egg foo yong in Chinese dishes).  All were pretty good and plenty filling.  We also had sweet potato clear noodle mixed with vegts.  Hubby and I had lots of leftovers to take home and even BFF & her Hubby, who can beat us hands down in an eating contest,  had leftovers.  
There were at least 7 other tables occupied by diners on a Saturday and a big table of 6 men came in later and were the only table to BBQ their own food which really started to smell up the place with food odor.

I think the price is prohibitive for most diners.  As we left, we passed by another Korean BBQ full of young hipsters. They flashed an electronic sign $20 for all you can eat and other meals were about $25.  Not sure about the quality and quantity of food but guaranteed that the noise volume will be much higher. 

BFF's Hubby says he's not into going to places like that anymore that's cheaper and more popular. He'd rather dine in a quiet restaurant, which is what you get at New Korea House - better suited for families and having a conversation.
author: Ry T.

description: ONE OF THE MOST AMAZING KOREAN RESTAURANT EVER! I love almost everything we ordered. The Dolsot Bibimbap was my fav. Japchae, Kalbi, Bulgogi was also really yummy. The Kimchi shigae was okay but nothing to rave about and the seafood pancake was..ehhh. Loved the variety of ban chan too.
author: Jenny N.

description: Arrived here on a sunny yet wet day at japan town on a Saturday afternoon. We just finished watching the wind rises and were starving. We were seated right away. We ordered the ddaro guk bap, dolsot bap and mandu. The ban chans were unlimited so we ate about 3 rounds of them. The food came shortly after we ordered. The food here is decent with great service. If I had a chance to come back again, I would.
author: Michelle D.

description: Our nonprofit had a holiday at New Korea House in December 2013. The food was great. It was tasty and fresh.  The service was perfect and very accommodating. The setting at New Korea House was just what we needed. We were about 25 people and we took up a few tables. It wasn't too loud and we were able to talk and eat in a festive and somewhat intimate environment. Although we didn't have our own room (as the restaurant does not have them), we didn't feel like that was a drawback. We were able to put together an affordable menu for all kinds of vegetarian and meat eaters. Some people ordered dishes on their own, too. We definitely recommend this! Your group also has options to park in the Japan Town Center parking, which can be helpful, too. I included some pictures on Yelp.
author: Alexa L.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Soondubu, Korean Tofu Stew.  We just recently moved to the City from Mountain View, so I've been on the hunt to find a place that is as good as So Gong Dong Tofu House in Palo Alto.  This was not it.

The stew was very watery, not spicy enough, and way too fishy. Also, it didn't come with an egg as this dish usually does.  We had the foresight to order some Bibimbap as well, which was good - but not Tofu House good.  The appetizers were alright, and there were many of them... but all in all they were just disappointing.

I did like the tea that they served with the meal, a green tea with toasted rice that is one of my favorites.

We probably won't be back.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
This 2-star review isn't written out of spite. It was just meh.

Here's what I noticed:

Really high prices ($13 yukgae jang for breakfast)
Dinky servings (a few strands of meat and clear noodles, but filled with scallions...)
Mediocre banchan (just some kimchi and bean sprouts)
Not very clean (big soy sauce spill in the middle of our sticky table)

I would definitely prefer to make my own Korean food. The Korean places in Richmond aren't great, but better than this.
author: Jeena C.

description: I was craving Korean food and decided to pick up some togo from this place. I have to say it was probably the best blind try I have ever hit. I ordered the beef bulgogi and spicy tofu soup. Words can not describe the happiness I felt as I opened up my togo bag and pulled out boxes upon boxes of goodies. The beef was so good. Marinated just right and soft. The tofu soup was uh-ma-zing. So good. Perfect in every way. I asked for extra kim chee (charged me extra) which came along with a box of side dishes (spouts, pickled radishes etc.) I was so happy. This place is awesome. Check it out.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Came in here despite the average ratings, because I was really craving Korean food and options are limited in this city and I'd already been next door at Yakini Q.

Food:
Ordered the Vegetarian Bi Bim Bap and the Steak Bi Bim Bap. 

They give you lots of little side dishes to mix into your entree but they do not give enough meat/tofu in the bowl. Kind of a ripoff for $16/plate.

Service:
Our server was pleasant and explained all the food to us patiently

Ambience:
Spacious and clean

Would not come back again. If you're craving Korean BBQ, your best bet is YakiniQ even though it is more expensive. At least it's all you can eat for $23.99!
author: Sangita A.

description: went here a couple of days ago for a date night with the fiance. Food was ok but not OMG. The fiance also wanted kal bi jim which is a key dish but korean restaurants but this place did not have it. He got the Kal Bi BBQ instead and I got the chicken Bi Bim Bap. They were nice to sub out the rice for lettuce. For the price though the amount of chicken was kinda skimpy but otherwise nice array of veggies. The Kal Bi wasn't taht big either but the fiance did like it. They also give you about 6 or 7 banchans.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
We walked in and went upstairs...kind of wondering where the front desk was. No one greeted us. We stood there confused on whether we should seat ourselves. Finally, an elder Japanese man having lunch with his wife suggested we have a seat. 

Ambiance was simple, clean and decorated with a huge fish tank in the middle of the restaurant. 

The Lunch Specials aren't that badly priced, but more on the pricey end. It was $8.95 for chicken bbq which includes hot tea and side dishes. The side dishes weren't the best, but were mediocre. The chicken bbq was average too, but still good. It was served on a white plate with some veggies, two slices of orange and rice. 

As expected, the service was more on the slow side. No place I would go out of my way to visit again. Oh...but they did give us some Sweet Korean Rice Tea at the end for dessert. :)
author: Wana L.

description:
My husband and I stopped in at New Korea House for lunch today. We ordered Kom Tang, Kimchi Jigae and Bean Dae Duk. All the food, including the ban chan was incredibly delicious. I'm Korean-American and grew up with good home-cooked Korean meals, and this food definitely tasted fresh and like my mom's cooking.

I have been to this restaurant in the past and didn't remember it being so good. Is there a new owner or cook?

The restaurant was not very crowded unfortunately. Hopefully if they keep making their food as delicious as it was today, that the place will prosper. I know that I will definitely be back.
author: Juliet S.

description:
This was the day I had two lunches - rather I paid for one but didn't eat it and the unfortunate experience was at New Korea House.  I had ordered the Tofu Soup with hot bean paste and no where on the menu did it say that it was not vegetarian (because everything else had meat and seafood in it and described it so).

When the soup arrived, it had clams and shrimp in it and when I asked the waitress (who spoke little English) she said that the lunch soup had seafood but the dinner soup was vegetarian and costs more.

So I asked her if I could change it and her exact answer was, "No, you can't because you made the mistake..." I looked at her and said, "Can I have the check please?" She dilly-dallied with the check and came back and gingerly said, "the chef is making you a vegetable one now..." Why? Because I wasn't going to take your bs insult and eat the seafood soup like a good Asian girl?

I told her that she was rude and since it was my first time eating there how was I to know the difference between the lunch soup and dinner soup and I was clearly following the menu.  And how dare she blame the customer?

Consider themselves lucky that I actually paid for the goddamn soup which I didn't eat - $11.91 no tip obviously.  What goes around comes around, that's all I can say.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
I've been to several Korean restaurants in San Francisco and New Korea House is consistently the best of the lot. Every meal there is top notch. If you are looking for great Korean then this is the place.

I'm a big fan of kalbi and Korean BBQ in general and the meat at New Korea House is fantastic. The marinate strikes that perfect combination of salty, sweet, and spicy. It's complimented nicely by the assortment of side dishes that are always fresh and flavorful.

The noodles and the soups are also phenomenal. Some restaurants make these dishes too salty or too oily but not at New Korea House. I find that the daro gook to be my favorite.

New Korea House is definitely one my "go to" restaurants anytime I want a good meal. I highly recommend it!
author: Jerry C.

description:
Came here for lunch. I wanted to have lunch next door at Yankiq but it wasn't open.

1. Too expensive for what they give you. I ordered bulgogi and short ribs and it was $55 for the whole bill.
2. There was only one waitress and she doesn't speak English too good. 
3. They don't have all the Korean bbq sides that I would usually get from another spot.

I felt like I wasted my money. 1 star.
author: Dina T.

description:
I had stumbled upon New Korea House when I went to meet up with my friend during my vacation in San Franciso.  I'm sure we can all agree that food tastes a lot better on vacation, right?

Well it wasn't exactly the case here.  My friend had ordered bulgogi and I had the bibimbap.  Everything tasted yummy but it's nothing that I can't order from Arizona.  

Regardless, the place was clean, the staff was friendly, and the food tasted great.
author: Joyce W.

description:
Sometimes relegated to stepsister status by the splendiferous grandeur of older sister YakiniQ, New Korea House should not be dismissed. 

NKH also offers Korean BBQ that you can order made, or cook yourself, and they do give you a semi reasonable amount for the price you pay. Surely, it's not the unlimited that YakiniQ offers, but when you have a really strong, pulsating hankering for some marinated meats, and you are not trying to wait 2 hours for a table, then NKH is the place to go.
author: Joshua L.

description:
This place didn't have all you could eat bbq so we were skeptical at first if we wanted to eat here. It was a late Friday night and everywhere wiser was full but this place was pretty empty so we ate here. 

There were four of us dudes in total so we got three plates of meat. They were all pretty tasty. We got to cook it on the grill. Even though it didn't look like a lot of food, it was pretty good and we all good full.

Overall, this it a little quiet Korean restaurant that has some tasty meat.

Pros:
- Quiet and few people
- Tasty meat
- Get to cook the meat yourselves

Cons:
- For the price of the plate of meat, it didn't look like a lot (but we still got full from it)
author: Paul U.

description:
Another adventure in the city with an old childhood friend and it was "fantastic baby" ...Big Bang song... (Highly doubt anybody would've got that, unless you are a Kpop fan :P LOL). 
After walking about 2 miles to Japan Town my friend and I were pretty famished so I was SO HAPPY to stumble upon Korean House Restaurant right across the street from J Town. I was a happy girl for sure. 

Korean House Restaurant is such a homey place, great for an authentic Korean meal. We were welcomed in Korean and I just wished I knew a bit more Korean to correspond back. The ban chan that they served was delicious!  I had a few bites, but Celiacs should be aware that most Korean food contains wheat, at least what they serve in restaurants. The hot pepper paste does contain wheat from the soy sauce and the malt or barley powder that they use. 
I ordered the Dolsot Bibimbap which comes served in a stone clay pot and it was piping hot! As long as you don't add the Gochujang sauce the dish is naturally gluten free. 
The Bibimbap was so delicious the crusty rice that forms at the bottom of the clay pot gets super crispy and flavorful as you mix all the meats and veggies together with the raw egg! I was so excited to dig in that I forgot to take a picture when it was first brought to the table, hence, the crappy picture. 

My friend ordered the Japchae which is traditionally made with lots of soy sauce so I just took some pictures of the deliciousness
author: Tiffany L.

description:
GB was suppose to take me to this poshy, only 10 seats Japanese Sushi place. Then I tell him... "sweetie sorry, I don't do raw fish" - he looked so sad. He even wore shoes for me!

Thus, off we went... we trekked back down to the parking lot and saw a bunch of Korean res. He said to walk back and forth to figure out what I really want. Then I told him to Yelp which one was good... I know I was being lazy! He wanted to go back here because it was Zagat rated. I said sure, why not.

We came in and the place was semi-busy for a Thursday night. I told him that I hope we don't have to cook our food b/c I was starving. He said he could grill it... I said ok b/c I don't grill as well. He just gave me the look and asked what exactly do I do... I just smiled =)

We ordered the meal for two for $37+ and it came with a lot of stuff. They don't have a menu online but if you do go, it's the middle one. It came with kalbi and jap chae (gosh I hope I'm typing this all right...you'd think I'd know all these by heart!)

GB ordered soju (didn't catch the name) but it was smooth. I only had half a shot glass b/c I'm limiting my alcohol intake in preparation for my birthday =)

Anyway, GB asked if they could cook it instead of us. Wow, I didn't know that you could ask that but that was cool. Food started coming in slowly. The usual appetizers but they had more. I opted for the non spicy stuff of course. Then came the fried tofu and oysters omelet like, with the dumpling soup and then the kalbi and the noodles. 

Overall, the food was tasty BUT the kalbi. I would need to take GB to SJ Omawari in San Jose for that. 

Service was good and friendly and FAST! 

Satisfied my protein hunger...good conversation with GB and at the end, I killed two birds with one stone by having this dinner. 

Will probably not come back here anytime soon... Gotta find my new Korean spot in SF!
author: Cath M.

description: Awesome Korean restaurant! Great vibe, food and really nice staff. Great for groups or for a fun date. Karaoke nearby for anyone who wants to have even more fun! Would recommend to anyone.
author: Mary M.

description:
This year we had a unique confluence of special days on the calendar. In one Sunday Night, you had Valentine's Day, Chinese New Year and Tet, all falling on President's day weekend, where a lot of people were out on a Sunday like it was Saturday. 

Consequently, you know a lot of restaurants would be crowded. All the Chinese and Vietnamese would have families celebrating, all the fine dining spots of French, Nouvelle, Steakhouse and similar places would be packed with couples, so where to go?

I headed for Japan Town. All of the restaurants there had waiting lines, too. So I went to an old stand by, a restaurant I used to go to a long time ago late at night after partying in the city because they were open until 3:00 am on Saturdays, and that was Korea House. 

Korea House is a popular name for a KBBQ place. Before i used to go to the one in Santa Clara, which burned down, and years later the owner reopened in Concord under the same name, and is one of my faves. But before there was a New Korea House downstairs, I used to go to this one, up the flight of stairs to a room full of hooded tables and in table cooking grills. 

It hasn't changed much. I am not sure if it is open real late still, but the rest is as I remembered it. It is cheaper than Seoul Garden in the J-Town mall and just as good if not better.

We ordered Bulgogi (marinated beef $19.95) and Sam Gyup Sal (pork bellies $19.95). Out came a mountain of appetizers, 11 Banchan in all! We started with a large plate of pickled. non-spiced napa cabbage. Raddish soup. Then 10 banchan. then a large plate of chopped Romaine lettuce, and two platters of meat. 

Although the side dishes were impressive, the meat wasn't particularly. The Bulgogi was good, but I have had more meat, better marinade, and better tasting. The Sam Gyup Sal wasn't the best, either, as I have had much better down in K-Town in LA or the OC. And down in SoCal there is a price war going on, so it is cheaper.

Service was good, but there were only 3 people working including the cook, so they were pressed to keep up with nearly a full house.  

Korea House is still a reliable go to KBBQ house in Japan Town after all these years.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Korean isn't as prevalent in the Bay Area as other Asian cuisines so it's good to find a stable Korean BBQ offering. The prices for the meat dishes aren't the cheapest but the servings are a decent size and the banchan are plentiful so I always factor this into the price. The restaurant has good gas BBQs built into the table and the staff always ask if you want to cook or have them do this. I like this because some diners don't like to handle the fire but I prefer to take time to cook and enjoy the drinks and conversation. The BBQ and the dumplings are pretty good but the best thing here is the soon doobu - spicy soft tofu. Service is attentive and food comes out fast; good for a mid week date.
author: Amaya B.

description:
Came here with the BF tonight for dinner. We ordered the sizzling bim bam bop and this stew with rice cakes since I have never tried rice cakes.

The decor is really nice better than the other Korean places I have been to in the city. The staff is pretty good. We were able to get a second round of appetizers but like half the dishes which is completely fine. They offered a good amount of appetizers the first round. Delish!

The bim bam bop was good but I really enjoyed the stew with the potstickers. The potstickers were alright. Trader Joes has better ones. What I really enjoyed was the rice cakes! They taste like tong yuan Chinese starch balls?? 

Overall the experience here is good. I've been here before and I would like to come back.

Another plus- I believe there are three stalls in the women bathroom. =]
author: Sarah C.

description:
We have chosen this place cause it was last minute and we were hungry. This place is over priced and the service here sucks. Food was descent, and i could find better places with a more variety than what they have here. 
ehh.
author: Vicky H.

description: The Dolset Bimimbop is great here. Also the accompanying dishes kimchi, bean sprout etc were delicious. A step above most places. Nice atmosphere too.
author: Karen S.

description: I had never had Korean food before but was staying at the Kabuki hotel opposite and thought why not. I didnt have a clue what to order but a taxi driver told me to try the Bibimbap. It was delicious. Lots of fresh vegetables, steaming hot rice and a fried egg to boot. Very tasty and lasted a long time. I have decided that  I now like Korean food :-) Service was super quick but quite blunt.
author: Proteus D.

description:
In the mood for Korean BBQ...the bf and I found ourselves dining here. The atmosphere of the restaurant was very warm and comfortable and the service was spot on (friendly, very attentive). This is a fabulous place for a date night or dinner with a group of friends. 

What we ordered...
*We went the Barbeque route (grill at the table) - we decided on the Bul Go Gi (thin slices of sirloin in our house soy marinade) and Busut Gui (mushrooms seasoned in a soy marinade). Both were seasoned well and the portions were pretty large, especially the mushrooms. Both also came with sliced white onions to grill. 
*BBQ was served with soup, rice and sides (kimchi, soy beans, bean paste, pickled radish & carrots)
*Sang Sun Jun cod fillets dipped in egg batter and fried sewed with a say dipping sauce. 
*Sake - hot and delicious. 

Prices (especially for the group meals) can be on the higher end, but I promise you will leave very satisfied. The Rice, Bibimbop and Soup bowls are very reasonable though. 

Bonus - as soon as you sit down and start checking over the menu...complimentary hot tea is brought to the table. Nice. 

Overall...tasty, fresh Korean BBQ with fabulous service...what else could you ask for? Give them a try soon!
author: Dru M.

description: Saw the reviews but wanted to give this place a chance since we were korean. Sorry we did. Over priced. Food was subpar. Place was pretty empty but the waitress set the tables before giving us water and giving us our side dishes. Best part, she placed the tray of food for another group on our table to serve them. HORRIBLE SERVICE.
author: Paul K.

description:
New Korea House...well you were very clean and had pretty decor 

BUT the food was good/ ehh i've experienced better but not bad or anything like that.

my friends and i ordered: 
Yukhae Jang- a spicy beef brisket soup with peppers, veggies, glass noodles and a whipped egg.
- we asked the server if they could make it less spicy since one of my friends cant really handle spice and it still had a lil kick to the soup and the glass noodles...well there wasn't a lot of them it felt like =\ 

Grill Bulgogi- marinated ribeye
- was good, my friend said she has had better but it wasnt bad. Also if you order 2 or more BBQ dishes they'll let you grill the meat yourself 

and a tofu stew 
- i felt the tofu stew was just average was good and between the 3 of use we finished it but was just average nothing mind blowing.

and actually for the price of the food it was a little bit on the costly side but the portions of the food were a lil bigger which makes up for it i guess...ehh i could be wrong maybe.

the service was okay could have been a little more attentive but they did let us sit and around and talk for like 30mins after we finished eating and paid the check. 

my advise is to actually get one of the pre-set dinners specially if you have like a group of 3 to 5.
author: Matt F.

description:
My expectations for all the restaurants were low today because of the large crowds at the JPop Summit but I expected them to at least move quickly. We walked into the restaurant because the lines for the ramen booths were circling around the block.  The line at the restaurant was fairly short and we should have taken that as a clue. We waited in line for 30 mins and the line was not moving- very odd!  We looked inside and there was no wait staff!!  Another 20 mins passed and we saw people leaving. We thought to ourselves "great! We're up next".  Another 20 mins passed and we were still not seated!  I looked into the restaurant and half the restaurant was empty!! The other half was waiting for their check. The staff? No where to be seen!  The entire restaurant was ran by 2 people and one of them was having a hard time calculating the check. 1.5 hour later, we were finally seated. 

The food took 30 mins to come out. They were so disorganized that other tables were getting beers out of their back fridges themselves!  Their menu states the lunch specials are available everyday except holidays but they ended up charging us full prices for the dishes. 1 kalbi, 1 bbq chicken, 1 japchae and 1 seafood pancake come out to be $100!!!!  Ridiculously overpriced food!

If your not in a rush or not parking in a metered spot and want overpriced Korean food, try this place out.  There are many much better options in st!!
author: m c.

description:
Not a bad place for korean, but nothing compared to LA places. i guess i have to lower my standards for SF, but they should be significantly lowered right?

Pros:
-korean places in sf are rare, especially more authentic ones
-soon tofu was good and the side dishses were yummy
-they had a pretty diverse array of side dishes, especially fish cake which is my favorite!

Con:
-pricey for korean food, its meant to be cheap!
-everything besides the soon tofu was just ok
author: Thach N.

description: Food was good but seems to be pricy. Maybe it's the area. Could find better Korean food with better prices
author: Tracy D.

description: I loved this place! The number of sides they give you here is impressive, and the meat is tasty. We ordered chicken and beef on a recent dinner trip. I thought the service was good in spite of our late night, post-movie dining time.
author: Dani D.

description:
Always a great time and great food- the go to for Korean in San Francisco. 

Highly recommend the short ribs especially.
author: Brian T.

description:
I've been here a couple times now.  The first time I came, I got bibimbap, which was good.  It was pretty much exactly what you'd expect of bibimbap, crunchy fresh veggies and fried egg over rice.  It was a warm day so I was glad I got what I wanted.  The second time I had japchae, which was also good, but I was less excited about it than the bibimbap.

What really makes this place great, however, are the side dishes they give you.  The waitress just shows up at your table with a huge tray of dishes and covers most of the table with little tastes of just about everything you could imagine. Each time I've gone there have been a few types of kimchee, fish cakes, sprouts, and several other things.
author: Marty F.

description:
It's been a while since I've reviewed a business on Yelp, but I had another great experience at New Korea House recently that inspired me to review again.  New Korea House is my favorite Korean restaurant in SF.  I first went to NKH a few years ago based on a friend's recommendation and have returned often because of the clean atmosphere, great food, and even better service.  It's the perfect place to catch up with friends, while enjoying delicious, well-prepared food.  Regardless if I am with my Korean or non-Korean speaking friends, the wait staff consistently treats us with friendly, prompt, and attentive service (unlike some of the other not-so-friendly, and dingy Korean places in the Richmond).  Several times the the owner (a really nice Korean lady) has come out to give us a free dish, simply as a courtesy.  Talk about "service"!

I recommend the spicy pork and naegmyun.  The kalbi is always really great too (make sure you cook the bones too so you can give them to your dog :)).  They use very good quality meat and the marinade / flavor is highly addictive!  I've lived in both NY and LA, and NKH certainly rivals the best BBQ places in those respective KTowns.  One added benefit: parking is very convenient.  It's located right across the the street from Japantown.  You can watch a movie at Kabuki or get ice cream afterward... although just a warning:  you might not have room for that ice cream after a delicious and filling meal from NKH.
author: Catherine D.

description: The food was pretty good but the service was excellent, and I would go back just to have her bring us food. She was very nice, telling us things like you shouldn't cut nengmyun noodles too many times or it loses it's taste, etc. The thing I didn't like was actually the hot sauce (gochoojang) for the mixed rice (bibimbap). It was not very spicy but also tasted a little weird. I would avoid that and go for some mainstream items or some barbeque. However she was so sweet and nice I would get anything from here and leave happy.
author: Alex K.

description:
I've been to Korea House several times but never commented on it before.

If you're looking for something a little different when you're in J-town, you have the choice of Chinese and/or Korean food on the block of Post on the hill across from the Miyako Hotel.  Korea House is one of two on the block.  I've never been to the other one.  No sure why but I always choose KH because I find the "look" of the dining area appealing.  Nothing special about it; just the normal layout of BBQ tables on each side of the room with a couple of large tales for big groups.

I almost always go to Korean restaurants only for the BBQ.  So, I can't speak about any other dishes. but I the BBQ is very good.  KH also has very good fans over the grills; you don't smell like BBQ when you leave and a decent selection of banchan w/unlimited refills.  Oddly, they charge extra for seaweed ($2) and lettuce ($4) which is a little steep but they give reasonable refills if you run out.  

Had kalbi ($29) and chicken ($20) on the trip tonight.  They precut the kalb for you rather than giving you a long strip attached to the bone (which is ok by me) but they still leave the bones on the plate for you to grill (if you like) as I like to do.  The kalbi is nicely marinated as is the chicken.  The beef was a little tough but the chicken was really tender after cooking.

Service is always responsive and efficient.  Ask for something and you get it right away.  No complaints.  KH isn't much different that the Korean places on Geary but it's a novelty in J-town and, if you're visiting the mall or taking in a movie at the Kabuki, it's really convenient to eat hear especially if you're parked in the lot.  

It can get pretty busy on a weekend evening but if you get there early you shouldn't have any problem  getting a table right away.  Check it out!
author: Martin C.

description: Since our kid was born, our restaurant choices depend on her, haha. Not to say the foods here are only for kids, but the foods and the service are really small kid friendly. We adults like the foods and the service too.
author: Lo Y.

description:
I'm obsessed with Korean BBQ. I'll upload pics of all the food we've eaten.. usually i go with 1 or 2 peeps and we always have 2 days worth of food packed.

Even after I took about 8  (ban chan's) off the table, the table was still completely full!

The yummies:
haemul pajeon (similar to  or green onion pancake!) , gochujang (spicy soup), and Bibimbap and of course tons and tons of daikon kimchi.

And for dessert: Yeot  !! MMMM

There's another korean BBQ place i go to in Oakland: delicious and has an event space upstairs for parties and kareoke!
author: Ying C.

description:
What a yummy lunch I had here recently. i was planning on eating at Bushi-Tei nextdoor, but smelled the barbeque and couldn't resist (note: Korea House has huge double doors and a stairway that you have to enter before actually getting to the dining area.. and somehow, amidst all that and being a passerby on the street, I still managed to smell the barbeque and get lured in). Anyway, I ordered the bulgogi and seafood pancake and both were just as I expected - delicious. The meat was pre-cut, juicy and tender. It was flavorful and didn't require excessive chewing for my sensitive teeth. The pancake was thick and loaded with seafood (unlike some restaurants that skimp out on the seafood). Also, the appetizers were very good! I kept asking for more fish cake and tofu.

Only one downside: slightly overpriced for the portion of meat you get.
author: Jenny T.

description: Overpriced, poor service, and the rice was inedible.  Ignored by staff most of the evening.
author: Joseph S.

description:
Whenever my coworkers at EA ask me what my favorite Korean restaurant is in SF I always say NEW Korea House hands down! I've been coming back here for years and it just gets better each time. New Korea House is exactly what a Korean restaurant in the city should be like - fast service, reasonably priced, cozy atmosphere and the food is just freaking yum. And furthermore, it's just a nice place to go get your grub on and unwind you know what I'm saying? 

I personally really like the Dolsot Bibim Bap. It's sizzlin' hot. And the Kalbi Tang (soup) warms your soul in the winter. Mmmmm, I'm going to bring my coworkers here on another EA outing soon. And we're going to drink lots of Soju and show em how it's done, son. ^ ^
author: Samantha K.

description:
One star is far better rating than I dare give . 
I wish there as a --5 star rating.  
New Years Day I had guests from out of town, we met up in the city, and found this New Korea House to eat at. Everyone was skeptical, but we went ahead with great hope of a great dinner. It took 5-9 minutes to get a person to even acknowledge we were a group of 8 hungry people.  
The dinner came out at a snails crawl pace.  The customer service was well ... "lets ignore the customers and see if they stay" 
The appetizer came out LAST . Some squishy pancake thing. 
They gave the wrong food to the wrong people, who started eating it while the person who ordered it wondered where their food was.  We had no idea due to having no idea what we ordered, had the server asked or even cared it would have been great!, but no not from this place. 
We ordered 4 sake off the bat, and 2 came out mid meal, the last 2 came out with our check. The food was extremely $$$$$ expensive for what it was.  Just basic Korean and not that great.    
The check came to about   $$200.00   pretty normal for am Amazing city dinner, but this was nowhere near amazing. It plain and simple sucked..
If I could save the embarrassment from taking people I care about to an awful restaurant , I would take back time and just walk out when the first 5 minutes of not a single glance from the servers.   
If you dare eat here bring a fat wallet and  be prepared for a sore belly....  so you are not surprised when you feel sick like wall 8 of us did. 

Overall: WORST RESTAURANT IN EVERY WAY!!!!!!!
author: Niki J.

description:
i feel a bit guilty for what i am about to write in regards to this review, but truth be told....this place is the worst restaurant ive been to in a long time.

i could go into detail, but id rather make distasteful reviews as short as possible...

the place was empty except for 1 table with 3 people in it...

i walked in with my friends and sat down at a table...we were brought menus, and thats where things went downhill.

the waiter was rude.  
the service was slow.
the food was mediocre.
the portions were tiny.
the price was extremely high.
the service was slow.
the food was mediocre.
the service was slow.
the waiter was rude.
the portions were tiny.

Korean restaurants are notorious for having rude service to people...even if the food is great, the service will usually suck...THAT IS IF YOURE NON KOREAN...

not at New Korea House...they are just rude and slow even if you are and speak korean...

the waiters were just chillin in the back choppin it up with each other...talkin to each other and havin a blast...i on the other hand had to get up to get stuff...water, napkins, more chopsticks...things of that nature...

as for the food itself...other than the tiny portions that they overcharged us for...their Banchan selection was minimal...and things didnt taste as good as they should've...maybe because i already had a BITTER taste of anger in my mouth for how we were treated there.

never again.  never ever again.
author: Kyu L.

description:
"A-Wop-Bop-A-Loo-Bop-A-Bi-Bim-Bop! "
BBB only review.

2 kinds of Bi Bim Bup here.
Cold and Hot.
Cold is 10 bucks and Hot is 14.

I like both.
The Hot BBB is in a large hot stone bowl is nice.
It comes with raw egg and will cook when you mix because the stone bowl is very hot.

Worry for get Salmonella?
Well, 
BBB without raw egg is like,...... breakfast Sirio without milk.

It kind of engine oil or moisture lotions.
Make things smooth. 

Raw egg makes BBB smooth, 
You gotto have the raw egg.
That is the risk you have to take when it comes to BBB.
You gotto be a macho about it.

The other day, I saw a bumper sticker says, "Go Vege, Stay Green and Save the planet."

Why no one say anything about that to China?
If China does that, then we can start save the planet.
I hope Al Gore knows that.
He is such a hypocrite.
Asia was so green before JFK took over.

I think "Go Vege, Stay Green and Save the planet." is Such a hypocrite comment because we are not all monks and nuns.
So,
I'll say, 
"Go Beef, and Stay KimChee and easy on the planet."
Life is too short.
FXXX It.
I don't care how you look.
