I love you.
I don't judge you by looks but I'll judge you by face lift.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bT236z363NM
author: Nobu K.

description:
Over priced Korean food.  The galbi was ok, but the portions were so small, almost like an appetizer.  

Service was also horrible.  Will never go back unless it's free.
author: Jin C.

description:
So effing GOOD.

As an Asian college student smack dab in Moraga, I am constantly craving *legit* Asian food. There is seriously no kind of good Chinese, Japanese, or Korean food in Moraga. So, we drove all the way to Concord. This food is just top notch Korean food. Love the appetizers, of course. They're so fast and it gets super busy at night. The thing that made my experience above and beyond was the exceptional service! The ladies who work here are ALWAYS smiling. We always get escorted to the door by someone and we get tons of thank you's before we leave. I love Korea House :)

Highly recommended.
author: M J.

description:
Great Korean BBQ in SF JapanTown. The staff was friendly and the atmosphere was pretty cool. I love to cook my meat on the table, just be prepared to smell BBQ for hours after that =)
Will come back for sure!
author: Enrick D.

description:
This has been a staple of my San Francisco experience since I was a very young kid.  While I've definitely had better Korean food, I feel as though what I eat here is definitely above average.  A few of the items (such as the Daeji Bulgogi) are not as spicy or flavorful as I'm used to, but it's still tasty.

A typical meal here involves Japchae and an assortment of cooked on the grill items, such as bulgogi, daeji bulgogi, chicken, and shrimp.  There is also a tripe soup that is excellent.  Service here is fairly good and I can tell that the food is fresh.  I can't really complain.

I did happen to notice that service can sometimes be a little less than attentive, but I understand that they get busy and might be understaffed.
author: Ian M.

description:
5 stars for being accomodating to our party of 30 and NOT kicking us out! At one point, they came over to close off our private room with the accordion partition - like those things will reduce noise! Maybe we were too embarassing for the other patrons to look at... THOSE CLAZY YERPERS!! 

Thanks to Hen A. who acted as our Korean ambassador of Yelp. He ordered us a plentiful amount of Korean beer, soju (and Hen even brought Calipco flavored drinks to mix in - GON-BEH!), a variety of meats for us to grill, and too many side dishes to fit on our tables. 

The spicy tofu (soon du bu ji gae) was brought out to each table in a piping hot clay pot and that was delicious. The chapjae noodles, which is typically complimentary with your meal, was ok - a bit soggier than usual. The meats were just so much fun to grill... food always seems to taste better when you're in charge of cooking it.

BTW, if you should accidentally turn off your flame, try not to relight it yourself - ask them to do it! Although one of our guys took the liberty of lighting it himself with his lighter, we all moved 5 feet away for fear of an explosion... you'd guess that we'd all run OUT of the room! It was all good though, but our flame got really high without us realizing it and I guess our grill got really nasty really quick... didn't know this until Hen came over to point it out! Our table did have a thick cloud of smoke over it...

This is a great place to come with a group of friends... don't know if they'll let our particular group back though! Got a teensy carried away with those soju bombs. And afterwards, you can go next door for some karaoke! Next time ;)
author: Connie C.

description:
Very disappointed!! Came here from out of town with my gf to visit SF and decided this place because I wanted to grill the meat. Ordered two plates of meat as mentioned in order to grill...but the waitress came out with our meat fully cooked. 

Apparently there was a misunderstanding or something, because I wanted to grill. If I knew that I was not able to grill the meat, I would've ordered something a little cheaper from the menu. 

The portion was too small to be $20 a plate, considering I ordered 2 plates and not being able to grill. In my hometown, I can get a buffet of Korean BBQ meat for $20/person. However, being the nice person that I am, I just brushed it off thinking that they were too tired to deal with the grill for me and my gf. 

Lastly, the customer service wasn't that bad, but wasn't great either. The waitress could've been a little more friendlier. I gave it a 2 star because the marinated beef and chicken were delicious. Moral of the story? Make sure to indicate that you want to grill if you're planning to cook your own food.
author: Jolexus X.

description:
When in Japantown, why not have Korean?  The menu is pretty standard.  No matter what you order you get tea, a sweet rice dessert drink and a generous array of banchan.  So generous that I can't remember all the different types so I won't even try to review them.  We only ordered two dishes so it may not be representative, but both had flaws that kept me from rating this any higher than just ok.

Yuk Hwe: I wanted so much to like this dish because I'm a huge fan of French steak tartare.  The presentation took me off guard: udon shaped beef logs instead of finely chopped cubes.  There was still the familiar raw eggs to mix into the already seasoned beef which had tastes of soy and sesame.  Asian pear slices took the place of bread crostinis to offer a crisp, fresh contrast to the raw meat.  Now where it fails: the beef was partially frozen!!!  Tartare is best at room temperature, but for health concerns, I can understand if it's fresh out of the refrigerator.  However, I didn't sign up for beefsicles!  The thinner pieces that had thawed were of decent quality, but chewing into crunchy half-frozen beef in the rest of the dish was so unappetizing!

Dolsot Bibimbap: Crispy rice that is way better than "snap crackle pop"!  The standard vegetables are in the mix.  A bottle of hot sauce is given to the table to spice to taste which seems like a blessing to spice lovers, but is really a curse.  The whiniest mild palated person at the table will inevitably complain and prevent you from spewing half a bottle... in which case you would have been better off to have the kitchen make it normal Korean spicy to burn that complainer!  The beef was not that great, it was too thick and well done.  I prefer when the beef is raw or partially raw so it cooks alone with the rice.
author: Adam B.

description: 20+ people..and they were so accommodating...endless beers...endless soju...such a rowdy group....my request for vegetarian dishes...seafood only dishes...they made sure everybody in my group was happy and well fed....and not once did the staff complain...always a smile on their face...and they just kept on serving...the food...it was good..the fish was good...all was good...korean dining is all about good food...with good service...
author: Hen A.

description:
Korea House is where I get my Korean BBQ fix.

It should be noted that this place does more than just BBQ well, including Bi Bim Bap. It is the only place I know of that does Samgyupsal (Pork bacon cut from the belly, served in the same fashion as galbi) although it is not on the menu and you have to ask for it. 

Kimchi Chigae here is VERY good but skip the pajeon (green onion pancake.)

Banchan here is excellent. I have found service here to be fairly attentive, and have never had the experience of chasing down the servers for anything.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Brief review: solid bimbimbap, good side dishes (but make sure you ask them to replace each one, or else they'll just take 'em away; also the plates are small), but quite expensive (our bimbimbap: $13, and i saw pajeon on the appetizers list for $20!!)

We walked past Korea House and the prices are much lower, and the place is similarly rated, so we'll try there next time.

Bottom line the food was good, but I don't feel like I got what I paid for.
author: Josh K.

description: Came here for dinner while visiting the bay. I have to say the food was tasty! We got a lot of kalbi to grill, and if was marinated perfectly. They even grilled the bone-in portions for us, when we asked. Our appetizers were tasty as well. The only reason why this isn't getting 4 or 5 stars is because $90 including tip wasn't all that worth it. A bit too pricey.
author: Paige K.

description: actually, the service is pretty good, the place is run of the mill, but the meats and the food is pretty good. the side dishes that comes with your order is adventurous at most. I enjoyed myself, and cooked on my table, its a different experience so i definitely recommend it.
author: Virlie B.

description:
Patricia Unterman to the rescue!  My sister was wanting to find a good Korean restaurant and this is the only one mentioned in the Food Lovers Guide.  So we went here for her birthday dinner.

All the food was delicious!  Dinner comes with loads of kim chi dishes.  I would estimate like 10 different ones.  The best are the miniature pancake like things.  You can easily fill up on this alone.  Bearing this in mind, the waitress tried to tell us that the bbq was 1 person portions.  For $20 I thought it was a bit steep.  But don't worry, 1 order of bbq easily feeds 2 people.  Unfortunately for us, we believed the waitress and ordered another dish as well.  So we felt compelled to roll out of there - couldn't exactly not eat the other dish, could we?

The only nitpicky thing about the bbq was that it didn't come with the lettuce and stuff to wrap it in.  The meat did come out with lettuce on the same plate but given it was sharing space with raw meat I looked upon it as decoration rather than food to eat.

The other dish I ordered was the tofu chi gae (sp).  Basically slightly spicy tofu soup with some shrimp and oysters.  This was really really good and welcome departure from the usual bbq and bibimbap.  You take the soup and soup some over the rice (in a separate bowl) and eat it with chopsticks.  You could drink it like regular soup but I've never seen it done that way by any Koreans.

I didn't have any bibimbap but other people at the table did.  Looked good and I liked the sizzling stone tureen you can get it in.

The only bad thing was that even though it was half empty it was still difficult to wave down waitresses for water.

Bike Parking: no designated bike racks.  I locked up to a lamp post in Jtown plaza.
author: Jean K.

description:
I love me some Korean BBQ...

The past few times I've had Korean food in J-town, my friends and I have gone to Korea House (which I guess is "Old Korea House" since this is the "New Korea House").  We decided to mix things up and go to the New Korea House.

I know Korean BBQ joints aren't really about decor, but I actually kind of liked this place - one story, relatively new carpet...didn't look as dingy as a lot of other places.  

But the more important aspect is food, and I thought the food was really tasty.  The little appetizer thingys they bring out in the beginning were all really good - the fishcake, the potatoes, kimchee...yum.  The meats were also delicious, and it was presented in a little "raw meat roll" that we unraveled to cook (unfortunately, we had to cut it ourselves...but the presentation was nice!).  The kim chee chi gae was just okay - not as pungent and flavorful as others I've had.  

While Korean restaurants are typically known for their high-touch service, it was hard for us to get anything - lettuce for our meat, water, rice, etc.  There weren't many patrons at the restaurant so the inattentiveness was puzzling.  And boo - they didn't serve us the cold rice soup-y dessert thing at the end of the meal...even though they brought it to other diners.

I'll still probably go back because of the food, but the service was definitely lacking.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Lunch specials. ($9-$13)

Banchan (side dishes): 
-oh deng (fish cake)
-kimchi (pickled cabbage)
-kong na-mul (bean spouts)
-oh-e kimchi (pickled cucumber)
-kak-tu-gi (pickled radish)
-gam-ja (sweet potato)
-doo-boo chu-rim (seasoned tofu)
-tot'ori-muk (acorn jelly)

+

-malgeunguk (clear broth)

+

Entrees: 
-bul-gak, bul-go-gi, gal-bi (bbq meats)
OR
-bibimbaps (rice bowls)

+ 

-shik-hae (sweet rice drink)

**overall great except small entree portions & bit pricey for lunch.
author: Marti L.

description:
Soggy rice -- 
The best part about dol sot bi bim bap is the crispy rice on the edges of the clay pot. They didn't heat the pot long enough or high enough to make the rice crispy. Very disappointing. The flavor was still good, but you barely get two scoops of rice in the pot. 

Soggy beef --
The bulgogi was weird, almost as though it was steamed cooked instead of grilled or bbqed. The flavor is not strong or tasty, just plain. Don't order the bulgogi. It's not worth it, even though the amount of meat you get is decent.

Soggy service --
First the service is okay, we went mid-afternoon on a Saturday. This happened to be the same day as the Asian Heritage Festival in Japantown. Although, we ended up seating ourselves since it was so quiet and no one came around to seat us. We didn't get water or tea refills. We waited a while get the check since none of the staff were even walking around checking on tables. It wasn't crowded, only about 3-4 other tables of two around.

Location --
This place is upstairs, I didn't see any windows, not sure if there is an elevator, pretty big and you can grill your own, if you want to. Although there is a minimum order to do that.

I highly doubt returning as my two favorite items weren't so good here. There are other places that sound like they are worth checking out, rather than coming back for more soggy food.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
When my friend and I wishes to have Korean BBQ, this is the place if choice. They serve hood marinated meat. There were times in the past they would even include a plate of giant mushroom for cooking when we ordered two meat items. I think know if they've been doing that recently.

I myself also love their corn hen with ginseng soup (sam gae tang). It's a special item I had during my one tour of Korea in 2006 at a restaurant near the presidential palace (and my group was told even the president eats it there). This dush brings back memories of that visit.
author: H K.

description:
One of my (many) rules has to do with Korean food.
I cook Korean food, and unless it's something that I don't know how to cook, or a restaurant can cook it better than I can - I simply do not go "out" for Korean food.  In other words, money will change hands for me to eat mediocre Korean food that I cook better in my own kitchen.

Right next door to New Korea House is a cosmetic store.  My friend and I had to get some stuff there, and given that we had planned lunch between the store and a showing of Karate Kid at Sundance, New Korea House was a convenient location for lunch.

I broke my rule and had lunch here.

I ordered the dolsot bibimbap off the lunch menu, and it was, as expected, mediocre.  My friend ordered the soon tofu (spicy soup) and given that this dish is usually awful almost everywhere else, New Korea House's was acceptable.

The banchan was decent in taste but very few in quantity.  Ding there, as one of the only perks to eating Korean food is having lots of banchan.

Service was friendly to us - but your mileage may vary; the waitress was an older Korean woman who seemed to treat us better than the service she showed others.  She brought out some special seaweed for our table - that happened to be really good.

I've been to Korea House a few doors down for galbi bbq, and I recall it to be pretty good.  I would not be surprised if the meat bbq at New Korea House was equivalent -- but how hard is it to make good meat?

For Korean dishes - I remain without a good place to eat in San Francisco.  Still, the closest good Korean restaurant is in Oakland at Ohgane; for anything better you have to head to San Jose, or ideally, straight to Los Angeles.
author: Grace K.

description:
Mediocre tofu stew near J-town.

Pressed on time, we ended up here because the other korean place wasn't open for another 30 min.

Since it was cold and I was under the weather, I ordered the tofu stew with pork- spicy hot.

:: food ::
The banchan had a nice selection and tasted ok. 

The tofu stew came out but there was no egg accompanying it (doh). It was not piping hot with steam forming like most places. It had this reddish slick on top but was not spicy at all. There was a lot of tofu. The pork was spare and very tough to eat. $11 of unsatisfaction.

:: service ::
Service was a bit on the slow side, considering no one else was in the restaurant but us. It took a while to flag down the server sitting at another table, facing the opposite direction to take our order. Tea and banchan took another long while. Getting our actual food and bill was a lot faster.

I came out stuffed but not satisfied. Plenty of other places to try around there before considering coming back.
author: Christina C.

description:
3-3.5

DISCLAIMER:  I am by no means a Korean food expert.  Not even in the slightest. 

Alright, with that out of the way, I was debating whether to give this place 3-3.5 stars or 3.5-4 stars because there were a few things I really liked, but the most important aspect was just okay.

We received soup with our orders, which was a delicious, extremely flavorful beef broth.  There was also a great variety of side dishes, and I enjoyed all of them.  However, the most important part of the meal, my main entree the clay pot bibambap was just average.  I was expecting crispy rice at the bottom to mix up with the vegetables and meat, but it just never got crispy enough.  The flavor of the overall dish wasn't as flavorful as other clay pot bibambap dishes that I've had.  The best part of the dish was the meat, which was tender.

Service was decent.

I really wanted to give this place a better rating, so I will give it another chance later!
author: Can C.

description:
Love!!!

Food is good for sure, but what I liked the most was the waitress who served my table :-)
She was very friendly and sweet.
Honestly, she was the sweetest Korean lady I've ever met.
Good service makes food taste better.

Thank you!
author: Iya T.

description: A restaurant that had been coming since the 80s and yesterday may perhaps be the last time. Food is good as always and service is consistent. Prices rise, took a big leap from what it previously was. New Korea House is never inexpensive! It was shocking to find at last night dinner their dishes are less than half the portion of what used to be served, while prices took a hike. When economy is bad, shrinking the dish sizes make sense. At same time rising the prices so to make up the loose of customers ??? Guess I just cant afford to come again:( Perhaps this also answer why they aren't busy like before!
author: William Q.

description:
This review is for ginseng chicken soup. 

We used to go to the old Korea House for ginseng chicken soup in cold winter days. So when we found it was no longer there and in New Korea House they also had ginseng chicken soup, we walked in with no doubt. The server told us we had to wait for 20 minutes for this ginseng chicken soup and we were OK for that. 

About 10 minutes, the ginseng chicken soup came. First of all, the portion was for 1 person only. But at the old Korea House, it was a big pot could satisfy both me and my husband. The size of ginsengs at New Korea House was babies compare to the old Korea House ginseng. And the price at New Korea House was more than the old one. As for the taste, I couldn't taste any ginseng flavor from the New Korea House ginseng chicken soup. I could tell they cooked the chicken in a different pot, not with ginseng together. This made me miss the old Korea House. At old Korea House, they gave us more side dishes after we finished any one of the plates. Here at the New Korea House, what was gone was gone. I know it's the way every other restaurants do, I was just spoiled by the old Korea House. Made me miss the old one even more. 

In summary, totally disappointed. Will not come back any more.
author: V L.

description: I've only been once and I really liked it. I'm Korean but not much of a cook, so I appreciated that the food here is authentic. The side dishes were wonderful, the kimchi is perfect. I ordered the kimchi jigae with tofu and a mungbean pancake. It was all very tasty. I'll be back when I'm in the area again.
author: Kim G.

description: I'm a regular here.  You get your standard Korean dishes here.  Decent, not great.  We are no SoCal when it comes to K-food.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Interesting how the "New" Korea House is located directly next to the "Original" Korea House.  It's also interesting cause the "New" Korea House looks older and smaller than the "Original."

I guess the owners are the same?  Not sure, but I tried both establishments within a week's time frame and I saw the same manager/owner both nights.  

The food seemed better at the "original" location (not the new one) but the service was better.  Probably because there weren't very many customers at the "New" location.  The den jang chi gae (spicy bean paste soup) was hella watered down and powdery....  The worst I've ever had!  But the sam gyup sal (pork slices), gal bi (short ribs), and the dae ji bul gogi (spicy pork) was pretty darn good.  

Pretty solid Korean joint...
author: Danny L.

description:
great selection of banchans, but the kimchi and the marinated radishes are the best!  priced at right around $20 per bbq meal, this may be one of the best price vs. quality equations that i've encountered for korean bbq.  note that two meals have to be ordered to be allowed to grill at the table.  spicy pork bulgogi is the best!

overall, great food and a nice, cozy ambiance.

BUT OH MY GOD THE SERVICE IS TERRIBLE.  we were one of three tables in the restaurant with 2 servers, who seemed more interested in eating their own dinners and chatting than giving us our check, bringing soup, etc.
author: Amy S.

description:
I'd give it -5 WORST PLACE IVE EVER BEEN. just recent
Went to this place cause we wanted to try it, 10 PIECES OF SHRIMP for $22? Are you kidding me? NO SERVICE! They need more waitresses,.  The tofu soup tastes disgusting, NOT much Seafood in it and it was suppose to be a tofu seafood soup, compare to tofu house this place is trash! Why? : 1) expensive/ ripoff 2) bad service 3) bad food.
author: Food L.

description: This place is OK.  It's not great, but I'm biased because I grew up on home cooked korean food and food from LA Koreatown.  It's also well known that you can't find good traditional korean food in the city of San Francisco.  But i come here a lot because it's acceptable and it's close to the movie theater.  The ban-chan could be a little better options and i can't believe an order of gal-bi is $29.  That's ridiculous.  But i hear it's about that much everywhere else too.  Some dishes here are hit or miss but nothing is bad and service is OK.
author: Easter E.

description:
I love love LOVE Korean food, and I'm amazed there aren't any places to go near my hood (Du-Tri)...I mean, isn't Korean supposed to be the "next big thing"?  Peruvian was last years "next big thing" and plenty Peruvian joints have popped up around me.

Anyway, I had a great experience here.  I had bulgogi (cooked in the kitchen), which was tender, sweet and plentiful (**Tip:  splash a little vinegar on the beef - um yum nom nom**), and the kim chee stew, which could have been spicier but was nevertheless delicious.  The sides...the *banchan*...were plentiful and tasty.  I pretty much scarfed everything too fast because it was so mouth-watering.

About the service:  I read a few complaints from others about this place, but I had a particularly lovely lady  - smiling, courteous and prompt.  

No complaints.  I'll be back.
author: jeff n.

description:
New Korea House has excellent banchan.  We particularly love the sweet and spicy crunchy cucumbers, fish cakes, and fried potato triangles. Today, we were given a huge pot of hot tea and free soup with refill.  I really enjoyed their melon soup. The meat is always fresh and tasty here. If you order two orders of the meat, you can grill it yourself which is nice in cold weather like this. However, with one order,  they grill it for you. We love the Kalbi which is the short rib.  One order satisfies the both of us.  

A warning is that in the banchan, you get white jello-looking things and these clean out your system.  I ate two today and spent the evening in the bathroom. So be careful or skip them altogether like my husband did and he has been fine.  Good luck.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
Note to self: bring more people next time. 
There's a minimum order of 2 dishes for the grill ... and if you're two Asians on the skinnier side of life, you may just have a heart attack, each, after downing about 5 lbs. of the most delicious sesame oil+chili paste meat you've seen in your now-much-shorter-life.

All the side fixings are good.
The rice is sweet and succulent, never sticky.
Healthy pours of the house wine for $4 a glass (you get about 8 oz.).
And make sure you check out the pufferfish with the googly eyes, and photos of the family deep-sea fishing trip. Holy Cow, is all I'll say. That's some big ass Pompano!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Just relocated from Honolulu, HI to the Bay Area.  Since we were all craving for a good Korean BBQ, we decided to try out the Japan Center and we found a New Korean House in Japan Town.

What a big surprise!!!  It was not a good sign that we were the only customers on Sunday afternoon around 5:00pm.  We'd thought we are too early.

There were two Waitress's standing around in the kitchen area. They acted like we were just too much for them and we might be even bothering them.

It was very small portions for what is worth on the menu... banchan wasn't anything to brag about.  Very so so....

The Kal-bi meat was tough... we were lucky that also ordered chicken instead.
We will never go back to this restaurant again. 

Where is a good Korean food and a friendly service in SF???
author: Kim L.

description:
My last visit here prompted me to update my last review.

It was a Friday night and me, the bf, and three others were out to get our din din on. One of the had mentioned they wanted Korean food so the first place that came to mind is Korea House for me. 

2 out of the 5 of us never been here so I egged it on that it was more of an incentive to check it out... since it was like.. my FAVORITE Korean restaurant. 

Came here a little early for dinner (but who cares, we were huuuuungry) and the place had only one family eating. 

The 5 of us ordered Dinner 1 which was a set meal and added an order of Kalbi and one large OB. 

The food was delish as always and the service deserved 5 stars on their own. 

We feasted like royalties that night and all left with good feelings in our tummy. 

Oh! And because I checked into YELP, they had a 25% discount on dinner. So that was an extra bonus!
author: Emily Z.

description:
My co-workers and I have added this to our regular lunch rotation, it is so wonderful!  The Bulgogi here is flavorful and sizzling hot. The small plates of appetizers and pickles that come out before the meal are always an adventure and ever-changing. The soups are also always quite delicious.

Fresh, warm food that's perfect for a rainy San Francisco day.

It is a little pricey  and watch your knees if you are sliding into one of their booths for the first time!
author: Heather S.

description:
The reason that someone said "you smell the least" after eating here as opposed to other Korean BBQ is that they use gas not charcoal so the meat doesn't taste half as good either. I'd rather smell a little and have wonderful food.

Also some of the dishes are way overpriced. We ended up paying something like $18 for a few mushrooms to put on the grill and they were so spongy and unmushroomy we wondered if they had given us eggplant by mistake.

Service was also horrible - We had to ask for water 4 or 5 times before they finally brought it.

UPDATE:
Have been there many more times and service is better and my wife says "the unagi dolsot bimbimbap is something I'd jump up and down for." She has ordered it 6+ times - the eel is delicious, the ratio of vegetables to rice is wonderful, the stoneware bowl is always hot - it is just delightful.
author: Marco M.

description:
I just went in tonight with a new friend and we're both Korean and new to the city so we thought we'd try this place since we found it on Yelp. But to my dismay, it was mediocre at best. The food was at least.
We order fried mandoo ($12) and for 8 pieces, I guess that's pretty fair but the filling reminded me of the kind of you get from the gookjee market in the frozen aisle. The entrees also came out before the appetizer-who does that in a restaurant? 
Our dolsoht beebeem bop was the highlight of my dinner there because it was piled high with vegetables and white rice of the stickiest variety. The place is a little pricey for what I'm used to in Chicago but the decor is nice and they do try to accommodate and not rush you. Service is good and the little touches with nicely arranged banchan might make me give this place a second chance if I'm in the neighborhood again.
author: Jessica K.

description:
1 Kalbi expensive and skimpy portions
2 Bulgogi very thick tough and not overall tasty
3 Terrible customer service -- refused to make a common dish because it was after 8pm.  Claimed it was because it would take the chef a long time and they'd have to turn a machine on.    There were three parties total in the restaurant at the time.  Also we sat down at 8:02pm.
author: Adam A.

description:
So it probably isn't useful to have a vegetarian review a Korean BBQ place, but I'll give it a shot anyway. I liked that you could grill the meats to your own specification and dress/marinade it the way you like it - the do-it-yourself, quasi-Benihana vibe worked well for the large group I went with.

I got the veggie bibimbap, which didn't quite hit the spot, owing to the fact that the chilli/spicy sauce they provided seemed off in some way - couldn't quite put my finger on it.

Warning - it's definitely on the high end of moderate - more than $20/person.
author: Kavita B.

description:
We came here with one of the girlfriend's uncles. He is kind of well known around Japantown, so the lady that owns it immediately came over to talk to him. She was very nice. We started off with a bunch of pickled veggies including kimchi, which was very good.

There really is a difference from the kalbi ribs served in Hawaii and ones on the mainland. In Hawaii, the cuts are thinner and use a vertical cut with several of the rib eyes included in the cut. These ones were big and fat, more of a horizontal cut with a lot of meat and part of one rib included. Both are good to me. Combine the juicy meat with the kimchi and it was pretty savory.

One of the surprises for me was a sweet rice based dessert. It was quite different than most other rice based deserts I have had. The soup part was really sweet and clear, but the rice part was a bit bland. For some reason, it was really good to me. It was a good mix of fluid and texture.
author: Brian A.

description: Come across this restaurant after my appointment in Japan town.  Make long story short the food here was okay my chicken taste dry seems like it might have cooked for a while;  when i ask for more small plate they said this will be your last refill which was also my first refill :(  won't be coming back!
author: Charlie H.

description:
I'm not an expert at Korean BBQ but holly Jesus this place was delicious. This was my first time at a Korean BBQ and I have to say that I am a fan. The BBQ pork was so good and the chicken was just as tasty. 

It was kind of fun to BBQ (actully someone else at our table did it) your own meat but I think after a while the novelty would wear off. Also, I think I could have done without all the little extra dishes that we ordered. It was fun to try but took up too much room. Probably would have been happier with more fantastic BBQ pork.
author: Jeff P.

description:
After wandering around Japantown looking for a second place to eat dinner after a disappointing first place to eat dinner, I decided to play it safe and come here.  I had been here once before and it was an enjoyable meal.  I considered going to Korea House practically next door, but it looked too fancy smancy.  Its ironic that New Korea House looks older than the Korea House... but I digress.

We ordered the marinated kalbi, the bulgogi, the tofu soup with fish eggs (forgot the name), and of course soju... what's Korean food without soju?  You have the option to grill at the table or have them cook it in the back.  Grilling your own food, while novel in concept, well really sucks.  You smell like bbq and you need to tend to your food instead of drinking and chatting with your buddy.

Anyway.  The food is solid, probably the kalbi was my favorite.  The banchan was decent.  Surely not the best Korean food in the world, but consistently good.  I would not be ashamed to bring friends, family, and out-of-town guests here.  Besides, soju makes everything better.
author: Bryan K.

description:
Wow, what a let down, big time. We live in the immediate neighborhood and were looking for some fun, good food. We have been trying to check this place out for a while, we dropped in and got a table right away. 

There was only one server taking orders for the entire restaurant. There was a follow up person so who was there to clear dishes. The follow up person did not speak English so trying to get any service during our meal is IMPOSSIBLE. We literally had no service. 

The prices seemed high for what was there and there are very few options on the menu. I would not order the chicken. It was terrible. All tendon and bones, literally no meat. The onion cake was soggy, oily and flavorless. The red meat seems to be what they are good at, if you bother to go, order that. 

It's also super smoky and no ambiance. 

Another issue with me is the lack of options for wine. There were very few options and the house white was a cheap acidic wine. I had to send it back. 

The net-net is that it was a huge disappointment and I would not go back.
author: Amanda J.

description:
Just okay.

Let me preface this by saying: I love Korean food. I ate it roughly weekly in London with a Korean coworker for several years and have mauled my way through K-Town in NYC.

The food here was mostly so-so. The bulgogi was particularly unimpressive, and served without lettuce and soybean paste.

Service was nonexistent. Our order was taken, food was delivered, and we never saw them again.

It's unlikely that I'll return. Wouldn't recommend it. Would be a shame to introduce someone to Korean food here btw.
author: jon c.

description: Just okay. Average. Had the silken tofu stew and the beef bimimbap.  Not happy about any restaurants in the japantown area so far.  Hoping next time but may just walk a few blocks out of tourist area
author: Foodlover B.

description: Delicious Korean bbq. We came here as a group of 10 on a Saturday afternoon around 1:30PM so it wasn't super crowded. Portions were quite reasonable, and we were all served within the same amount of time. I would come again.
author: Shang S.

description:
In summary...
Thumbs up for soups and small side dishes
Hands wavering for barbeque and broiled rock cod.
Thumbs down for bibimbap and oyster pancake.

This joint probably has the most selections on soups, and the ginseng chicken soup was soothing for this type of weather.
Kalbi was decent, well-seasoned.
Dolsot bibimbap was disappointing because it wasn't cooked in the stone pot. It didn't have the rice crispy, and rice was too moist.
Oyster pancake was soggy and mushy.

This place has some good stuff and I think a 3-star is probably a relevant rating.
author: Edmund L.

description:
Korea house, New Korea house, whichever whatever - they both suck!  Can't stand this place.  Went a few times and everytime thought the food sucked.  The service is horrible too!

The pajun - soggy and mushy.  Should be crispy on the outside.
Banchan - tastes like it's been sitting out awhile and they don't serve the good stuff.

Dolsut Bibambap - I had ordered this and got the cold bibambap.  Sent it back saying it's not what I ordered..I wanted the dolsot bibambap in the hot stone pot.  They basically went in back and dumped the cold bibambap into a stone pot.  The inside rice was cold, the same veggies, and there was no noorunjee (bottom crispy rice that's fried to the stone pot because of the heat).  

The waiters/waitresses never check on you and you have to flag them down even when you come during a dead lunch hr and you're the only ones there.  Hate this place!!!!
author: C A.

description:
I sat at my table waiting for my friends watching the next table over. There was a guy that looked about 70 sitting next to an Asian woman that was maybe 30, I make no judgment, and across from them was an older couple that looked very suburban.

This is one of those places where you can cook at your own table or they'll cook for you in the back, why you'd go to a restaurant to cook your own food I can never figure out. Sugar daddy, I guess I am making judgments, was doing all the cooking for the whole table. He used his chopsticks to put the meat on the grill, turn the meat over, serve the meat to the rest of the table, and eating with them. In his mouth the chopsticks would go and then out to take meat off the grill to put on someones plate. The whole thing was disgusting!

I had the Dolsot Bibimbap. It was good but I've had better.
author: Manny F.

description: The staff here is very kind and attentive. We were able to get seated at 6PM on a Saturday with no problems. We ordered bulgogi, job chae, pork belly (forgot the Korean name), and kalbi. All the BBQ were good cuts of meat but not particularly flavorful. The side dishes were plentiful and tasty and the job chae earned an A+ in my book. My only complaint is that the water glasses are so tiny. I had to act much braver than I was with the kimchi since I had no cold beverage to wash it down.
author: Lau B.

description:
3 Stars Overall, no big WOW factor when I ate here. 

Food:  3 stars
I tasted better Korean food elsewhere.  It was just bland, but the kimchi and other extras made it okay I guess. The price that we paid was a little high for our two dishes, the beef and the chicken that we cooked at our table, but then again it is Korean and it's usually expensive anyways. 

Ambiance: 3 stars
The place didn't appear to be welcoming, maybe because it was really slow during the time I went, but the decor needs some updating.  The place appeared to be well kept and clean. 

Service: 3 Stars
Took our order, brought us our drinks, then our food. Just A-OK service, nothing really spectacular.
author: Crysthel C.

description:
If you are looking for amazing Korean food, you're not going to find it here. Sadly, you're not going to find it in San Francisco. You're going to need to take the trek to the south bay and even they don't totally compare to LA or even NYC.

That said, I'm a fan of New Korea House. It's clean, it's reasonably priced, the service is great, easy cheap parking, and the food is good enough for me and my Korean family when we are in San Francisco and want a decent meal.
author: Marie K.

description:
I always have associated Korean BBQ in San Francisco with Brother's. Grill your own meat, the side dishes, etc. Best in the city ... until I discovered this place. I was pleasantly surprised by how the food turned out. Very delicious!

They have a similar set up -- the grill honestly is a little better than Brother's. I think the vent system there is a bit better too since I didn't smell like Korean BBQ afterwards for the rest of the day. Also the ambiance is less Chinatown-ish and more elegant. Rockin the 80s music :)
author: A C.

description: I went back to New Korea House recently and was not disappointed.  My wife and I had Kalbi and Yuk Hae Jang.  The Kalbi was tender, juicy and very flavorful while the Yuk Hae Jang hit the spot (well seasoned and super spicy).  You get a great assortment of side dishes and the service is great!
author: Henry C.

description:
Ok, I've been here only a few times.  I'd been going to the other Korea House upstairs these past few years but since they're now closed, I ate here a few days ago.  

The food was bad bad, bad.  My friend and I  wanted to eat Naeng Myun since it was a very hot day.  Naeng Myun is all about the broth and the toppings.  And in this weather, they shoulda been expecting customers to come in for some!  

It had no flavor. I kept putting more and more vinegar and mustard in the soup until I realized I'd put almost half the bottle that was on the table.  Um. not a good sign when a customer is adding their own seasonings!   I couldn't believe they served that and I don't believe their staff would ever eat that,  honestly. 

Then, when I got home, I got sick all night from the food.  So bad experience all around.

The servers were nice but I can't say very much else about this place.   I never see any more than 2 or 3 table full whenever I pass by this place and I see why.  The food is disgusting and sub par, like they didn't make it with care.  I don't see this place lasting for much longer if they couldn't make their upstairs place last.
author: I love t.

description:
Place was ok.
Ban Chan had a variety of choices, different then most places which was refreshing.  Was it better, I'll leave that up to you to decide. 

As for the food, 
We ordered the bibimbap, pretty solid.  

Korean BBQ orders- The basics
Spicy Pork- Stuck to the grill and melted to nothing
Bul Go Gi- Very different, it was sliced, looked almost like large oval shaped pepperoni.  And not marinated.
Kal Be- Good but super chewy and fatty
Overall-they don't give you that much meat.  

Service-  Was so so.  We had to ask 3 times for more ban chan.  I asked 2 times for water, never came.  
To top it off, since our pork was sticking and melting to the grill, we asked if they could cook it in the back, the guy looked at me like I was crazy and had to ask the boss, then the chef.  Finally they did. 

Decor- Nice and clean.  The grill area was great.  You don't get much smoke stuck to you for days like most places.

Price-  4 People, $120.00

Good place for tourists
author: Chase F.

description: This place was aight. Came here to have the kbbq with bulgogi and pork belly. The bulgogi was a bit on the bland side and that was disappointing and the pork belly was okay. The meat didn't taste that fresh and when the bulgogi was given to us it was still frozen. It costs $7 for a plate of lettuce. On the menu it said bbq items come with soup , but the server said they ran out of soup . If it doesn't come with soup then why do you say it does on the menu , so I ordered a vegetable tofu soup which they didn't run out of. Aren't most of the soup base they use the same? The banchan or side dishes were okay , their kimchee had a very heavy ginger taste to it. The only thing I liked about this place was that their ventilation system was good , so by the time I left I wasn't smelling like bbq. Honestly, though the food wasn't that great here and I don't think this place is worth trying again.
author: Lucy C.

description:
3.5 stars.

Almost never a wait (hmm good or bad sign?).

Pretty tasty kalbi - but kinda pricey at $22 for a decent sized portion for one grown man.

A good selection of side dishes (forget what they are called) - but some of them were too vinegary for me (cucumber, radish).

Kim chee chigai was decent - with chunks of beef, tofu and cabbage. I'd get it again but again, kinda pricey ($12) for what it is. I think prices are lower at Tofu House on Geary.

Overall, a good place to grab korean before a movie at Kabuki (or a massage in my case, tonite), but not somewhere that I'd venture to if simply craving korean. The spots on Geary and in the Richmond are better overall. Also, the environment, while clean, courteous and more than the average hole in the wall/no decor bbq spot, feels empty and more of a spot for families, someone trying out korean for the first time, etc...

Lastly, I actually do not advise eating korean before a massage - as I did tonight. I spent 1/2 the massage worrying that I might let out a kim chee smelling fart.
author: Deann M.

description:
Food: Not the best quality meat. The saeng gal bi was really dry and the bibim bap was just mediocre. I hate to say it but I think the haemul pajon was better at Playground. There also wasn't any rice paper :(

Maybe I'm too use to SoCal's korean bbq restaurants but this place was a bit of a disappointment. At least the service was good and there isn't ever a wait since Korea House is just next door.
author: Annie B.

description:
Came here after 2.5 hours of cleaning the JCCNC and part of Buchanan Mall. Me, my daughter and boyfriend were famished after, so bbq was on our minds. 

We walked upstairs to Korea House and found an empty restaurant with one couple eating. Two sets of patrons came in after, but it was still early, per say. 

We simply ordered, two beers and a coke with our order of Bul Go Gi and Kal Bi. Out of course came the bowls of vegetables and soon thereafter our two steaming plates of meat with individual rice bowls. I am so happy we had the meat cooked for us, because I know me and my boyfriend would not have made it taste as good as it did. 

Everything was nummy until I got the bill for $64!! It was worth the eat, but not something I would venture to do in the future when I know I have limited funds.
author: Jamie L.

description:
I've been to soooo many Korean places that I've lost count. And most of them are pretty good...like 4 stars good. But that's the problem. They're all kind of the same. 

This place gets 4 too, but maybe just a smidgen of the fifth star for an outstanding dolsot bibimbap. Now if you're really into bbb, then you'll appreciate that their version isn't as dry as most of the other ones I've had. In fact, if you drizzle that tasty sauce out of the squirt bottle (which had just a little kick), then you've got a bowl of hot yummy goodness that hits the spot on a chilly San Francisco evening in December. 

And if you could care less about the bbb, I can tell you their meats, chap chae (sp?), seafood pancakes, cold noodles and the little dishes were all good. 

So there you have it: good food, reasonable prices, service with a smile, and PARKING (J-Town lot across the street). Oh! And they're great for groups. It's a spacious dining room for a SF restaurant and they have no problem accommodating large parties.
author: Virg Y.

description:
Probably my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. 

Their Soondubu Chigae (tofu soup) is so so good, just the perfect amount of spiciness, and a very flavorful broth. Not watered down like some places. One of the best I've had.

Dolsot Bibimbap (mixed vegetables, rice, and meat/seafood in a hot stone pot) was also very delicious. Nothing like a hot sizzling bowl of rice, fresh veggies, thin slices of beef, and an over easy egg to top it off!. The best part is the crunchy rice at the bottom of the bowl..yum :) The meat in it was just ok though.

Banchan (side dishes) were fresh and super tasty here, and their kimchee was above average. My only complaint was the sider order of I mung bean pancake which was super oily and didn't have much veggies inside.
author: amy k.

description:
Chant with me...BUL GO GI, BUL GO GI!  This place has some pretty damn good Korean BBQ.  The tender beef and sweet marinade has my stomach craving for more.  I always go out here with family and friends during special occasions.  Why?  Because the food is great!  Great choices in Kim Chi, pickled cabbage/vegetables/etc.  The rice tea helps settle that full stomach after a big meal.  The service is friendly.  It's always a great place for a large groups and the Korean Beer is the best.  Ok, I may be a little bias because I'm korean but honestly the BBQ Bul Go Gi or Kal Bi is really good.  

For newcomers,  just a heads up.  You can either choose to have the restaurant cook the meat for you or you can cook it yourself.  However, there's something about cooking it yourself over the grill, but BEWARE...YOU WILL SMELL LIKE BEEF afterwards.  So, wear some clothes that need to be laundered.
author: James M.

description:
Meal: Dinner
Date: Sunday, March 1, 2009

I'd only had Korean food a handful of times before eating at Korea House. I almost ordered the Jap Chae but a mediocre experience with the same dish at a lesser restaurant and the fact that it didn't seem to be a featured item on the menu convinced me to try something else. In this case something else was a bibimbap dish with eel.

There are several bibimbap dishes on the menu. They all come with side dishes of pickled vegetables and so forth. I was stunned by the number of side dishes they brought me, there must have been about a dozen of them. Some I ate separately, some I mixed in with the bibimbap . It was a real challenge and I ate as much as I could but in the end I had to stop before the food was all gone. It was just a little too much for me, even though it was all delicious. I wasn't crazy for all the side dishes but I do like crunchy pickled veggies and there were more than a few of those.

Great meal, good service, good price: $21.99 including tax and tip. I don't feel as thought I know enough about Korean food to give it a proper assessment but I'm a fan.
author: Dave L.

description:
I've been trying to look for other places besides Brothers to go to for Korean BBQ and I figured that the reviews and photos on yelp weren't too bad for this place. Besides, all me and my friend were looking for was Hite and somewhere to grill all the meat we were going to eat! 

This place was pretty quiet... but then again, we walked in around 5pm and we were the only ones who were there. It was like our own private restaurant! The waiters were very nice and gave us some time to see what we wanted (it's not like the place was hustle and bustle, so there wasn't really a rush). I have to say I'm not really a fan of the side dishes that they brought out, BUT I did love that they brought out a bigger side dish bowl of the bean sprouts, which is my favorite side dish. But compared to other Korean spots I've been to, they give you a smaller choice. 

Also for the price of the Bul Go Gi and the Sam Gyup Sal, I would have thought they would have given us more (more so the Bul Go Gi). The Bul Go Gi was marinated, but the Sam Gyup Sal was not. Their menu seemed quite extensive, and other than that I think the prices for this place weren't great, but still good. The food was also delicious!

The service was nice and courteous, and it was even more awesome when they brought out a complimentary order of Busut Gui (which I have to say was really, really good). I would definitely go here again.
author: Caroline L.

description:
One of my favourite things about getting Korean food is all the mini appetisers that arrive complimentary to your order. Kimchee, pickled daikon radish, cucumber, marinated potato, beansprouts... all fabulous apart from the rice jelly thingy... I could live with never seeing that again. 

I've come to the Korea House on quite a few occasions and always enjoyed my meal. The servers are always nice and friendly, and the place so far has never been too busy to prevent us being promptly seated. Good for me, but a shame for the restaurant. 

The pajon pancakes on my latest visit were a little soggy, but were a success with my friends. Dolsot bibimbap is always a tasty combination of sizzling rice, beef and vegetables - and as much chilli sauce as you want to throw at it. Saying that, I have had better bibimbap on other nights, or I would have given this meal the full 5, but I think the chef was a bit bored by the time we arrived (around 9:30). We also had the prime rib and mushrooms to grill. I have to find out what these mushrooms are as they are no ordinary button mushrooms, but possibly formed from some kind of giant sentient mushroom Prometheus that has various parts of his anatomy sliced off on a daily basis. That should make me sad, but it is so tasty... I overlook the suffering. 

Overall, I really enjoy my visits to Korea House... and I am always hard pushed to try another venue. I know what I like, and I like da House.
author: Catriona C.

description:
Eating a nice dinner at Korea House with my Korean mother.

MOM:  (Random thought)  You were a mistake, you know.  We didn't want you.  Dad didn't want children.

ME:  (Choking on kim chee)  WHU...?  What the fu...??!  What do you mean "I was a mistake"...huh?  Huh?  

MOM:  We didn't want you.  We already had Jason.  We didn't need another one.

ME:  ANOTHER one?  What?  WHAT?  

MOM:  Think about it.  Eleven year age difference.  Who would wait a decade to have YOU?

ME:  IS THAT A RHETORICAL QUESTION??

MOM:  Oh, calm down.  We love you...now that we had to have you.  

ME:  WAS THAT A PAUSE?  DID YOU JUST PAUSE?

MOM:  Jason was planned.  We wanted a boy.

ME:  JASON IS A LOSER!  YOU DUMPED JASON IN KOREA FOR THREE YEARS AND MOVED AWAY, REMEMBER?

MOM:  We wanted to plan  better life for him here in America.

ME:  (Lower lip quivering)  And ME?  What about a better life for ME?

MOM:  You so spoiled.  (Sigh)  

ME:  What...so basically, you popped a nickel into the candy machine and the wrong color gumball came out...ME!  

(Stuffing face with chap chae and rice in my sorrow)  I'm, like, the yucky green, lime-flavored gumball nobody wanted.  You chewed on me, sucked out all the flavor and then spit me out!  (sniff, tear...)

MOM:  Oh, don't be so dramatic.  It's not like we thought about giving you away that much.

ME:  I hate this family.  I hope my real parents come to find me soon.  PLEASE GOD, give me a sign.

(A Yoo Hoo falls from the heavens.)  

ME:  Thank you, Lord.



(One star off for being a bit pricey...and for being the place where I was scarred for life.)
author: Kristina R.

description:
Update 9/2:

Last night they accommodated 27 of us hungry yelpers. The reservations were for 15. They fit us in. They struggled a little, but kept their cool. Most of all, they kept the food and drinks coming. I also found out they will cook your food for you too, which we opted to do. That worked out very well, as I didn't want to smell like BBQ and have drunk people cooking. 

One extra star to make 5!

---original review below------

Very nice upscale Korean foodies. We went on a Sunday night and ordered way too much food. Having just finished being BBQ-master I wasn't really in the mood to cook my own food. But duty called, as I was the only one on our 'kids table which were were relegated, otherwise known as the Japo table" who could cook. 

Note to self: Go to these establishments with people who cook regularly. Otherwise food safety is out the window. 

The Korean bacon was different but pretty good. The Kal Bi was very good. (They even cooked the bone part in the kitchen for us.) And the soup? Uh, no thanks. Our table, our peeeps, we like to fill up on rice not soup. Thank you very much. 

So what if they looked at us funny when we all asked for another chawan of rice. So what if they looked at us funny because we left enough kim chee on the table to feed the entire North Korean Army....for a month.

Aigooo Machisoooo!!! My Korean ex-gf would be proud.
author: Kevo M.

description:
Korea House has a private room for special events, and the food is awesome!  I attended a 1st year old birthday party and was blown away by the menu.  The service was really helpful too.  

Buffet style:
Kal bi skewers
Chicken skewers  
Fried Chicken - Korean style
Kim chee - both water and regular.
Assorted egg battered meats "jun".
Burdock & Lotus root.
Vegetables and more...

I ate one of everything and it was enough for 2-3 people.
author: HY L.

description:
I have never ate a nice Korean BBQ until now, Guri made an amazing night. He somehow got 25 plus people to come here and ate some of the best Korean food I have eaten in a long time. Everything was perfect. The company was beyond five stars. The food was good but very over priced. Everyone was drinking OB beer and soju, it was a night just like any night with these yelp friends of mine, total annihilation, total drunkenness. 

Yours truly was sober!
author: Stanley K.

description:
What do you do after you've been packing and moving furniture and boxes all day? You treat yourself to some good Korean bbq, that's what!

After hours and hours of moving, me, Eugy and donut Hen A. come here and do some serious eating. 

2 orders of unmarinated kalbi
2 orders of marinated kalbi
2 orders of samgyupsal
1 order of marinated busot gui 
1 kimchi jjigae
4 really big asahi
1 cham ee sul

and towards the end...

another order of marinated kalbi...

The waiter actually asked us if we were sure we wanted that much food. Um, yeah, actually we do. 

The marinated kalbi was definitely my favorite. And the kimchi jjigae was so good. Went perfectly with the kalbi. Wash it all down with some ice cold beers. You got yourself a perfect dinner.
author: Jen D.

description:
CONNIE AND HEN ARE THE BEST!

So I would give this place 3 stars because the food was about 4 stars:  tasty, straight-up korean fare.  Good marinades for the meats, and they had beef tongue for me :).  But the service was really slow, and the tiny little kimchee dishes were inadequate for parties our size.  The kal bi had the full bone, but also was not the thin spiral cut I'm used to at Brothers.  They were chunky so took a lot longer to cook.  Good thing I like my beef rare!  :)

Ahhhhh OB and Soju.  What korean meal would be complete without that stuff?  Big props to Hen for bringing the Calpis for the soju ;)  Though I personally think yakult tastes better ;)  I can't remember the name of the soju brand we had, but it was way better than most of the soju/turpentine I've had before.  

But then I add one star because of how large and loud our LARGE group of yelpers were, just because they put up with us.  And I knew although the service was slow, they were trying their best to accommodate us, esp the manager.  They just need more wait staff!
author: Fong L.

description:
Thanks to Connie for setting up another great event!!  There were maybe 25 of us, and boy did we get loud.  Sogu bombs.  I was thinking we were gonna get kicked out of there.  I told Connie that this is the last time they will let Yelp in ... no holiday parties.

The food is standard bbq, and each table got platters of chicken, beef, and pork maybe?  You grill it yourself ... but be careful not to turn it off.  SOMEONE did at our table, and we were wondering why the food was not cooking.  Maybe the grill is cold because it's .... HAUNTED???   No, it was not haunted, but it was turned off in an attempt to turn it up.  (Sorry!  but I forgot your name.  I will not remember your name, but will know your face if we cross paths again!)  

Also with the meal ... I have to give a big thanks to Hen for ordering for us.  You get lots of picked veggies like red kimchee, which could have been spicier, cucumbers, jicama, and lots of other side dishes served family style.  There was some spicy tofu soup that was pretty good too, and comes to the table in a contraption that keeps the soup boiling hot.  Also on the menu was a "pad Thai", ala Korean style.  That was really good.

BTW ... what was the name of that noodle dish??  I want to order it again, but my deaf ears could not pick up exactly what it was.

OH ... the sogu!  Great stuff!  How is it flavored??  I think Hen was in charge of this too.  People said I had a lot of sogu, but I didn't feel anything.  

It's a great place to go in Japantown, but be sure to wear something that you won't mind smelling like BBQ.  It does seem a bit pricey, at it came to $33 per person, but I did not get to see a regular menu.
author: Michael M.

description:
We were looking around for a Korean restaurant where you can d.i.y. on the table with a grill, and couldn't find too many around. Most of the Korean restaurants that we know of does not let you cook your own meat on your table (there's nothing wrong with that, but we were looking for some interaction with our guest that evening). 

So my better half took me to this one that he's been to many moons ago. It was quite empty for a weekend, and our server was very quiet and didn't say much to us. We ordered and was basically left on our own for the most of the evening.

The seafood pancake (don't remember the name) was good and came in a very large portion. 3 of us couldn't finish it!  All the bbq meats were also good, and I enjoyed it the best. We can cook as we eat and took our own time.

We also ordered a blue crab soup thing (don't know the name) and it was the spiciest soup I have ever had in my entire life!!!! Wwhooooo!!! All our mouths were on fire!!! It was ridiculously spicy, I couldn't handle it. And I love spicy food!

All in all, it's a fun place to cook your own bbq on the table if you don't mind the smell on your clothes afterward. It's nice for a cold evening and you can go straight home to shower afterward, and the food is pretty good too. I shall avoid the spicy crab soup next time, but I encourage the brave to try it.
author: Florence W.

description:
Why are there no mentions of the prices below?? $15 for bi bim bap??

Ok, so at least the bi bim bap was good. So was the $15 meat pancake. And the decor/service was lovely.

But seriouly - $30 for bi bim bap and a pancake?? No no.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
While walking past this restuarant to our car we got a good whiff of bbq beef...wow taht sure smells good. Lets try it out sometime~

So on friday, my lady and I decided to check it out. Now Im probably a dummy when it comes to eating korean food, despite the fact taht I've been to a good amount of them. I look ridiculous when I try to mix a bi bim bop and I look like a idiot when i'm doing bbq...

BUT TAHT DOESNT MATTER...i think?

the point is, if you dont know how to cut your meat, the servers will assist you with that, any questions they will try their best to explain to you. Overall as a bbq place it was pretty good and my lady n I enjoyed ourselves. 

Dont wear nothing fancy if you do bbq..you will end up smelling like food and I dont know if that is something you want to smell like if you have plans after dinner. Oh yea, I didnt like the seafood pancake taht much but it wasnt bad~
author: phillip w.

description:
Family style food - great place if you are with a large group of folks and hungry! They do a good job with the scallion pancake and dolsot bi bim bap. I also liked their silken tofu stew. Smooth soju and good barley tea. They serve generous portions of the complimentary appetizers (bean sprouts and kim chee are my favorite parts of a korean meal). 
Expect to smell of korean food when you step out (but then again, that's true with most ethnic restaurants). Prices are higher than I'd expect though for standard entrees like bi bim bap, but the service and food make up for it.
author: Shweta V.

description:
Wait, a Korean restaurant without rude servers? Have I been transported to some alternate dimension??

No, I'm having dinner at Korea House!  This is the 'upscale' spot to go to when you're craving BBQ, but not craving the attitude or the stink.  Okay, so I still left reeking of BBQ, but my overall experience was top notch.

We had the Bul Go Gi and Kal Bi - I have to say that I really liked the Bul Go Gi - they took the time to even BBQ it for us at our table (I think it wasn't so much to cook for us as it was to talk to my BF's Korean aunt).

Everything was delicious and the service was excellent.  It's a lot pricier than say Brother's, but I think it's worth it!
author: Christy L.

description:
There aren't that many, or maybe no Korean restaurants in my hood, but thankfully I am sorta near J-Town where they have some. I had been craving the spicy spices of Korean food lately and I came here last night and got my fave, hot beef soup. I didn't try BBQ because my brother wasn't with me last night...but it smelled good. Anyway, they mixed up my "barely any spice" order with "extremely spicy". I took one spoonful of the spicy spicy soup and started coughing. Thankfully the server was super cool and re-did my soup to "barely any spice", which was manageable. They also had an assortment of the small dishes, which I love. 

However the only bad thing about eating Korean, at almost every single restaurant except for my tofu house (since they don't let u cook it), is that you smell like Korean BBQ afterwards. It seeps into ur hair, ur clothes, ur socks, etc...I'd wear a garbage bag and a hair net if i could get away with it.
author: Natalie S.

description:
This place was frikkin awesome! I came here with a friend of mine and we've gone to many Korean restaurants on El Camino in San Jose and heard that this place was good, so we took a trip to the city.

It was clean and nice looking inside. It was a good welcoming atmosphere instead of the small and fob Korean restaurants that we're used to. The waiter was really nice and made sure everything was fine. The waitress didn't speak English very well, but she was also very polite. My friend and I are both servers, so we were impressed with the service compared to most other Korean restaurants.

The selection of food looked pretty awesome. At first, it seemed pricey, but we were hungry. I got the cow's tongue and my friend got the kalbi. We were also impressed that the menu had Japanese translations as well, but some of the words were wrong, haha.

The side dishes were really good! I've had the Korean side dishes at many different places and I like how each has their own taste, but I especially liked it here. Kinda small, but not a big deal, just get another one. The spicy side dishes weren't very spicy though.

The portions were a lot bigger than we thought! Woo, it was fun grilling at the table. The cow's tongue was kinda hard and difficult to chew, but still tasty. The kalbi was also really good, but since they were thick cuts, it was a challenge to get the insides cooked. We both got a second bowl of rice because there was so much meat!

Overall, a really awesome restaurant. Perhaps a bit pricey if you're used to the small Korean restaurants on El Camino or something, but my friend and I thought it was a really great deal due to portions and service. I will definitely recommend this place to others and we will be back again!
author: Momo C.

description: Mixed reviews about this place. I ordered some beef soup, and it was really watered down. However, some of the other stuff was really good. Good jap-chae and Tofu soups. I should have probably ordered something else, but oh well. The side dishes are good, they give you a pretty decent amount.
author: Dave K.

description:
This hit the spot!! 

After a long day in Napa and about 3 days without eating Korean food...we came here to satisfy our Korean food cravings...Kimchee jjigae. Bulgogi. Ojinguh bokkeum. Out of the three...the ojinguh bokkeum was the best. Really tender, spicy yet not unbearably spicy. The other 2 dishes were good too...but it was not like momma's home cookin'. Nor were they like some of the L.A. Korean restaurant food good. We were still happy and satisfied though. The place is clean and the service was excellent. One of the best places I've eaten during my visit to SF...maybe it was just the Korean food cravings...but nevertheless...it hit the spot.
author: Caroline Y.

description:
Walking in I was immediately struck by the familiar smell of Korean Barbecue that will permeate my clothes, my hair, and my entire being. My friend and I weren't particularly ravenous, so we went for the seafood sundobu, 1 order of Kalbi, and some chap chae (yes, I've been practicing my korean, can't you tell?) Since we only ordered 1 order of barbecue, the kitchen prepared it for us (thereby sparing us of said body-permeating food smell). The meat was juicy and tender, the chap chae was as expected, and the sundobu, predictably, burned a hole in my mouth with the right amount of spicyness.

My biggest gripe is the slow service. There were only 2 staff members at around 8:30 which was when we had asked for the check.  I'm sure it was  quiet night (although a large party checked in not long after), but it took forever to flag down someone to take our credit card, and then forever to get the card back. I would still go back for my Kalbi fix. It was super tasty but be warned!! Bring cash if you're in a rush.
author: Jordan G.

description: Had a concert at the Fillmore, and thus had to eat Korean food before hand.  It's a rule...don't question it.  We branched out a little bit from the regular two right next door.  I was glad we came to this place.  It's a very solid Korean joint.  Service was good, panchans were plenty.  And I was really pleasantly surprised with how good their spicy tofu soup was.  Their bi bim bop was also delicious.  I'll definitely come back again - the next time I go to a concert at the Fillmore.
author: jon y.

description:
Let me first say that I know my fare share of Koreans. They are group which, in all their "hardened" East Coast mentality, have blatantly labeled Korean food in SF as complete garbage. And while I'd like to stand up and argue with these guys for the sake of defending the name of my self-professed City and it's culinary scene; and really you just have to put New Yorkers in their place sometimes (rebuttal comment: NYC can suck a fat one), I also admit  I'm probably not a connoisseur of the cuisine in the first place. 

So where to go when your visiting mother turns to you and says "let's do Korean". Uh-oh.

I've been to this place before and while I thought the meal was fairly good, I had my doubts now. Was it good? Would it even matter to my lovable but admittedly midwest-Olive-Garden-loving mother? I didn't really have many options on my list to begin with. 

Criteria.
Restaurant not crappy diner or simple shack on Geary. Clean. Ample seating. Ventilation that doesn't make you, your clothes and all things you touch reek. This restaurant met all the above.

Food.
We predictably ordered your typical Caucasian take on exploring Korean flavors. Bulgogi. Jap Chae. Some ginseng soup with cornish hen. Did I mention portion control and number of entrees were overlooked?
Anyway, my assessment: the bulgogi was ok but even I could tell it wasn't the best. Maybe they skimped out and used diet 7-Up... yeah, I know your secrets! The Jap Chae was bland and consisted more of vegetables then actual noodles. The soup was a surprise hit and was a very comforting version of asian style chicken soup. The complimentary side dishes were good.

Was it good? Even I can at-est that this may not be the best Korean food but it did do the trick for our cravings. Come here for a decent meal if you are without hard-nosed Koreans from the East Coast (or LA).
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Know what to order here, the bbq chicken is so tender (we had them cook it). Otherwise, everything was just ok...we also got the beef that went with the sesame and sea salt. The beef is much thicker then what I'm used to (cho sun ok in chicago is  my standard)
author: Amy S.

description:
I really enjoyed my visit here. The inside was clean, and was not hotboxed with smoke like some other kbbq places. My group ordered a bunch of meat dishes, which were around $19-23 ea. Good portions, and pretty good sides. 

I definitely would go back to fill my stomach again with Korean goodness.
author: Ray C.

description:
I ate here yesterday with two friends. They both ordered bi bim bap and gobbled it up before I could say bi bim bap. I had what I always have, tofu kimchee bokum (with meat). 

They didn't have the tofu part on the menu but accommodated my request and the service was hands off but efficient and friendly.

The tofu kimchee bokum was very good but didn't have much beef in it. Maybe they got the wrong impression and thought I wanted mostly tofu. I'd say seoul garden does it a bit better. However, the ban chan (side dishes) were excellent and included:

Black beans: 5/5 Awesome
Sprouts: 4/5
triangular tofuish thing: 5/5
kim chee: 4/5
gelatinous white rectangle thing: 3/5 - maybe I just don't like this
potatoes (no seasoning): 2/5 not a hit

There was so much food I didn't even try the white kim chee and the zucchini but they looked good. There may have been one or two more side dishes too.


btw - where does anybody offer a great lotus root side dish????

oh and the whole thing cost something like $17/person - I will definitely be coming back.
author: Adam G.

description:
I've had this discussion with a Korean friend and we both always have the same question, why is korean food sooooo expensive.  If anyone can answer let me know, because i can make the same kalbi at home and charge you less.
Went here for lunch and 3 dishes were plenty for our group of 4.  I was disappointed by the portion size but in the end the amount was perfect.  Chapche needed more noodles, less cabbage.  Bulgogi was tasty and the tofu soup was just right.  All portions were just too small for the price you pay.  And when i say small, i mean salad plate size or smaller portions.  Good variety of the snacky snacks.  Not sure if i'd go back if i wasn't in the area already.
You also have the option of bbq'ing the food yourself or having them cook in the back.  Either way you still leave smelling like bbq.
author: Susan Z.

description: Korean BBQ food is pretty much the same everywhere so I'm not going to get too much into deal. They have great lunch specials that range between $10-$15. The food was good. Tofu soup was really good (I don't usually like it), and they give you rice soup dessert (yummy). We also ordered these gyozas but those weren't very good.
author: Karen L.

description:
One of my new faves for lunch in the j-town area.

For under $10 you can get kalbi or bulgogi or bi bim bap, or spicy soup; all served with 6 panchan side dishes.

The waitresses are ultra friendly and its never too crowded at lunch time.
author: Tak H.

description:
It's always very hard for me to be very impressed with any Korean restaurants because I grew up having better than restaurant quality Korean food everyday.  However, I do try very hard to not compare too much with my mom's amazing cooking whenever I eat at Korean restaurants.  (My friends are tired of me saying, "It's just not as good as my mom's!" ;)

Having that said, I did think New Korea House was pretty decent, and here's what I thought about their dishes:

Sides - Good
Spicy BBQ Pork over the Grill - Excellent
Spicy Beef Soup - Good
Green Onion Pancakes - Excellent (comes with some shrimp in it, but doesn't say it on the menu)
Bulgogi over the Grill (Sliced BBQ Beef) - Disappointing (Dry and not so flavorful) 

Also, one thing to note - if you're looking for some real spicy Korean meal that'll make you keep wiping the little sweat drops off of your nose throughout the whole meal, I don't think this place is it.
author: Sophia F.

description:
Wasn't too sure about a korean place in the middle J-Town. Trying to grab meal 2.5 (the meal between wedding ceremony and wedding reception) and grabbed a quick couple bowls of soon dobu (with the egg!).

The staff was courteous and helpful. The ban chan came quickly and a nice variety. Why oh why is the kimchi always raw?

In no time at all our clothes quickly reeked of korean food. WHAT WERE WE THINKING? I guess that's what happens when you're hungry.

Spongebob Awesomeness: Yes, we bibbed ourselves to not messy our fabulous outfits for the reception. Soon dobu splatter is not sexy.
author: Ronald M.

description:
was looking for the old korea house when we realized it closed. so we gave this place a try.

overall pretty decent, very flavorful soups and stews. banchan selection was good (little dishes). service was also good. 

seafood pancake was a little soggy, but tasted fine.

however, prices were a little high for my taste. i had korean food that was just as good in the sunset for less.
author: Jill L.

description: Their tofu soup is very good and comforting. They make it mild for children or anyone who doesn't like spicy food. I personally think their portion is generous. I'm very full when I leave the restaurant.
author: Aya M.

description:
Good appetizers, delish Korean dishes, and nice price.

Honestly I only visit during lunch time, and it's has been good always!
Not just to me, also to my fellow Korean co-workers.
We LOVE LOVE LOVE their sea food Bibimbap, which is a bit spicy seafood, vegi and rice dish in a sizzling stone bowl.

Yup, the food is Sizzling Hot here!
author: Chacha M.

description:
parking...in SF?!?! goodluck!

it's ok... nothing really stands out about the food.

staff is super nice :)
author: Mai G.

description:
I only had two dishes, chop chae and kalbi, yum!! 
Close to home and delicious! Hits the spot when you're craving Korean food. Service was a little slow, but that's cuz there's only 2 of us, but for a Friday night it's packed with huge family dinners. 

One thing I have to say that is to be prepared to smell like BBQ!! 
Total for us was $20 each for 2 dishes.
author: Judi K.

description:
Not to be confused with Korea House (perhaps this is a newer establishment under the same ownership that apparently has little creativity in naming restaraunts?). 

Anyway, last Friday night, time was NOT on my side and I was absolutely starving. I duck in (nice place by the way) and hastily ask the waiter, "what can I get to go in ten minutes?"

He pointed to something in the menu which I do not remember the name of. Eight minutes later, the guy had it in a box with hot sauce, rice and kim chee. Rock and roll!

I opened the container hastily out the door and found some sort of barbecued beef with a fried egg, some bean sprouts and other greens. I have no idea what it all was, but man, it was GOOD!

Yummy, hot and quick-- the winning combination.
author: Stuart Y.

description: This place is quite special to me.  My mother and I always used to go here whenever she was in town.  The BBQ chicken is tops, as is the naegmyun, and ojinguh bokkeum.  The banchan selection is simply heaven.
author: Lawree S.

description: I definitely enjoyed getting quality Korean food without having to drive all the way to the Richmond. We both got the sizzling bi bim bap and were quite satisfied. The banchan was brought out almost immediately and was a decent selection of food. The bi bim bap itself was pretty tasty and not super expensive. Service was good, too. I would certainly come back here if I wanted Korean food.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Give it up for the oldest Korean restaruant in SF.  Im not talkin bout the new korea house, im talkin bout OG wooden doors Korea House.  I dont even have to talk about the quality of food, this place is special in many other ways.  Its all about the downstairs.
