Nice Bar, vegas lounge style booths, you can sing karaoke, its more of a banquet style place.  All my large family banquets are held there, so I remember running around that place as a weee lad.   Im glad that you yelpers recognize that this is a great place.  

Represent.
author: Hen A.

description: Decent Korean food in a fun, outdated environment. The soup I had wasn't brain-melting, but the silken tofu was good quality. I need fishcakes, and this place didn't have 'em.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Great value, delicious food, nice service.

My coworkers and I came here for a team dinner the other night, and we were glad that they were so accommodating of us even though we showed up 45 minutes late to our reservations. It seemed we didn't have to worry since they had plenty of large, round tables that could seat big groups. We ordered bul go gi, daegi bul go gi, kal bi, and mushrooms to grill. We also got the add on that comes with the lettuce and rice, and we also ordered the seafood egg pancake/omelet, bi bim bap, mandu, and steak tartare. 

Everything was so tasty! The food came out super quickly, the meats were all well marinated and fun to cook, the bi bim bap wasn't drowning in sesame oil like other places, the mandu tasted homemade to someone, and all the little side dishes were great (bean sprouts, fish cake, tofu, kimchee, etc). 

Definitely a great place for large or small party. And not crazy crowded like Brothers! It doesn't have the same boisterous atmosphere, but it will do when you're starved and want your food fast.
author: Katherine P.

description:
I came here for my friend's bday party and there were easily 25 + guests. They were very nice and gave us a private room upstairs where we proceeded to gorge ourselves on kalbi, jap chae, and about 15 dishes of tiny appetizers. 

The cod was really spicy, and the beer did not help put out the fire, but the beef was sooooo tender and tasty and the jap chae was smooth as butter. It went down fast. I wish we could have grilled at the table, but they charge like $20+ per plate...and there's maybe 18 bite sized pieces per order. Good lord that's a lotta money!

At the end of the meal we each split it for roughly $40 a person, which included tax tip and alcohol. Three and a half stars for being so goddamn expensive. Why does Korean food have to be so goddamned overpriced but delicious?!?

You can park at Japantown garage a couple blocks away or keep your fingers crossed and try to find a spot on the street.
author: Aaron F.

description:
My "go to" place when I want good Korean food without too much of a wait.  Heck, if I can't get in here, then I walk up a few doors to Korea House and basically get the same food, just in a different atmosphere.

Saeng Sun Jun app (portion-wise, it could easily be a main dish) - essentially, it's battered white fish with a soy dip on the side.  Easy way to get fish w/out having to look at eyeballs and/or picking out all the bones.

Bibim Naengmyon - spicy, cold, chewy buckwheat noodles of yummy goodness with meat and vege's and a hard-boiled egg and sometimes Asian pear slices (which are a nice crunchy contrast to all the flavors in the bowl).  And if the scissors come out, be sure to say "Neh (yes)," otherwise, you're in for a treat fighting with those noodles.

When ordering meat, unless you like the smell of grilled meat in your hair and clothes or you're planning to take a shower later that night, pass on BBQing at your table.  Heck, from all the other folks BBQing, you'll still prolly reek of meat.  Not that there's anything wrong with that - occasionally.  I tend to prefer the pork, mainly cuz it's spicy, but that's me.  

Bibimbap - or what I call the kitchen sink is basically a mixture of meat and vege's over rice with a friend egg on top.  You can add spiciness with the red pepper paste they'll bring out.  It's sometimes a bit sweet and def not as spicy as what my mom has in her fridge.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
I LOVE KOREAN BBQ, or basically any food that you get to cook at your table, and this place did not disappoint. 

We had five people and we ordered three barbeque dishes, about $20 each. We also ordered a bunch of beer and sake. They give you a bunch of appetizers in little bowls and rice and soup. We got a beef, chicken and prawn dish. They were all good but the beef and prawns were amazing. I wouldn't recommend getting chicken because it takes so long to cook on the grill. It tastes good once it's finally cooked but the beef and prawns only take about a minute and are much more enjoyable.

The table next to us starting doing sake bombs and the staff was very mellow and did not have a problem with people being loud. They also heard it was my sister's birthday and brought out this fun potato and egg pancake thing (kinda like tortilla espanola) with a candle in it and we all sang happy birthday. 

I will definitely be going back to this place, especially with a group.
author: Jackie G.

description: My parents and their out of town guests took me here last night.  It was a nice enough place.  I am not a fan of cooking my own food on a bbq at the table.  For some people, this might be a load of fun, but for me, not so much.  I don't really like meat or grilling, so that might explain it.  I liked the small kimchee plates on the table, and this bowl of tofu and vegetables we got.  I don't think I'd come back unless I was with people who love meat.  There are lots of people like that.  The meat itself was very good, but it just seemed laborious to cook meat for 6 people.  We lounged there for almost 3 hours and they didn't mind, so that was really nice of them.
author: Julia D.

description:
Good place to go if you don't know what you want, but know it needs to be Korean.  And I'm talking about food here. Holla.

What's the difference between this and Korea House next door? Is it the same food and/or owner? No idea although both will serve you well. NKH requires you to go up some stairs and the interior is a bit nicer.  You could have a birthday dinner here, which I've done before. Ordered the following:

Nakji bokeum (spicy squid app) - could have been spicier but chock full of squid pieces; took this one home in a doggybag
Kimchi chigae - surprisingly strong
Dolsot Bibim Bap - hard to screw this up and they didn't

I thought it was all well done. The side dishes were plentiful - my favorites being the kak tu gi (radish kimchi) and kong na mul (bean sprouts). I was tempted to get some meat but it required two orders to cook at the table. 

Oh and get the Kimchi chigae if you're into it.
author: Michael S.

description:
Bibimbap, that panopoly of your own side dishes in a bowl to mix up with rice and work that squeeze bottle of gochujang out hit the spot.  Spicy, absolutely delicious soon doobu jigae sans seafood was excellent.  I didn't get to try the yuk gae jang as the bro hoarded it to himself.  Yummy warm green onion pancake (bin dae duk), radish, cucumber and cabbage kimchees and other tasty side dishes rocked our worlds.  We cleaned up, man.  I'm so stuffed, I can't breathe.  Eating Korean rules!  Service was fine.

One star down for no freebie dish, rubbery meat in the soups and bibimbap, watery japchae, and untasty shikae at the end.
author: Esther R.

description:
This is the first Korean restaurant SF that I've been to that's got an interesting point of view.  It's positioned as Korean "country cooking".  

Indeed, this food reminds me of my grandmother's country-style cooking.  Lots of unique vegetable side dishes in fermented/soy-based sauces.  Water-based kimchee "soupy" kimchee side dishes.  They have unique side dishes vs. what you can normally find in a Korean restaurant.  (They also promptly refilled the side dishes we inhaled.)  

I had their Kimchee Stew which came bubbling hot and had great flavor.  They also had great BBQ...but how can you really go wrong with that?  For me, the mark of great Korean restaurant is in the level detail and attention they pay to the basics (firm rice, good kimchee, etc... ) and this place has got the basics down pat.  

The appetizers were on the expensive side.  Hello?  $14 for Pa Jon (Scallion pancakes)?  That was my only gripe.
author: Tom K.

description: Having moved to the bay area from Los Angeles I sure was missing having access to some good korean food.  Until now!!!  I found this little treasure and since then it has been my go to place!  I love how the quality of the meat is top notch!   I usually order the Galbi , yukejang, galbi tang, and seafood pancake.   Try it out and you won't be disappointed!
author: Pearlie S.

description: I came here for "breakfast," which I guess only includes four different kinds of soup. I was disappointed because I really wanted a hot pot of some sort. The veggie soup I got was a bit too spicy for me and I didn't even finish it. I ended up just eating all the delicious banchan. It was pretty early in the morning and the place smelled like cleaning supplies. On one hand, it is good to know that they clean the place. On the other hand, it was not a pleasant smell that complimented my meal. Service was just okay. I'd go back later in the day because I'd still like to try some other dishes.
author: k h.

description:
I will first explain what my rating is based on.  I have been here three times now.  I don't know if this is the right one cause there are two right next to each other, but I have been to the one further east on the street level.  I think the other one is on the 2nd floor.  Also as a caveat, I am Korean, speak Korean, and know that at many Korean establishments, they treat you better because you are Korean so if your experience isn't good here, maybe that is it.  

Never ordered meat cause I am Korean, grew up on the stuff, and don't really crave it.  So I always order some soup because that is the stuff I can't make or buy at the store. 

I have been to lots of places for Korean food in SF and so far, this is the best.  (A little rant:  Those who like Brother's are so off cause if this was Los Angeles, there is no chance that it would be the best in SF, not even if you took away Koreatown and was only counting a suburb like Cerritos or Garden Grove.  I do admit that they do give you a variety of stuff when you order a combination meal for four, but the food isn't that good)  SF's Korean food is very limited and I am limited in my ability to get off what I consider this island of a city.  +)  

Their small side dishes (banchan) have been good.  

Once, I went there and my friend and I each ordered a soup, and then I tried ordering another pancake thing (pa-jun) and the waitress who was this older lady told me that it was too much and pretty much took that last thing off.  Yeah, you might have found this rude but I found it endearing, like something my mom's friend would do.  Plus, she brought us this other pancake thing (bin-dae-duk) that I believe comes free and that was really tasty as well.  

Never has it been crowded and if you ask for more side dishes, they give it to you which promptly which is great cause I come not only for my entree but those sides as well.
 
Now only if they gave shik-hye (rice punch) at the end, I would be so happy.
author: Mark C.

description:
Korea House is consistently good with everything.. From Jigae to BBQ..  I love their extensive Banchan and hot tea... 

I had a hankering for Bigae jigae yesterday, racking my brain for which place served it best. You know. you try a number of places, looking for the perfect pot and then because you've tried so many, you can't distinguish which one was the best...

Defaulted to the old standard, Korea House Rocks... and was again pleased to know that I wasn't wrong. I've never had a problem with their service, but it may be because i'm demanding and they know it. :)  Service with a smile. :)
author: Aimee C.

description:
The restaurant was a bit empty for a weekend dinner and that's nice because you don't have to worry about smelling like your food when everyone around you is in BBQ heaven.  We ordered the Soon Do Bu, Bibimbap, BBQ Chicken, and Pa Jung.  The Soon Do Bu was quite spicy, so be warned.  We didn't see the stone bowl Bibimbap, which made me a little sad...  The Pa Jung was just OK.  

I agree that the prices were a little expensive, but not way beyond the usually more expensive $ range.  If you're in J-Town but crave Korean food, I'd definitely recommend this place.
author: Ginni S.

description:
Overprice !! most expensive than any other korean restaurant around. 
This place is tricky ! They put cheaper price on menu outside on their window and when you came in, the price is double. They told me outside menu is for Lunch only. Then why I did not see "Lunch" on the menu outside ? 
Inside Price: kalbi $29, Bulgogi $22. Even lettuce is $7 !!! I thought lettuce is Free ??
 Taste just ok but not worth the price. Go Tofu House or Brother or Han Il Kwan they give you free tofo soup and unlimited Lettuce.
author: Steven L.

description:
"stereotypically" Korean restaurants are associated with: rude service, bad English (or NO English), stinkiness after you eat BUT not this place! :)  When I called to make reservation, the guy was super nice and helpful.  Service was attentive and they even sent out some king oyster mushroom on the house!  
We started with their seafood pancake (cannot go to K bbq w/out ordering!) and it's huge and got plenty of seafood.  The various types of meat we ordered were all very tasty and well marinated.   The best is that every table has a hood that actually works so we all left the restaurant not smelling like the food we just ate! :)  big plus~

I haven't been to too many Korean restaurants in the city actually but I used to live in LA and can confidently say that while the food might not be comparable (but hey, u CANNOT beat LA when it comes to Korean food, just no) but it's good enough and service is def WAY better esp when the customer and server can understand each other!
author: Vickie L.

description:
What was i thinking?????

Should have never gone to a Korean restaurant in Japan town.  I thought Korean restaurants in Michigan and Seattle was bad, oh my goodness, this was the worst Korean restaurant I have ever been to.
author: Ernie K.

description:
As far as my background in korean food, this was the first korean restaurant i have been too, but regardless, i was impressed!

My girlfriend and i stopped into Japantown for lunch and stumbled into the new korea house. It was empty at noon on a thursday, so we practically had the place to ourselves.

We ordered from the lunch menu and for 20 bucks (not including) tip, we both got a fabulous meal. Not only did we get what we ordered, but we were also served all these mini-dishes which included some vegetables in different sauces, tofu, what looked like kim chee, soup, and some kind of korean pancake with a soy dipping sauce. It was worth twice what we paid for it! And the ladies that served us were very friendly and helpful with how to navigate all the wonderful food in front of us.

i'm definitely going back, perhaps to sample their dinner menu!
author: Charlie R.

description:
Of the Korean restaurants in the Japantown area this one gets an overall "okay" from my mom. The food is decent, the place is clean, the portions are hearty and the price is reasonable. There are a lot of stairs to get into the restaurant and also to use the bathroom. My only complaint is the potential to leave the place smelling like you've been at a barbecue. That's pretty typical of a Korean restaurant but it's still a hassle.
The banchan is abundant and they're good about filling up any empties. The service is pretty good too.
author: Richard S.

description:
the one i went to said 'new korea house' 

good service. good side dishes (ban chan) but man..main food sucks..
i grew up eating korean food and for the past 6-7yrs been to seoul almost every year since my sis relocated there but i'm not too picky..most korean restaurants do a decent job..but this place was simply below my standard for korean food....

i had biji jjige (ground soybean stew) and ordered bin-dae-dduk on the side, but the seasoning was all off..!!! maybe their bbq is good but way i see it, if you fail on basic home food like biji jji-ge, forget it..i was so happy they had it on the menu since it's hard to find these days, but was so disappointed..i left more than half uneaten and didn't bother taking the leftover either. they cooked w/beef when it's usually made with pork (the server did tell me they use a little bit of ground pork when i asked about it before ordering it) and personally, think used way too much green onion, and the ground soy bean tasted slightly undercooked. and the sauce..! which is THE crucial point in this dish, so mediocre, i could've made a better sauce..

bin-dae-dduk (mung bean pancake) was all mushy;  the batter must've been too watery or not fully cooked or something..i like the prepacked  ones i get from kukje market (daly city) much better.
there was something about the texture that made me seriouslyl wonder if they just reheated the premade pancake rather than making it fresh..

my friend had stone pot bibimbap, which looked good enough (my food looked good too, until i tasted it..) 
i didn't bother trying. it'd been too sad if they failed such basic ones like that one..

i'm giving 2 stars cuz the service was good and again, ban chan was good enough (but no superb either)

go to temescal/oakland if you want decent korean food in the Bay Area..or 8th/geary area ..not japantown..
author: Karen H.

description: This is the place I head to when I crave Korean food; I come here on a monthly basis. The bbq rib eye, stir fried kim chee with tofu, spicy pulled brisket soup, and kim chee soup are my favorites here. The small plate dishes are delicious, especially the cucumber kim chee. Make sure to ask for the lettuce to wrap the beef, rice, and sprouts. Then devour it like a lettuce cup. Give this place a try; you won't be disappointed.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I wonder why there are so many 4 star ratings for this place. It wasn't outstanding in any way. Maybe I ordered the wrong dish? I'm willing to go back to give it another try (with another dish) later on....but my first experience:

The setting and location are pretty good. The place is clean, waiters efficient (although not the friendliest ones around), and prices fairly decent for a typical Korean BBQ. The selection wasn't aplenty, but then again, that's typically the case for Korean BBQ joints. 

I got the Bul-go-gi...which wasn't that great. By the time it was cooked on the table stove, it was dry, tasteless, and kind of hard. -_-. Had to stuff my rice with a lot of the veggies provided to get a tasty mouthful. My friend ordered the Kal-bi, which compared to mine, was much tastier....but still fairly typical compared to other similar restaurants.
author: April Z.

description:
This ranking is for the lunch special.  Wow!  I flew into SFO today and headed north for Japantown with a craving for Korean spicy pork.  I went with the $8 Spicy BBQ Pork lunch special.  Besides a good amount of tasty (if not super-spicy) pork, it came with 5 really good Korean starter dishes (including kim chi, spicy pickles, and asian greens), a really tasty beef broth, a pot of tea, a cold shredded carrot and papaya salad, two orange wedges and a piece of cantaloupe.

If this place was in NY, I'd go once a week easy.

Note: Outside of the lunch specials, this place looked pretty pricy... 

Aside:  Why hasn't iron chef had a BBQ Pork battle b/w a Korean and Southern chef?  How is this not more interesting than the 'lentil battle' I  saw last night.  Lentils?  Oy...
author: Scott R.

description:
Very delicious Kalbi! Bulgogi was good too, as well as the chap jae and seafood pa jun.

They gave plenty of "sides" including my all time favourite: umm... I don't know what's it called - but it's those fried fish cakes in some sweet sauce :-)
author: Sheren H.

description:
Yum.  This place is delicious, conveniently located, and pretty reasonable for Korean bar-be-que.  We had the short ribs and the bul-go-gee, both were excellent and the texture was different enough to make the meal interesting (I would normally be opposed to ordering two types of beef).  They have gas grills, which I guess aren't quite as fun as the charcoal ones, but you'll leave smelling less like Korean bar-be-que then you would at some other restaurants.  Their little side dishes are not as varied as other places, but maybe that's because there were only two of us.  

I think the total for 2 entrees, 2 large beers, tax, and tip came to about $70 for two.  I will definitely go back to try their tofu stew.
author: Cristina C.

description:
I just came back from Seoul, since my girlfriend is back home for the summer, and I missed her quite a great deal. So one morning I woke up and said FUCK IT! and left for Korea.  I came back, and the funny thing is, The culture shock hit me when I was back on American soil!!! 

I've fallen in love with Seoul! I miss everything about Seoul; the businessmen in shiny suits, and crystal encrusted ties. The girls that look like they took HOURS to get ready to go out, just to go to the mall. The buildings, the bustle, the organized and polite....chaos of it all. I also miss the food! Oh god the food. Not the hip and happening modern fusion cuisine, but the Korean BBQ and all the different versions that exist in Seoul.

I came to Korea House expecting the same experience.... But I dont know... it just didn't feel.... Korean to me. I'm not going to say that i know all there is to know about Korean BBQ, but coming back from having korean bbq for lunch and dinner everyday for a week, I tasted the difference. I don't know what it is, so i guess there's one star deduction.

Another deduction comes from how utterly expensive this place is. In Korea, me, my girlfriend and oh, maybe I dont know 5 other people ate and drank until everyone at the table was passed out, and it only came to 100 USD. Here at Korea House thats how much it came to for two people. TWO PEOPLE! 

The only reason why i gave it 3 stars is simply because it gave me a sense of South Korea... sort of an allusion to it. I just need to go back to Seoul I guess, and I think I will....
author: Kelvin M.

description: Korean BBQ sometimes just totally hits the spot. The three of us were craving meat. We sat down at Korea House and feasted on our Kal bi and Bu Ko Ki. 2 orders of meat was definitely enough for the three of us. We left with full tummies and a food coma. Ahhh, good times.
author: Debbie C.

description: A reliable Korean restaurant in Japantown. It's slightly less expensive than Seoul Garden, so this is one reason I'd come here. I also like the big round table that can accomodate a larger group. I believe that the upstairs can be rented for a bigger function. I've had Korean Bean Paste (Miso) stew, Kimchi Stew, Pork Bulgogi, and Bibimbap. All were acceptable. It wasn't memorable enough for me to want to cross the bay bridge just for the food, but I'd not object to dining here, if I happen to be in the area.
author: Su K.

description:
Update: After moving in with NKH#1 for a minute, they've now moved back to their original locale.  

I hate to do this, but we're now at 3 stars.  Something about the portions and quality went awry the other day for my take out; tasted different a while back too :(  I know I've had better!  Did the chef change?  Okay, I recommend that you eat here if you want to sample all their side dishes, etc.  There just isn't enough compartmentalization in these styrofoams to help them out.  Ugh.  And why doesn't our county/country recycle styrofoams?  Such a guilt trip to taking out... 

Anyhow, I pray the original standards of cooking come back soon...

===== originally 4 stars ====
I love this place!!  Their kalbi, bulgogi, dolsot bibimbap, kalbi tang (soup), japche, hae jan gook (soup), are all on my usual/favorites list!!!  Too bad I can't spell. 

I started out going to New Korea House 2, but then the owner consolidated restaurants and moved it all to New Korea House 1 (up a flight of stairs), I was told.  The service was awesome at #2, and the friends we made were super generous with the assortment of side dishes and dessert.  (you gotta work it up into the usual customers' ranking *wink*!)

I see new waiters at #1 now, and their service is okay.  Food is still great, and as always you get seated right away.  A good place for large groups and families with children.  and loud talkers like me.  This is my go-to Korean restaurant, esp when I'm craving meat / kalbi.  

During dinner hours, you can either find street parking, or I've often parked in J-Town garage for cheap, esp if you're in/out of dinner.
author: Nanemone T.

description: Decent food. Kimchi and side dishes were very good. Entrees were alright, a bit pricy compared to other Korean BBQ places around the area.
author: Landon Y.

description:
Korea House is where you'll get comfort Korean food without the LA attitude. I uprooted from LA a month ago and was refreshed to see some kind service for once unlike the restaurants in K-town where they throw down onto the table all the side dishes and give you dirty looks if you don't speak Korean. We went on a Friday night at 10pm and they said they close @ 11:40 - which I assume means the time their kitchen closes. 5 of us ate and everything we had we enjoyed: kim chee chigae, kalbitang *hangover soup as I like to call*, soondoobu, chapchae and kalbi*tender and sweet* and 1 bottle of soju. Out the door $20 bucks a person with tip. 

Watch out for them turning off the restaurant lights to get you out towards 12am though. Then again, if I were them, I'd want to go home to.
author: Jessica C.

description:
As others have noted, good food but a bit pricey.

I am compelled to recommend the soju with cucumber drink.  They slice up a whole cucumber and lemon and have the soju marinate in a dalek-like daisy covered dispenser.  More refreshing than a mint julep!

If Koreans re-enact Gone with the Wind, they will be sipping cucumber soju on the porch while fanning themselves on a porch swing.
author: Dave S.

description:
3.5 - I knocked it down by half a star cuz it's kinda pricey. I had the Dol Sot Bibimbap ($14.95) which while good wasn't amazing. Could have had more beef for the price. What was good was the panchang (side dishes). They offered 10 different sides - kim chee, 3 types of daikon, sprouts, potatoes, spicy cucumbers, tempura, black beans, and the white jello looking thing.

Korea House offers full bbq for your grilling pleasure. I glanced at the menu and basic Bugolgi was $19.95 a plate. I'm sure it is pretty tasty but be ready to spend a little and you definitely will come out smelling of what you ingested. Even this time around, with no one grilling, the air was still heavy of the smell. Not a bad thing but I prefer not to smell like someone else's lunch.

Would certainly go back with a group.
author: Cindy W.

description: New Korea House is conveniently located below Yakini Q. It serves traditional BBQ dishes a la carte without the party atmosphere of other Korean BBQ restaurants in the area. Its clean and a step up in class than Yakini Q. Its no frillsand often uncrowded. It pretty traditional BBQ as seen in the groups of older men who come in their house clothes at 11pm. It makes me feel magically transported to Asia. If my mom was in town I'd take her here, she'd find it delicious and entertaining. It can be a bit pricey, plan on spending $50 a person at least.
author: Alice S.

description: I was a bit disappointed.  Both the ribeye bulgogi and the dolsot bibimbap (chicken) did not have much flavor.  The daeji bulgogi (pork) was good and so were the kimchi side dishes .  Based on the reviews , the neighborhood and the price, I expected much better. No tripe.
author: Markus U.

description: I absolutely love living in SF but a huge drawback of living in the city is the lack of good Asian eats.  As is the case for Chinese food (no, San Franciscans, R&G Lounge is mediocre if you've ever eaten in the southland pockets for c-food ), if you want good Korean food, it's in L.A.  I was born and  raised in L.A. and enjoyed fabulous Chinese, Thai, and Korean food for half my life as I suffered the smog, pretentiousness, traffic and sprawl that comes with living there.  But I always had KoreaTown and my bi bim bap.  Seriously, there is no Korean and Chinese food here in the city.  New Korea House suffices for some Korean food when the cravings overtake me but I have to blank out all memories of my nights of bi him bap runs in L.A. while I'm eating it here.  Or else I am a sad, grouchy bitch as I sit with my head sunken in disappointment while snarfing NKH.  It's not a knock on NKH; I haven't found any better yet.  I'm still searching and open to suggestions.  I've taken lately to asking random local Koreans I meet if they can make good bibimbap and if so, whether I can pay to have some if they make it. Yeah, I'm a pathetically desperate gal. So my review of NKH is basically favorable if you haven't ruined yourself already with the mental imprint of what good Korean food tastes like.  That sounds facetious but it is not meant to be.  Helpful review it's likely not but that 6 hour drive doesn't sound that bad right now for a weekend soon.
author: Liz K.

description:
Korea House is where I first encountered Korean BBQ, and it was love at first bite! I have fond memories of this place.

My mom brought us here some 15+ years ago, when I was like 7 or 8? I distinctly remember the giant wooden doors and trudging up a stairwell to discover the joys of cooking deliciously marinated meats at our own table, wrapping them up in lettuce with rice, and sampling a variety of banchan.

I went back a few years ago and felt the prices were a little bit on the pricey side, but I honestly have no idea what we used to pay back in the day. Then again, I also eat disproportionately large quantities of food for someone my size, so all-you-can-eat Korean BBQ is always the better deal for me.
author: Albert H.

description:
I like this place.  Reminds me of the Korean BBQ restaurants back home.  This place has alot going for it.  It's clean.  There's a grill on every table.  The service is very efficient, it took a whole 2 minutes after we put in the order for all the 50 dishes of panchan (side dishses with all the yummy goodies like cucumber kimchi, cabbage kimchi, radish kimchi, bean sprouts, potatoes, spinach, gelatin, etc...) to come out then 2 minutes later they brought out the BBQ meat then 2 minutes after that they brought out the other dishes we ordered.  They are very very efficient here.  They also hooked us with a free dish.  If you didn't know this about Korean restaurants is that hooking customers up with a free dish is a customary thing.  Or maybe I pulled the Korean hook up by attempting to order in my broken somewhat decent Korean.  

But anyways, the food was great.  The service was great.  They hooked us with a free dish and it's Korean food which is my favorite food so I give this place 5 stars.
author: David C.

description:
Let's face it, Korean food is pricey in San Francisco. 

Yet, I know that when I visit New Korea House, I will feel satiated for days. Actually, a few weeks ago, I went there 2 days in a row. Its THAT good!

I am obsessed with their kimchi chigae. If you ever feel a cold coming to visit you - kick it to the curb with this fantastic soup!  If you feel like BBQ - the meat is delicious - and you won't smell like beef after you leave.
author: Judy L.

description:
I was craving kimchee soup last night, so we decided to give Korea House a try. My BF never actually "bbqed" Korea food before, so we decided to also cook our own chicken and Kal bi meat on our table grill. 

While we were waiting for our meat to grill, we ate our numerous vegetable side dishes and kimchee soup. I was not that pleased with our soup. It wasn't that good. It was served with "regular" texture tofu (so image huge chunks) and not soft tofu and there was no beef in it at all. Now that I think about it, there wasn't any other veggies in it other than kimchee. It wasn't that spicy and overall, it was not the best kimchee soup I've had.

The meat, however, was pretty good. The kal bi and chicken was marinated very well. After grilling all night for our dinner, I remembered why I always preferred the kitchen to cook for us. It is a lot of work, so you have be in the state of mind for that. 

I probably wouldn't say Korea House is one of my preferred Korean restaurants in SF.
author: Denise L.

description:
Note: review is for takeout only; not for sit-down BBQ, though we're going soon.

My household has a new obsession with New Korea House, if only for their tofu chiggae takeout expeditiousness during the sicky cold/ flu season.

Barring traffic, it takes a little under 10 minutes to drive from the SOMA to Japantown, and by the time you reach NKH (with some speedy parking luck), you'll have you'll have your neatly and firmly-packaged  hothothot tofu stew, 2 cups of rice, and a generous platter of at least 9-10 types banchan.

Sometimes calling in is more efficient and walking up and trying to wait for a server to take your order.  When I was there on a recent weeknight, the 2 servers that I could see were rushing around so madly it was all I could do to flag them down.

And the stew? Delish.  It's all packaged up very well - there's nary a drop spilled by the time I get home, and the stews are still piping hot.  The seafood tofu chiggae is always a favourite -- containing many tiny peeled shrimp, some oysters and one lone clam.
author: Claudine C.

description: Normally I bash and destroy the korean restaurants in the SF/Bay area, but this one isn't half bad!  I came here craving jjigae, and was surprised to be served a piping hot, well flavored kimchee jigae!  I had the dduk mandoo guk, my most favorite korean comfort food of ricecake soup, which is made with the broth of beef or oxtail, has those little disk ricecakes, and mandoo, which are our people's way of saying "dumplings".  It was good and maybe a little bland, but good with kimchee and better that way than being salty.  The bindaedduk, which is a pancake much like pajun but made with mung beans, was questionably made... it still had the texture of pajun, which is typically made with rice flour.  It was lacking the gritty bean texture.  They tasted good though, if you don't care about a food being mislabeled for something else.
author: Terry K.

description:
This Korean restaurant is wonderful!! The waiters are just wonderful and very nice. We go there about 5 times a month and BBQ there for dinner.
The side dishes are really good. My favorite side dish is fish cake.
author: Stephen T.

description: I was always friendly with the owner.  pretty good korean food.  cannot complain.  obviously not the same as palace BBQ in sunnyvale, but what is?  a little pricey for what they give you, but not uncommon for korean food around here!
author: paul l.

description:
So there's cheap Chinese food, cheap Vietnamese food, cheap Thai food, cheap Indian food, and cheap Japanese food..

So why aren't there any places that serves cheap Korean food??  Did they all conspire to not serve cheap Korean food in San Francisco?!  Just name one place that serves good and cheap Korean food and I'd be up all over that place five times a week!  

Anyhow, the food at Korea House was delicious!!  The chope che was goooood.  The bi bim bop was goooooood too.  Even the side dishes were goooood!!  But was it expensive?  yeeeeessss.
author: hello k.

description:
We had a large 20+ table and they had to split us up into 3 different tables..which in the end actually worked out better because the bill was easier to split. 

I love Korean BBQ. I think it's a fabulous cuisine and i love all the appetizers that they give you when you sit down.  All the different varieties they give you, the different flavors are so unique.  

We started with rounds of 5 large sapporos for our table of 6.  We ordered the BBQ beef short ribs, bbq beef, some noodle dish and another meat dish...the flavors were awesome, BUT...unfortunately, a lot of the meat was very fatty and also, the bbq short ribs were almost impossible to eat. Way too much of that impossibly chewy, no way you can bite through it stuff and no meat at all. really a shame because it was so nicely marinated. 

The noodles we had were AWESOME.  I don't know what they were called, they were the clear silver noodles though and it was really really good, but the portions were tiny =( 

i gave this place 3 stars due to the fast, friendly service, the food WAS good...excep for a few exceptions on the meat fattiness...and company was awesome =) 

between the 6 of us, it was $25 each for a large helping of meat, rice, noodles & LOTS of sapporo beer..

i do also remember some shots of soju throughout the course of the meal...maybe that was from another table though...=)
author: Lulu C.

description: Not so great. Weak barbecues, bland meat and inexperienced wait staff. I'd better go to Jang Su Jang in Santa Clara, even if it's far.
author: Guillaume R.

description:
Excellent side dishes.  Great atmoshpere to bring friends to have Korean bar-b-que.  

Best Korean place I've been too so far.
author: Alan T.

description:
In terms of Korean restaurants in SF, this is a pretty good choice. The quality of their meat is sometimes hit or miss, but their other dishes  seafood pancake (Hemul Pajun), soondoobu, dolsot bibimbap and gookbap are rather tasty .  As others have stated earlier, their side dishes (ban-chan) are very yummy, a sure sign that the cooks know what they are doing in the kitchen.

Whenever I go, I don't have to wait, and the service is pretty good for a korean restaurant  Sometimes, we get free food, which is always a plus.  Their price is little steep compare to other restaurants, but in korean restaurant standards, about average. 

I don't know who decided korean food should be expensive, but that's a bad news for everyone who enjoy korean food.  I simply don't get it... the meat's cheap, and other ingredients are cheap, so why is it so freaking expensive?  No matter where I go, 1 serving of most korean bbq cost $20.  Wtf?  Is it because we simply put up with it and keep going back?  Oh well.... I sure will keep going back for more.  I just can't stay away.

Bon Appetit
author: YJ H.

description:
Had one of my best meals here recently. Myself and two friends (one getting over the flu), stepped out on a cold night for tummy-warming Korean food. 

Both friends have raved about New K House before, but this was my first experience. Everything was excellent. I couldn't stop raving over the side dishes. So many varieties and flavors. The soy bean sprouts were particularly yummy, but I tried every dish saying "this one's my favorite -- no this one's my favorite." You get the picture....

Entrees were steamed squid with special dipping sauce, spicy beef soup, beef tongue with onions, and a dish of eggy coated fish pieces. We practically licked the plates. Seriously... Next time I conquer the grilled meats!
author: Antoi C.

description:
My friend and I came here for lunch and we were the first one there.   We both knew what we wanted and quickly order. 

The panchan were great!  Very fresh and we both throughly ravish those little dishes quickly.

The bulbogi was great.  Lots of tender beef for me to share with my friend.  It was perfectly cook and seasoned and it was quickly disappeared off my plate.  The kalbi that my friend order was equally good.  She throughly enjoyed biting off the bone and the tenderness of the beef. 

All with great service from the waitress.

Will be back soon to eat more.
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm grateful for a clean, not crowded Korean BBQ place that doesn't make me smell like I've lived in Soy sauce and charcoal for 2 months.

Korea House (the upstairs one, not the crappy street level one) is a propane BBQ place, with excellent dishes and lunch specials - reasonably priced, too!

Dishes to try:
kalbi
duk mandoo guk
dolsot bimbim bop

My only wish is that one day they'll make Sul Long Tang - that would really make this place perfection in my eyes!
author: dj z.

description:
This place would get 5 stars if not for being so expensive..

I went there for lunch on a Sunday thinking I would just grab a cheap bowl of tofu soup...but ended up with a $50 bill between the 2 of us.

The tofu soup was possibly the best I've ever had though.  We also had the dolsot bi-bim-bop which was 'ok' but nothing special.  The pajang (onion pancake with meat) was good, but just slightly soggy for my tastes.

We did have a FEAST between the 2 of us.  The table for 4 was just completely covered in dishes since they definitely hook you up with all kinds of tasty side dishes.

I probably will go back, but only for dinner since they don't have lunch specials (or it might be just no lunch specials on Sundays).
author: Sam H.

description:
Came here with some friends after leaving a sushi place that was packed because we were not willing to wait. This is the average Korean restaurant with average tasting food. However the prices were a little above average. For what was offered the prices were a little too expensive. 

The place was very spacious, had many tables and is good for groups. There are many tables with built in grills for self cooking. But I usually skip that option because I don't like smelling like smoke for the rest of the night. The service was nice and quick.

Since we set out to eat sushi that night, I had to order something raw.  So I ordered the Steak tartar with sesame oil and pears. It was pretty disappointing because the steak was still partially frozen. We also ordered an eel bibimbap, jap chae, grilled chicken, tofu soup. The standout dishes to me was the jap chae and grilled chicken. There was nothing really special about the chicken, it was just cooked well. The jap chae was warm and flavorful but not worth 15 dollars, especially for the small plate. The cantaloupe they had for dessert was dry and stale, I prefer the melon flavored gum served at most other Korean places. 

Overall 3 stars. There are plenty of other similar restaurants if you're in the mood for Korean.
author: Colin H.

description:
The lack of a good Korean restaurant near the Financial District is really driving me nuts. Thankfully, my craving for spicy tofu stew was satisfied by a quick $10 cab ride to Japantown and NKH.

My first reaction was one of alarm: given the high ratings that I'd seen for NKH on Yelp, I was slightly concerned that there was only one other table filled in the whole restaurants. Maybe Tuesday is meatloaf night at home for all of San Francisco. No matter. My craving beckons.

The service was swift (and it better be, with only other table!), and the banchan arrived before me in minutes. I proceeded to dip everything in the delicious and glowing-red hot sauce of the pickled cucumbers. I was less impressed with the seafood tofu stew itself, which bubbled for a full 2 minutes after being brought hot to the table. However, the stew tasted quite bland to me, and the promise of seafood was realized by only 1 tail-on shrimp, 2 oysters, and assorted bits and pieces of shrimp-like protein in the cast iron pot. All in all, it was something of a let-down.

The tab for the stew and a coke came to $20, which seems a bit excessive given some of the other Korean restaurants I've visited in the East Bay. It may be punishment for my cowardice for not venturing deeper into the Richmond for Korean food. Next time, I won't make that mistake.
author: Ian S.

description:
this is the best korean place i've had in the J-Town area, and I think i've tried most.  It's quite a nice looking joint actually, with good decor etc, but really who's here for the look of the place?  we're here for the food.  definitely on the pricier side, the meat quality is actually very good, but they do skimp a little on the quantity of meat.  for that reason, it gets a 4 star compared to my other review of Han Il Kwan (my vote for best korean in SF).

they were able to easily accomodate our party of 12 (at 2 tables), with no reservations on a friday night.

all in all, i'd come back for a more "upscale" korean joint.  not that i need the upscale-ness, but who knows, sometimes you want that.  otherwise for cheap eats i'm across geary at arang (it's decent and reliable), or Han Il Kwan.
author: Jason J.

description: I love Korean food!...I went to lunch and had their Chicken BBQ lunch special for $8.95. It came with rice, vegetables, and all the side dishes you can ask for.  Their chicken was good but nothing special.  I would of gave this place 4 stars, but the kim chi had a little tangy kick to it, which i didn't like...the place was clean and our waitress was kind.  Overall:  would probably check other Korean joints next time i am in the area.
author: RJ B.

description:
Prior to today's lunch visit, I had dined here once before with my parents (my Mom loves Korean food) and sampled their Korean BBQ.  Everything was as expected, nothing extraordinary but still quite tasty.  
Today for lunch, I decided to try one of their Bibimbap, the one with bulgogi, a first for me.  I enjoyed it tremendously as it was an extremely satisfying meal, the little side dishes round out the meal nicely.
author: Jon P.

description:
So growing up near Japantown, my dad used to take us to this place for all occassions...Birthdays, Graduations, and normal Sundays.  I have a fond connection to this place because it's where I celebrated many good times in my youth.  So, for that, this place is 5 stars in my book.  My dad loved this place and we would always go there.  No arguments, just good times.

But, the last few times I have been here (and I go about once a month), the service has been bad and the food was so-so.  I don't know what happened to this place, but I give it chance after chance.  I have been to the other korean spots in SF and like them from time to time and they are good...but not New Korea House food.  I am giving -1 for the service and -1 for the so-so food.  It used to be amazing...I don't know what happened.
author: Dan D.

description:
Great bibimbap!
The staff were very friendly and chill, which is not always the case at some Korean  restaurants, so props on that.
author: Doug W.

description:
So I have a ton of friends who have all had Korean BBQ before. I however am the exception untill my birthday this year.

   My best friend took me to Korea House for my post birthday and hangover dinner. This place is awesome!!! Yeah its decor is kinda lame,there was a huge dead fish in the fish tank and you will be thirsty if you don't remember to ask for your diet coke and water when you order but other than that....pure awesome. 

 You cook the meats yourself on a grill in the middle of your table, and who doesn't like that?  Many dishes of Kim-Chee and other delights are deposited  on your table pre meal. All of which are wonderful. The bibimbap was to die for and our table was fighting over it....the entire time. 

They serve beer so you can get all post hangover over and get your ass back out there and party it up again. Food is great and its not that expensive portions are enough for more than one perfect for two.

 I couldn't stop screaming "Korea House is rad"  our entire dinner, and yes of course I will be back...I love you Korea House you rock.
author: Charlie B.

description: I have tried this place, and other Korean places, with my gf since her family is Korean.  So far we have liked this one the most for its food.  The ambience is fine, and usually when we go there are 5-6 other tables.  We typically order the kalbi (korean beef short ribs) which comes with a bunch of side dishes of kimchi, etc.  All in all I always have a good time here and lately this has been our preferred Korean place.  I definitely intend to come back from time to time.
author: Chris W.

description:
i believe this was my 3rd experience with korean bbq. my gf and i were staying in the neighborhood, and decided to have dinner in the area, and luckily, this was within walking distance. 

we were sat immediately, and decided on the bbq. troves and troves of food were brought out. we were able to try all the different little dishes, which we loved. but the best part of it was of course the bbq!

it was a nice and novel experience, great for date nights, cooking the food right in front of us. the variety of the sides were great too. we were able to enjoy new things, and most of which, were great tasting.

i would still consider myself a novice in the world of korean food, but this was a good experience. the bbq was great, trying the new sides was great. the decor was okay. but you can def take a date here.
author: Mik B.

description:
It was ok.  The pork belly was only 8 pieces and cut way way way to think for my preference.  I felt it was over priced... especially when to get the lettuce and miso paste was an extra 7 per person or something insane

I would not ever go back.  

Only went cause we were there on a sunday afternoon  about 5 and wanted a super late lunch and it was the only korean bbq place open in japantown at that time.
author: M. S.

description:
The bibimbap was DELICIOUS!!!  I especially loved the crunchy rice at the bottom of the bowl.  It also included A LOT of side dishes which were delicious.  My favorite was the fish cake slices YUM.  

Anyways, that was not the best part.  I dropped my Ipod there and didn't realize until the next day.  I totally thought that someone would've just taken it and kept it but I thought I should call the restaurant up anyways to make sure.  It turned out they found it and kept it for me!  When I went to pick it up, they wished me a happy new year.  So if the food wasn't good, I would go there again just because of the nice staff.  Since the food WAS good, I'm going to go there more often.
author: Wei P.

description: Fantastic veggie bi bim bap, $12 for lunch, with lots of banchan
author: P K.

description:
the first time I went here was with a Korean women who ordered for all us girls on a girls night out.
It was crazy... i have never had so much food put in front of me. I loved it all. (save for those weird rice flour jello thingys)
I then took my boyfriend. Of course we ordered way too much food again.
But it was all so good and fun.
We had BiBimBop- it was great. Love  barley cooked egg and savory spicy sauce.
And we also had a tofu stew with squid, shrimp and pork.
Too great to finish.
Wish we could have taken it all home but we had movie to go to, and thought I would be too tempted to break into leftover's during the movie.
author: shannon t.

description:
Best and cleanest Korean food I've had in a long time. Fast and happy service. A billion little plates of pickled veggies and a nice cup of tea when you sit down. Food is plentiful and delicious. This place really impressed me. 

The BBQ and soups are GREAT! Be ready for a lot of really really good food!
author: Tiffany T.

description: Great bimbimbop! We had the veggie one and it was delicious!
author: K J.

description:
Summary: Nice servers don't make up for the low quality -- but a few things are ok, so you might get lucky.

I had sul lun tang, which is basically beef bone soup, and the broth was proper. They don't have it by name on the menu but the nice waiter guy set it up for me. The meat was not so good. Only the cucumber banchan was good, so that's like one out of six -- not a high rate. And I love Korean food.

I muscled down two bowls of rice with half the broth to get full and got out of there. I'd like to review the BBQ meats they have, but I'm not going back and I wouldn't bring a visiting Korean friend there. Sorry, waitstaff, you are very nice but that's not enough!
author: Nick C.

description:
New Korea House gets 3 full happy tummies! My friends and I wanted to try someplace new to satisfy our Korean BBQ cravings. We met here for dinner last night and afterwards I dreamt about the delicious goodness that I ate!
Atmosphere: meh, the usual Korean restaurant feel. 
Service: great service by our waiter! 
Food: we ordered bul go gi (thinly sliced marinated beef), kimchee chigae (tofu soup with kimchee) and bibimbap (rice mixed with beef and veggies with an egg on top). The japchae We skipped the traditional cooking-of-the-bul go gi and asked them to cook it for us. It was served and we weren't disappointed! It was perfectly sweet. The kimchee chigae wasn't spicy enough but I still enjoyed it. Bibimbap was pretty good except the sauce wasn't spicy enough either. 
There was also of course the usual and customary side dishes, which were better than average. Great tasting kimchee! Loved the tofu with soy sauce and the crunchy cucumbers! We also ordered a bottle of soju and each had a good 3 shots to enjoy throughout our meal. 
For dessert we were served honeydew. I was hoping for the cold rice drink... :( Our bill was $65 but the feeling of yummy goodness in our tummies was priceless.
author: Amanda W.

description: I went back to Korean House few weeks ago, I had not gone for few years. They changed the menu, and added all you can eat. I feel the quality is not as good as before.
author: Caroline C.

description:
The food here is authentic, and is easier to order a wider selection of dishes than from Brothers. I still have never seen anyone barbecue here, and the inside is so clean and nice is suspect the would kick you out if you tried. 

The wait staff is excellent and accommodating, and we were served very promptly. The squid and kal-bi we ordered was good as was the chigae.  If you are around Japan town, its worth a stop, but there are plenty of better options of Korean food.
author: Geoffrey P.

description:
One of our favorite Korean places.   It's actually better for it's non-bbq fare ie. more advanced korean dishes such as the spicy stews, pa-jun, dok kuk.  The bbq kalbi is good but not it's specialty.  
The decor is nothing to speak of - you go for the food.
author: John P.

description:
Came here for a friends birthday, so there were about 10 of us at the restaurant.  We ended up ordering and trying just about every dish on the menu and drank their entire supply of BO beer.  The little appetizer dishes are by far my favorite.  You have the option of ordering the BBQ meat pre-cooked or you can cook it yourself at the table.  If you choose to cook it yourself, be sure you're not hitting the club right afterward because you'll reek like charcoals.

Two thumbs up.
Food was good, portions were generous, and service was above and beyond. The kimchi chigae is excellent here.
author: Angie L.

description:
So far, I've been coming back to Korea house for their Kalbee entree, Yu Kae Jung, and tofu soup. 

The kalbee beef is tender, juicy, a bit sweet, and pretty dang good! I've been there about at least five times in the past year and the food was consistently good.
The bulgogi beef (only tried once) looked good, not too fatty, but it was sliced super thin. I think it was overcooked the last time I had it. That dried it out too much. Haven't tried a second time.

The Yu Kae Jung (Spicy Beef soup) is usually always good, spicy (when you ask for more spicy), and the portions are good too.

The tofu soup is pretty good too.

Usually, these soups should be packed with flavor but a lot Korean place don't do these soups right. They might all look the same but having the right taste is hard to find.

Ambience is good, parking isn't bad (near japan center parking garage), and service is not bad either. The waiters seem to work hard.

This is still one of my favorite (not much to choose from) Korean joints. Also, I must say that I haven't tried Brothers Korean BBQ yet. I know everyone says that they're the best. I'll try it soon and compare.
author: Tim S.

description:
we didn't do the BBQ hoopla last night...... i'm not yet ready  to cough up the ~$35 per person meal, besides it's not payday yet...

so we were seated in a flash, since there were only one table occupied by a couple. 
we ordered a boiling hot kimchi jjigae which truly bitten me back with a tasteful, fermented kimchi! 

all my pores on my skin opened up and i sweated a little bit.

the bibimpap was appetizing and enjoyable. the beef was really tasty.

the 11 banchan was quite enjoyable, too.

though we didn't order any alcoholic beverages, we have at least gotten our cold water on their OB beer glasses!!

i will definitely coming back to have a feast on their BBQ meat...on my pay day of course!!!
author: Nelle A.

description: This was a great place for a large group.  We had a group of about 15 people for a birthday party and they seated us in the private section, which was nice and quiet with a very large table that everyone could fit at.  I particularly enjoyed the built in flame grills in the table, and it was a great group interaction cooking your own meat.  My only gripe is that it was pretty expensive even when the bill was split 15 ways, but it's hard to tell if it'd be cheaper if you came in smaller groups.
author: Rochelle F.

description: We ate dinner here last night. The Kalbi was delicious, and so was the marinated shrimp. All the banchan tasted good, and they were plentiful. The interior has a cozy,relaxed feel to it. Service was friendly and efficient. The prices are higher than other Korean restaurants in SF. Yes, we will come back.
author: Joe M.

description:
I love korean bbq.  I used to go to Brothers for the longest time, but they started to become very rude and extremely stingy with their sides.  They make you feel like you are asking for their first born child if you want more lettuce!  

A friend of mine told me about New Korea House, and I haven't been back to Brothers since.  The Kal Bai may not be as flavorful as theirs, but I am a much bigger fan of Bolgogi anyway, and everything else there is very good!  The staff is very friendly, but can become overwhelmed when there are too many people and not enough of them.  I would recommend going here instead of Brothers.
author: Sonia S.

description: So, three of my friends and I came here last night after strolling around J-town and taking sticky pictures. lol Yes, I said sticky pictures lol Anyhow ! Moving along, we ordered Bul Go Gi #1 , Kal Be #3, Sesame Salt Pork Belly  #8, and of course SOJU!!! ahaha We got the choice of either cooking the meat ourselves or having the kitchen cook it for us. We decided to just let the kitchen cook for us since we were lazy and didn't want to smell like korean food afterwards. ahaha we still smelled like korean food anyways lol Food came out pretty fast and the service was good. We got lots of side dishes. YuMmy~! Although my mommy makes it better of course lol Their food was pretty tasty as well =D The bill came to about ~ $90
author: Trina M.

description: We wanted to go to Korea House in Japan Town for our late lunch.  The place was not busy like before, got the menu and tea and waited for 15' still nobody took the order so we left.  We walked down the street and saw this place New Korea House and decided to give it a try.  Of course quiet too, we were seated right away, and this time took the lady much faster to take our order. The menu looked exactly the same like the other place that we just left, I think this establishment might have purchased the other restaurant.  Anyway, we ordered so much food for the two of us, kalbi, chicken, spicy calamari, soon tofu soup.  All food came out pretty fast and we started bbq-ing.  Service was not the greatest, I don't think the server didn't care enough for the customer.  The food just did not taste right.  My husband and I were so disappointed, we definitely will not go back there!
author: Pikachu P.

description: Sick and visiting S.F., we ordered takeout from here and were surprised to find that it's actually in Japantown. Luckily it wasn't too far from our hotel and while I wasn't expecting much, I was surprised to find that even in my sick stupor I could taste the wonderful sweet, garlicky sauce on the bbq meat and the spicy healing warmth of the broth from the soup. I was in heaven, then peacefully passed out from the Nyquil shortly thereafter.
author: Hannah J.

description:
decor was decent and the service was very nice.......BUT..... how do you go to a korean place that serves bbq and not have cha-dol?  other wise they would have all 5 stars.  
i must say though, the hea jang gook was very good......(key to an upset stomach due to way too much alcohol).
i would take my parents there.
author: junie k.

description: Just went here again, I have to say, they give you an amazing amount of kimchi, which has bumped my rating up a star.
author: Kelly L.

description: We had the BBQ Pork and the Short Rib Stew.  The Portion of the BBQ Pork was smaller then I'm use to and more expensive then the average Korean BBQ places I've been.  The Short Rib stew was just Short Ribs and minimal cabbage and noodles, it was mostly un-flavored broth.  We didn't eat it and didn't like it.  When we told the staff they didn't care at all.  This place is expensive and flavorless, very lazy outcome from whoever the chef was.  The staff wasn't that friendly either.  I will not be back.
author: Michele G.

description: The meal started off good with a good variety of small plates. Why a 1 star rating? I ordered a beef noodle soup dish and BIT INTO a "DO NOT EAT, DO NOT INGEST, HIGHLY POISONOUS, SKULLS AND CROSSBONES, KILL YO ASS" packet that one would find in MSG laden asian snacks. The hot soup must've cooked the packet a bit because it was rock hard and looked like it was about to burst. I'm guessing they just dumped the entire bag of instant soup mix in, poison and all. I informed the waitress and she was apologetic and returned to the kitchen to get me a new order, I'm assuming from the same broth batch as the first...She was nice enough to leave the tainted bowl on the table to show she wasn't just fishing out the POISON PACKET, but c'mon. When the bill came, the $12.95 for the POISON soup was still on there. Really, New Korea? F you...
author: Peter H.

description: I was super excited about having korean food with my friend who I haven't seen in awhile. We decided on New Korea House, which was actually really close and on the same street as the original Korea House. There were so many different side platters but none of them were very impressive. The food was not very memorable either, seeing how I can't seem to remember what we had that night. Will have to keep looking for another korean restaurant option in the area.
author: Angela S.

description:
The FIRST Korean place I came with a NON CHINESE FELLA, in FACT, he was a white dude. Anyhow, I think I found a decent Korean place that marinates their galbi with fine perfection. Their bahnchan (sidedishes) needs a bit of work, but their baechookimchi (cabbage kimchi) hit the spot. service was a bit spotty. Paying $120, excluding tax for 6 servings??? *oink oink* But given that we WERE in SF... one thing I DID notice was that they were a bit slow in cleaning up their tables after their customers left.  

-1 for price and snail service. Like seriously SLOW SLOW SLOW.

Sadly, it was not enough to feed me, plus 10 more. You can never get enough galbi in your stomach.

i'm feeling a bit crabby because i'm still hungry for more.. meow!
author: Jennifer S.

description: People look at me when I say that I love Korean BBQ!  They don't know the half of it.   The concept of getting to grill your own meat at the table just rocks my world.   The meat is fresh and thinly cut.   Go hungry and with no less than 4 people, because you will get about 1 - 2 pounds of perfectly marinated flesh to grill and about 12 little portion plates with raw garlic, kimchi, and other pickled goodness.   My teen son gets a kick of playing cook at the table.   Helps that he can wield the cooking chopsticks like a pro.   Don't recommend this place if you have little kids (5 and under).  The grill is right on the table and little hands are opt to get burned.
author: Diana D.

description: there are two New Korea House around the area, both of them are so so. The food is just OK, not any sup rice. I won't be there again, I can find dozen restaurant that cheaper and better tasting than here.
author: Carol X.

description: My bonafide Korean uncle, liked the food. He said it was good with "clean" clean panchan ("side dishes"). A little overpriced, but I think being in Japantown and their decor, they are going for a slightly more affluent crowd. I'd go Brothers I on Geary, Han Il Kwan (Balboa 19th), or My Tofu House before I would go back here though. Just not a good value compared to other choices nearby.
author: Sun K.

description: After spending a summer in Ulsan, South Korea, I developed quite a fondness for bulgogi, kalbi, bibimbap, and the like. I came back to SF in search of some good Korean grub. People sent me to Brother's on Geary, but it wasn't the same. It was decent, but it wasn't reminiscent of the summer of '99. I'd almost given up when my friend Alex took me to this place on Post St. For a brief moment I was transported back to the town of Ulsan and the flavors of true Korean cuisine. Just like the true test of a good Mexican joint is its salsa, the test of a good Korean restaurant is its kimchi and sides. Order up, kids. And don't be afraid to cook your own meat!
author: Marie M.

description: This place was okay. I was impressed by the decor. It had a lot of Asian (Korean, maybe I'm not really sure if it was) relics in the hallway. Food was average. I have to admit the Kim Chee was excellent. And Yes, I noticed service was a tad bit slow. Although, I only notice one person really working. Seemed over price though. For six we paid $150. I had better at an all you can eat type of Korean BBQ and it cost less too. Don't think I would be going back to this place any time soon. That and the fact the waiter sneezed twice before handing out the desert! He didn't even wash his hands! yuck and gross factor x 10. by the way, i did pass on that dessert!
author: Judy P.

description:
i actually like this place better than the old korea house..
they are open pretty early.. 
so you can grab a traditional korean breakfast before you start your day..
mind you.. they have a limited menu in the morning..

i think she was the owners wife?
maybe?
but she was reallly nice.. constantly refilled our side dishes and then gave my sister some soup base that they use to make the soon doobu stew.. and taught us how to make it at home.. telling us she NEVER gives out the recipe.. but for us she'll make an exception :D

in conclusion..
the food is pretty good..
pretty much the same deal as old korea house..

finally.. a korean restaurant i'm not ashamed of
author: monica c.

description:
My ex-girlfriend was Korean and she inspired me with a love for Korean food. (Thank you even though you hate me, jk, no really)

I have gone to New Korea House, probably 5 times since I have moved here.  (Almost a year woooo!) Every time the food has been delicious.  

I usually order the Bi Bim Bap Dolsut.  Make sure its Dolsut!! This means it comes in a stone bowl, sizzling hot, it is SO good.

The first time I was here it was for lunch, and let me stress that the lunch prices are about half to 2/3 less than the dinner prices.  All the other times were for dinner.  I have even taken a few Korean friends here and they say its pretty good.  Now to American taste buds, when someone from the home country of the restaurant says the food is pretty good, to us that means its REALLY FUCKING GOOD. 

However, I would recommend their lunch because of this:

Lunch for two ran me about $30 with drinks.

Dinner (same plates as the above lunch) for two ran me about $70 with similar drinks.

You decide.
author: Adam C.

description:
FINALLY!!! a korean place where the food doesn't taste like lumps of msg went in it. this place is the spot for korean bbq..it actually has a self serve grill like down in ktown in la.

the servers are like your moms, generous and slightly flighty, which i think is quite adorable.

i always come here after a night of drinking..get the gook bap (soup broth with cabbage and sprouts with a sprinkling  of red pepper). these days its the only thing i crave in the mornings.

i'd come here any day when im in the city!! pure gem!!
author: Carol P.

description: Came here for a late lunch, and luckily they were open.  The woman working was nice, although there was only one person working for all the tables.  Granted, it was a late afternoon and they probably didn't expect as many people that were in there.  The food was good, and I had no complaints about the bibimbap.  The waitress offered to mix ours, but we said not to because there were other people in the restaurant who needed attention.  We ordered the pancake as well, but it wasn't too great because of the amount of greens onions(?) in it.  I loved their side dishes, but probably won't go back.  I recommend this place though to try, you might like it yourself.
author: Derrick D.

description:
During a family vacation to Yosemite National Park, my wife and I devoted the last 2 days to be spent sight seeing San Francisco. Now, we are from New England, and were not familiar with the korean restuarants in the area, however came across many during our visit to Japan town. We happen to choose this one in particular, and are now grateful of our choice. 

The service here truly demonstrated a rare level of hospitality which is uncommon among middle-priced casual restaurants. I have to admit that this is partially due to the fact that it was lunch time, and only one other person was there at the time. The waitress was wonderful, and gave us free rice "suk-cho" at the end to drink.

The food is above average, and featured many side dishes, such as tofu in soy sauce, yellow radish, "muuk" rice, kim-chi along with many other. As for the main dishes, we had the jajang myun, and the bibimpab. The portions are huge, along with the fact that we received a complimentary order of chicken bbq from our waitress. 

The prices are reasonable, although many of the appetizers such as the tang-syuk are more expensive than the entrees. I recommend these as main courses in and of themselves.

With great service, healthy and delicious food, and reasonable prices, how can I not write anything other than how wonderful this restaurant is?
author: Roy M.

description: My friend had told me about how awesome the bibimbap was at this restaurant, but then warned me that there were two restaurants right next to each other with very similar names.  Unfortunately, I went to the wrong one! The bibimbap was alright, nothing to write home about.  Also, they didn't provide that many banchan. Definitely better Korean places out there for much less.
author: Joy C.

description: Hella delicious tofu/fish stew action with a million tiny pickled veg dishes on the side? Yes please!
author: Jess F.

description:
reliable korean bbq, but still not as good as my favorite place han il quan.  we had:

-tofu soup (too salty)
-kal bi (very flavorful but some bits were slightly tough and required extensive chewing)
-bulbogi (pretty good, but nothing memorable)

the place is clean, the service is very good, and it's true, you don't really smell when you leave.  a meat dish will set you back $18-19 so it is not the best deal in SF, but from what i hear sf korean bbq doesn't come cheap!

i felt that their selection of panchan (the little snackie dishes) was fairly good quality (bean sprouts & pickled veggies especially) but lackluster and not anything special.

i think it's worth coming back again to try the bi bim bap mostly because it's closer proximity to my house than han il kwan.
author: Josie M.

description: Of all the korean restaurants, you smell the least after leaving this one.  Thats key.
author: Wakako U.

description: It's hard to compete with my personal fav (Han Il Kwan), but this place holds it own.  The tofu soups are hearty and full of flavor unlike other Korean restaurants and they'll hook it up with a couple of eggs if you ask.  My lady is picky about her tofu soups and this is her new go to place.  The BBQ meats were a little on the salty side.  Just balance it out with some of the 10 different veggies dishes you get.  Good service and a quick turn around on your food after you order.
author: Jason A.

description:
so much food.
so gooood.
soooo full.

I've never been to the original Korean House, but my dining companions claim that the food at New Korea House (only two doors down) is better than the food at the Original, however the interior of the original is prettier.  ..  

There were 7 of us and we ordered the standards: Bol Go Gi (thinly sliced bbq), Kal Bi (meat on the ribs), and Pi Bim Bap (which you must order DolSot to come in the simmering stone bowl), the Jap Chae, some squid and the traditional fried cod.  

All the entres were super fresh, delicious awesomeness and I was fully satisfied.  Both the BolGoGi and KalBi were particularly flavorful.

The tons of little starter plates were pretty good, but they mainly consisted of different kinds of Kim Chee and tofu, and there wasn't as much variety as I recall in other spots (i.e. no medichee, my favorite little spicy anchovies) 

I will forever have a special place in my heart for PiBimBap: it was the first meal I ever ate in Korea.  When the Korean women I was with informed me with great pride that when Michael Jackson visited Korea his favorite dish was BibimBap I remember thinking to myself: 
"me too, me tooooo!"

Unfortunately Korean food is and always will be pricey.  I have resigned myself to that sad fact and I always anticipate the large bill at the end of the meal.  Aside from that I walked away full and happy.
author: Shayna N.

description: This is a great place for a lot of food, for not a lot of money.  I came here with a group of friends for dinner and left full and satisfied.  The staff was very nice and they were quite accommodating because we were late for our reservation.  We were super hungry and placed our order as soon as possible.  Of course, we're little piggies and ordered a ton of food.  We had kal bi, bul go gi and daegi bul go gi, mushrooms (all for the grill), plus bi bim bap, mandu and some other dishes too.  As soon as the order was sent to the kitchen, we were bombarded by the usual side dishes of kimchee, fish cakes, bean sprouts, etc.  Wow, our table was full.  Then all the meats arrived with lettuce and rice.  Eeeps, no more room on the table!!  It was great!  The food was very flavorful and delicious.  We were all sooooo full at the end.  This is a great interactive meal, good for groups or a couple.
author: Kristina D.

description: I need to speak Korean so I can manage to get service on my own.  The owner was nice enough to offer mushrooms and a tofu soup.  I just like how we can all get totally wasted and stuffed for a reasonable price.
author: Jen C.

description: Definitely a more authentic ethnic experience. But in this day and age, where they are using Atkins as an excuse to screw you out of table bread, It's nice to go to a place that puts almost 50 types of little snacks on your table before they give you raw meat to sizzle at your own table. A plus for smokers I bet.   Fun with friends that can handle not having hard alcohol on their beer and wine permit.
author: Jean W.

description:
eeps.  20$ for a small serving of bulgogi?  i guess this is the norm for higher class korean food, but it's a little steep for me.  i got the clear potato noodle & beef dish.  the beef was boiled, i think, and not very tasty.  There were also too much cabbage in it.
the bulgogi was good, but it came with this huge thing of cabbage too.  
and like all korean resturants, they came out with 20 different little items in the beginning for you, but i think this place makes those little dishes better than a lot of places.  they also served a plate of weird tasting lettuce that i've never seen before.

anyways, this place is alright.  i might go here again.
author: H. L.

description: Good banchan here.  But you technically pay for it.  This is definitely a typical expensive korean place with good food but where you can find as good or better and cheaper in richmond/sunset.
author: Charles C.

description: I was planning to go to Korea House and didn't look closely at the restaurant name and ended up at this place (they're just a few doors away from each other).  Overall I thought it was good but expensive.  I had a soon dubu craving and it'll cost you around $12 here (as opposed to $8 if you go go the restaurants in Santa Clara).  For some reason they didn't have the mushroom soon dubu so I ended up with a vegetable soon dubu.  They didn't ask if I wanted it mild, medium or spicy and I ended up getting the spicy version.  We also ordered Jap Chae (also about $12).  If I come back it would be to try the lunch menu which is hopefully less expensive.
author: Cindy B.

description: Great food.  Nice atmosphere.  Really, really nice bathrooms, which is one of the best ways to evaluate an establishment.  Service was very courteous, rather than the traditional gruff wait-until-I'm-ready-for-you prevalent in most Korean restaurants.  Portions a little small although quality is good.  Pricey, but I guess you're paying for ambiance.  Parking's awful, which is to be expected.  Stop by Treasure Island on the way back to the East Bay's a nice way to end the evening w/ friends.
author: kevan h.

description: We had a great dinner here last night. We had the Bul Go Gi, the Short Ribs, the stone bowl BiBimBap, and some spicy pork tofu stew. Delicious, fun and a change of pace! Great for grabbing dinner before a movie at the Kabuki.
author: Sarah R.

description: Tasty dolsut bibimbap. Lots of panchan even just for a solo diner. Friendly service. Would go to again.
author: Brian W.

description: This is an easy place to enter with a friend and get good kalbi and maybe 7 different tiny plates of okazus. Pretty filling and the tour companies even have their busloads of  Korean tourists of San Francisco have lunch here.
author: miriam b.

description: Korea House is our regular Korean restaurant, our "dangoljib."  My wife and I usually go on weekday evenings so the place is very quiet.  Sometimes we're the only people there.  I strongly, highly recommend the "gukbab" soup, which isn't on the menu but is hands down their most delicious selection.  There's even a big blown up article on the wall showing South Korean President Noh Moo-hyun saying "the gukbab is really delicious!" (all in Korean of course).  Aside from the gukbab, the tofu stew (soondubu jigae) and soybean stew (doenjang jigae) are also really good.  The side dishes (banchan) here are excellent.  I've tried the BBQ beef once and it was serviceable, but for Korean BBQ you should head to the Richmond.
author: Ray C.

description:
There were four of us, but I don't think any of us were really thrilled. My wife and I both thought it was average.

The bulgogi (beef dish) was a bit smaller than most Korean places I've been to. The side dishes were fine, and that's one of the most important things.

The jap chae (clear noodle dish with meat and veggies) was a bit bland.
