The yuk eh jang (I totally butchered the spelling; sorry!) (hot and spicy beef soup) was probably the highlight of the meal. Oh, and the bib bim bap was also pretty good.

I was hoping for a better experience, because I'd heard good things about this place. I mean, it's not a bad Korean place. It's just average, at least when we went. I may come back and see if my first meal was just a random fluke. If I do, I'll update my review.
author: William S.

description: Enjoyed this place.  What it's lacking in atmosphere and decor it makes up for in authenticity and good food.  The little sample dishes they bring out at the beginning of the meal are interesting in every way.  Some are really good, like the tofu strips and the mung bean dish, though the kim chi was a little tough.  The sizzling pot is the way to go for an entree!  I've had the seafood one and the veggie one, and I have to say the veggie was awesome!  It had lots of vegetables that were crisp and delish, and the tofu was perfectly done.  The seafood was ok, but a little chewy.
author: Scott C.

description: Any place that gives you a teaspoon for a big soup/stew is not *great*.
author: Christine K.

description: They have the best BiBimBap ever! And you should go during lunch because it's cheaper! I believe just the regular BiBimBap is just $8.95. And for dinnertime it's around $14. Not too exact, but it's great going in for lunch! And it's very clean, and not crowded at all.
author: Amy X.

description:
Below average Korean BBQ place. 
The meat was mediocre; the side dishes were OK, but they charge an outragous $7 for lettuce and doenjang. 
It's way to expensive. We ended up dropping $140 for 4 people. That's just not right.
There are way to many other Korean places in and around SF so I will likely never go back.
author: Jesper B.

description: DELISH! Thanks to Connie and some wonderful friends at yelp, I found a new delicious place to cook my own meat. MMMMMM
author: Jewel N.

description:
yum-o! although there are no weekend lunch specials offered, korea house is still a great place for delicious soon dubu with LOTS of banchan (side dishes)! the fact that they have fresh nokdumuk (my favorite of the side dishes... basically a white jelly thing made of mung beans and flavored with seasoned soy sauce and green onions) and is generous about replenishing any empty dishes of banchan is enough to keep me coming!

i'm not sure what to make of the fact that every time i come here, it's always pretty empty... but hey, if i can get the food i want without having to fight others for a table, that's fine by me!
author: Andrey C.

description:
Horrible Kalbi and Dol-Sot BiBimBap 

for expensive price. Don't go here.

Yuck....
author: Tevantheesa L.

description: Only my second experience eating at a Korean restaurant and I loved it! The kalbi and the bi bim bop were great. My fav part of the meal though were all the little kimchi dishes that they serve you as soon as you sit down. So yummy! I'll def be back!
author: Lauren Y.

description: I am very disappointed with the barbecue. I strolled in here hoping to get the best bbq ever ( the one that even beats koryo over in oakland). I was excited because of the great reviews on yelp and yes,after dinner, i went out with a pouty mouth, like a little girl sulking because someone stole her candy bar. We ordered the bulgogi and it was just not great. It was hard , granted that it might be that we cooked it too long, but it was still not one of those meats that just made you feel like you're in bbq heaven. Maybe its the marinate, maybe its the type of meat, who knows? The only thing that we like were the marinated mushrooms. Now, those are yummy!
author: Iche S.

description: Korea House is one of those places with a grill in the middle of the table where you can cook your own food. It's fun for a group -- and tasty, too (especially the spicy pork). But the service just plain sucks -- I had to hunt down the waiter (as in get up out of my chair and poke around the restaurant) to order, get more drinks and for the check. Not cool.
author: Katie B.

description: This isnt a BCD but its good.  Even for a fatty like me I got full.   Lots of BBQ and lots of sides.  Don't forget to bring a wad of cash.
author: Fatty A.

description: This is very good Korean food in an interesting, if a bit closed in, space on Post St. The Dolsat Bee Bim Bop is everything I dream of when not near a Korean restaurant. Recommend it for quick service at lunchtime.
author: Jim G.

description: I give this place 3 stars because of the selection of side dishes. Other than that, I don't think they marinated their kalbi enough. I know my Korean food because it's my favorite cuisine. Nothing beats LA K-town.
author: Elaine L.

description: I'm a little biased since my friend's aunt owns this place, but it was good.  The Korea House, which is just next door has the same owner.  A little pricey if you were to take a quick glance over the menu ($15-20 / dish), but you have to remember that these Korean BBQ places come with tons of refillable little side dishes.  Food quality was excellent, you can either BBQ at your own table, or if you are just there for the food then they'll do it for you!
author: Mark D.

description: This place has consistently good food.  I always order Beef Bul Go Gi.  For about $25 two can eat like kings!  Also, I've never had to wait for a table.  It's great.
author: Jeanne C.

description: WOW. YUM. The rib BBQ meat was so tender and the marinade perfectly balanced. The side dishes are generous and tasty. You can grill your meat at the table and the place is clean. They did forget to give me my lettuce for wrapping my BBQ, but they gave it to me right away when I mentioned it. The soup that comes with the BBQ is made from beef bone and you can taste the freshness. I will def go back and bring friends with me.
author: lisa s.

description: $20 AYCE korean BBQ in a city that doesn't have many of them is ok, but not great.  service was the best thing because the servers tried their best to make sure to get us anything we asked for.  also theres a doorbell you can push to ask for them which they always responded too.  the meats are nothing great tho and could be better.  the fans overhead don't really work so the place is smoky as hec, but thats understandable.  not many choices for side dishes, and side orders like tofu soup are horrible.  but for the city where there aren't many AYCE bbqs, this place is worth 3 stars.
author: paul k.

description: Went there on a weekday, service and food were decent, and bi bim bap was good, but I'm not that experienced in Korean cuisine.  For BBQ, I think I prefer Brothers.
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description: If you are looking for naeng myun on a hot day, this is not the place to go. The yuk-soo is just water.  The beef is tasteless, tough, and the wrong cut.
author: Jane L.

description: I went there with an absurdly large group (25+). After the first rocky 30 minutes it took to order and get beer, I thought they did a good job with the service. Our table was last to get our food, so the waiter brought us another round of kimchi. As a vegetarian, I skipped the BBQ and had Bi Bim Bap my favorite way (no beef, stone bowl, and raw egg) and thought it was great, very flavorful. The other vegetarian options were a tofu mushroom dish and tofu stew with bean paste. Meat eaters enjoyed the BBQ, but it does get pretty beef-smoky when everyone is grilling.
author: Amy E.

description: This restaurant is a *little* pricey, but my gf has told me it is the best Korean she has tasted in San Fran -- closest to what she grew up with at home.  So, now, this restaurant is in the regular rotation.  No arguments from me -- I can grab a nice bite and then go next door to super7 to see what's new.
author: Tim G.

description: Plentiful on the free side dishes, but still relatively pricey for simple korean BBQ.  Expect to pay $15-20 per dish, before tax & tip.  The barbeque ribs I had were tasty and the service was quick and friendly but overall I'd rate the restaurant average.  The background music sounded like a going-through-a-breakup mix cd, but that may have just been a one-time thing.  If I was in the area again, I'd probably try one of the other Korean restaurants in the vicinity before coming back here.
author: M P.

description: For the last 15 years or so I've made it a point to have lunch here every time I attend a meeting at the Miyako Hotel directly across the street. This was the first Korean food I've ever had, and still among the very best. And the food is so reasonably priced that it's difficult to get your lunch bill up to the $15 minimum for credit card payment.
author: Bob F.

description: Pretty substandard Korean fare for me. If you're looking for Korean in J-Town, Seoul Garden or Dubu would be a better choice. The Dol Sot Bi Bim Bab was good in that the rice browned in less time than most places, but the Kim Chee Jige had little in the way of Kimchee or flavor. Panchan was good, as was service. But...I consider jige the standard of a Korean restaurant, so I can't go higher than three stars, especially given the above competition is just a block away.
author: Johnny O.

description: My stomach is still screaming "Too much food!" after eating at Korea House.  P and I were starving and like excited kids, our eyes were bigger than our tummies and we ordered a little too much.  We ordered kalbi (excellently marinated), haemool pajun (chock full of squid, shrimp, mussels, and oysters), and the eel stone pot (I really like this variation).  And the panchan that came with our orders was too much -- soup, kimchi pajun, pickled napa, pickled radish, kimchi napa, kimchi cucumbers, kimchi radish, radish, bean sprouts, fish cake, black beans, and that jelly thing.  You bet we had plenty of leftovers.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Much like Korea House with the wooden double doors, this is just as good.  Ive eaten here twice, the first time being with my Korean language classmates from up the street at IIC.  The soup, bbq and all the panchan side dishes were good.  This is one of those places that give u that small personalized pancake which Ive always liked.  You cant go wrong with either place.  I didn't pay either time here so you may want to check out the prices first, but food is good.
author: Gilbert C.

description: it's okay.  kind of pricey for the quality you get.  i think it's better than seoul garden though.
author: Young P.

description: I was disappointed.  It was a family dinner, took my Mom who generally loves Korean food, but this was so-so.  Not the best we've had....probably more like the worst.   It was over priced for the portions given.  I won't be coming back.  There are too many other great Korean places to eat at.
author: Marie E.

description: Great Korean food. We had the pork, the kal-bi, and the prawns. All of them were great, especially the pork. Don't bother with the fixed price menus in the front of the menu. They're good, but it's a ton of food. When you order anything here, you get the works anyways. Also had the crab soup and it was just OK. Super hot and spicy and too much work eating the bits of crab in the shell. Overall, a good restaurant and a great deal.
author: Pierre K.

description: one of my favorite korean restaurants... i love the little plates of appetizers and can always ask for more... i love their chap jae, bulgogi, kalbi, bbq shrimp. I have also been to brothers but prefer this place more. ive been going here since i was a little kid. When i am in japan town this is usually the restaurant i go too.. i know me going to a korean restaurant first in japan town but hey ill take it haha. i also go to japanese restaurants in japan town... gotta love that okonomiyaki and potato croquette
author: Anthony V.

description:
we had the bul-go-gi and i was truly disappointed.  the meat didn't seem very marinated and they don't really give you very much.  the pan-chan was ok but nothing to write home about.  

and we were one out of probably 3 tables there and the servers seemed to be asleep or something.

if you're going to pay that much, you could do a lot better.

i was t
author: michelle k.

description: Restaurant is located in near by Japan town. We were there for dinner and  don't quite remember what we ordered but I do remember that we order 2 dishes of bulgogi for $20 each (thats $40). I am Korean so I should know how bulgogi is supposed to be served; on a hot sizzling. plate but instead it was on a bowl like bulgogi soup. I just can't believe so many people are give 4 and 5 stars, am I missing something?
author: Peter K.

description:
I am a Korean born American and I've been going to New Korea House for over 30 years.  I've tried a lot of Korean places in the Bay Area, but this one is the only one I kept going back to.  Their food is authentic, fresh and most of all tasty!  For all the food you get, I think this place is a bargain.
The Korea House next door  is owned by the same owner. But I think the chef at the New Korea House is ten times better in creating tastier dishes.  Only draw back to this place is that your clothes smell like BBQ for days after.  So my suggestion is don't wear clothes you have to dry clean to this place.
author: meehyun k.

description: I was visiting from LA, craving korean food, so my friend recommended New Korea House. I must say, I was very pleased with the service. The owner was working that night and she was extremely friendly, brought out special dishes that weren't on the menu including;  kimchee jun(korean pancake with kimchee) and BBQ mushrooms for my vegetarian friend. It was a little empty that night so initially we were considering not going in, but I really wanted korean food so I was really glad that we went inside. My favorite dish was bim bim bap and BBQ pork. We stayed there for a couple of hours, drank 5 bottles of soju and came out very satisfied. I think the food is not as good as down in LA but better than NY. I definitely  recommend to people that crave good Korean food in San Francisco.
author: annie k.

description: The food is good here, but that doesn't make up for the 2 times when I went at 10:15 pm only to find out that they are closing when the sign reads open until 11 pm.  The first time was ok, but tonight, it happened again. if you are going to close, turn off the freaking OPEN sign. Don't make starving people climb up the stairs to find out you are close....that's not cool, by the way, we ended up at Brothers on Geary, much better food and service...
author: L K.

description: I'm not a huge fan of Korean...even though I'm Asian.  4 of us went on a weekday, and had a lovely Korean-style meal.  Very tasty marinated meats, and soooo much food.  I love the variety.  Different explosive tastes w/ every bite.  You're not here for the decor, you're here for food.  The staff is polite, responsive, and non-intrusive.  Grilling your own meats makes this a fun place for a dinner w/ friends.  Your food stays hot, and you can have a long meal w/ great conversations.
author: K N.

description: Food was pretty good, atmosphere so so.  Final bill $110 for 5 people with no alcohol and one dish per person - not the cheapest but not too bad.  Of course some people think that cooking your own food entitles you to a discount.
author: Aleksandr O.

description: So many dishes and generous portions! The staff is rather friendly and the atmosphere is small and intimate. I found the built-in grills on the table to be pretty neat. I like how they bring out tons of complimentary appetizers. Although I didn't know what any of them were, it was fun trying them out. The Kimchi Chigae we ordered was too salty, but our other dishes were fine. Although we had lots of boxes to take home, we were ridiculously full. I felt bad for the person sitting next to me on the muni, because my clothes fumed of Korean food, ha.
author: Katie N.

description: i really like the tofu soup here and the short rib soup. its really tasty and the bbq beef is good too. the small dishes you get in the beginning are good and the tea with the bits of rice in it was refreshing. the only bad thing about this place is its expensive. i think the food it great but the pricing is high. thats why i dont go very often anymore. you can get good korean food at lots of other places that are much cheaper than here.
author: chloe w.

description:
*** I think I've found my new Korean spot ***

The sun was slow to set and made the evening air pleasant. Quick steps up the stairs. Brief pause as we waited to be seated. Menus opened just for the sake of it... we three already knew why we were here. 

I had been there two other times: once in high school, I took my foreign exchange student friends there (won't go into the mischief we caused that night!) and the last time with a date who hadn't tried Korean food previously. Wasn't that impressed so I continued to go to my usual, Han Il Kwan. But tonight was different.

We came to Korea House for their samgyeupsal, only discovering they served it once I read Miriam W.'s review. Lot of pressure since my two accomplices depended on me for the Korean hook-up. We were not disappointed. 

The deets: 2 orders only (cannot order just one). Cook at your own table (can control how crispy you want it... ya ya, it's a gas grill, suck it up). Be careful of cross contamination (they'll give you metal tongs to place on the grill, but once you're ready to eat, use your chopsticks to plate). Served with a sweet dipping sauce. I ate it dipped in the sauce and then wrapped in a lettuce leaf with a bit of kimchi or hot paste).

Banchan:
All the little sides were great except for the gak du gi (spicy pickled radish... overripe which made it mushy). Kim chi was perfect. A few sides were different from the usual array one gets at a Korean restaurant: slightly sweet soy radish, soy sauce potatoes, green leaf lettuce salad with slightly spicy vinegar-sesame dressing).

Customer service was excellent (though I will mention there were only two other tables when we first walked in):
We originally tried to order one samgyeupsal, one ojingo bokum (spicy sauteed calamari), and one kimchi chi gae (spicy kimchi stew/soup) but once we found out we had to order two samgyeupsals to get it, we decided to pass on the calamari. The lady took our order and went back to the kitchen. After a few seconds, she came back and said she'd throw in the kimchi chi gae for free if we still wanted the calamari... of course, we took her offer.  Much better than the fried fish we'd get for free from Han Il Kwan. And when we asked for refills on the sides, we got them no problem and with a smile. Only gripe was every other table got green peppers (not too spicy) to eat with the hot chili paste and we didn't get any! Guess I could have asked but only realized this once we were almost done. Also, helps if you speak Korean, but not necessary.

Price: 
Think we each put in $22  for dinner and tip. I think it's a great value and could have probably fed a 4th person with the amount of food we had left over (all the samgyeupsal was gone, though).

Meal ended with cantaloupe slices, rather than the sickly sweet shik-kai (my friend loves to call it "dirty rice water"). 

Will definitely go back to try their nang myon (cold noodle in a vinegary broth... perfect for hot summer days) and dol sot bi bim bap (hot stone bowl bi bim bap).
author: B W.

description: Yummy. This place is some good azz Korean BBQ eats, yo. The rib-eye was fresh and delicious, the marinated pork was so fricking good I almost shit myself. And the kim chi and other assorted pickled yummies were all I could hope for. I took my man there for his first Korean BBQ experience. He was stoked. I was so excited to be sharing something new with him because we cherish the firsts that we have together. He's a man's man, he likes meat, he likes grills, and he likes spicy...so I knew he would L-O-V-E Korean BBQ. The place was recomended by Joey at my favorite neighborhood bar, 821 (see review). Joey is the shit and after we helped him clear up some space in his Treo so his internet would run faster he was all smiles, showing us pics of his daughter, giving us happy hours prices...I figured he would he would have a good idea of where to go for KBBQ too. I do have to say that the prices were a little higher than the Korean BBQ places I had been to in the Avenues, but it was a nicer setting and a perfect date place. I would recomend this place to people who want to have the fun experience of Korean BBQ while also taking taking their parents, wife/husband, or girlfriend/boyfriend to a nice night out. Over all a great experience...
author: Robin B.

description: Went for late lunch and not a lot of people were there. Excellent service and lady kept refilling the tapas ! cheap!
author: lucy l.

description: First of all, the service was fantastic.  Like a lot of other korean restaurants, they gave us free stuff like the tofu stew and a plate of meaty mushrooms for grilling.  There was six of us and we only ordered three plates of raw meat (short ribs, pork, and beef) and a rice in claypot.  The large round table was filled with side dishes.  The side dishes tasted ok, none of them really stood out.  They also use gas grills and think that made a difference in the taste of the meat.  It was all good, but it wasn't fabulous.  So I'd have to give them 3 stars.
author: Katniss B.

description: go here for the lunch specials! it's under $10 a piece and tasty as well. the kalbi is well off the bone.hehe and the be-bim-bop will get you hoppin, they missed one star cause they forgot my sake. but it was busy and the waitress is at least 70. so i forgive her
author: brooke h.

description:
New Korea House, being in Japantown, is certainly one restaurant not to miss.  Trips to J-town are always fun and with the interest in seeing "New People", the J-Pop clothing/accessory store/cafe, walking within a block of it to the restaurant was very convenient.  

For a Sunday dinner, the restaurant was about 30% occupied.  We browsed through the menu even though we were fairly certain we wanted some kalbi.  The selections of soups and appetizers were quite large.  We ordered one of their Dinner Specials -- Dinner B, which consisted of 2 orders of kalbi, gul jun (large shell oysters dipped in egg batter), Jap chae, Man du guk (meat dumpling soup) and pan fried tofu.  The dishes were served within 7 minutes of ordering! 
 
We were enjoying the ban chan so much and before we knew it, the oysters were served on the table.  The oysters were large (as the menu claimed) and prepared with just a minimal amount of batter so as not to take away from the taste of the fresh oysters.  They were served on the same platter with the tofu.  The soup was served hot with 2 large pieces of dumplings in each bowl!  There wasn't much of a conversation at the table as we were busy satiating ourselves!  By the time we got to the kalbi, we were fairly full but we savored every bit of those pieces --- slightly spicy and slightly sweet, tender and definitely palatable!  The servings were very generous!!!  The restaurant was very quiet as may have been because it was a Sunday evening.  It felt as though we were dining by ourselves but were served well by the attentive waitress. Dinner for two totaled to $89, excluding tip & alcohol.
author: Mika S.

description: The best Korean BBQ in SF, hands down.  Fresh meat, great interior, good service, and reasonable prices.  Expect to pay $20-30 a head, and you will be stuffed!  The Kalbi is great here if you go definitely try it out.
author: Alex Y.

description: K-House is one of the better known,established joints in the city. Good to come with a large party-family styleee, taking over the front room overlooking Post St. Newbies are always in awe of the HUGE wooden door. Even better to go with novices so that you can do all the ordering...as the Galaga Kid does. She brings all the newbies and asks them what they want knowing that she'll get blank stares, shrugs and the occasional, "Um do they have like noodles an' stuff??" Duh!! Then Kid Galaga runs the show ordering Banchan, Bulgogi, Galbi, Japchae for the Spaghetti eaters that wouldn't know what to do w/ a plate-o Naenmyon, Yukgaejang, ..maybe an order of Man Du. Waitresses are running around bringing back trays to the bewildered. Galaga's hands fly in the air like little nunchucks for requests of extra Pap and pickled cucumber. Bottles of OB show up. I have to sneak in a Sundubu or Kimchijigae (bean curd spicy stew). Buuuuut after the hoe-down and "HEY! WHO ORDERED THE SUNDUBU??" while Galaga reviews the bill, ...everybody leaves with happy bellies.
author: Johnny C.

description: Korea House is in excellent location near the Japan Town on Post Street.  But the food quality did not match up the excellent location.  For example the Seafood mixed Tofu was okay but little flat to the flavor.  But where are the sea foods?  Well, further look at the dish you understand why.  There were tiny pieces of shrimps (i mean tiny) in the tofu soup along with some vegetables and there were few pieces of clam meat.  That is the justification to call this tofu dish seafood!  The clames tasted from frozen. I am paying $12.95 for this dish and I expect more sea food in this if you call it seafood item.  The quantity was larger than a small bowl.  There was no egg offered for this dish like most Korean restaurants would offer.  Either the chef was too stingy for one egg or the chef decides that I did not need it since I did not ask for one lousy egg.   Yes you get small dishes with this order.  But the dishes were not plain and cheaf and not very tasty.  two daikon (white radish) dishes: one sweet and vinegar daikon, one kimchi daikon.  We did not see any seaweeds, fried croakers, potatoes and etc.
author: Way L.

description: love this place for their bbq shortribs, bbq pork, bibimbop, pajon, dubu, and soups. esp for late night eats with a handful of good friends after a basketball game.. order some meat, a few bottles of beer with some kimchi on the side.. mmmm.. what could be better?!
author: tessie n.

description: we used to come here quite often. well it seems to have been going downhill in the past years, it has gone from being full at night to positively empty, the fish in the aquarium are declining in number too, the salad (so good last yr) is inedibly salty, but still this is where my loyalty is. i'm vegetarian so i grilled squid when everyone else grilled beef - the squid is quite good, doesn't combine as well with the side vegetables, but not a bad substitute. they give you us kimchi pancakes for free. they have a good dipping sauce if you ask for it. also the squid with hot sauce is great. you'll probably be one of the few diners here, but it does mean prompt service. 3 people for $60 is not bad at all. they have great HOT noodles (they look like worms, but are very resilient, in a good way).
author: Lijia X.

description: delicious!  we ate here last night.  lots of yummy food, very friendly people, extra speedy service (although we were there early - around 6:30 on a saturday).  a little pricey but you get a lot of food for your buck.
author: Liz S.

description: i didnt like this place too much b/c im soooooooo picky when it comes to korean food ~ the bulgogi was horrible- too dry & not even marinated~ the side soup they gave was alllll salt! and the side dishes were just okayyy... i give it 2 stars for their kalbi since it was pretty good. also, the service was decent..! basically, i wouldnt go back~ but it was worth a good try.
author: Pudgee W.

description: Thank you, Yelpers, for another great recommendation! I've always gone to Brother's but thought I'd check Yelp to see if there was a better place. I've grown tired of the poor quality meat, rude service, and overwhelming smoke at Brother's so I decided to give Korea House a try after reading the Yelp reviews and hearing that it's the favorite place of a Korean friend. They have a rather odd location in Japantown, which probably accounts for the fact that I had no problem getting a table without reservations at 6:30pm on a Saturday night. I ordered the Kal Bi BBQ. The meat was of fair quality (that's why only 4 stars), a few pieces were not edible due to being like rubber, but most of them were tasty and tender. The bone parts were undercooked and the meat near the bone was raw so I couldn't enjoy the flavor of crispy meat on bone. Note, I was eating solo, so the BBQ was prepared for me in the kitchen rather than self-cooked at the table. Why do they get 4 stars, you may be wondering? The service was friendly and efficient and the kim chi was the best I have ever had in my life!!! I'd go back again just for the kim chi. I was given the usual set of 10 or so kim chi dishes and they had the most incredible mouth-feel ... a bubbling euphoric feeling that came from the active fermentation of the bacteria in the kim chi. They were really alive, fresh, incredibly flavorful. I've tried a lot of Korean food over the years and this kim chi beats anything I've ever had, even in Korea.
author: Eater S.

description: whenever we opt for korean food on a weekday and don't feel like driving out to ohgane or seoul gomtang, we choose korea house.  it's never too crowded, we love the banchans (THE MOOK IS ALWAYS MINE...) and even if the kimchee jeegae is just ok, the meats taste like what they're supposed to taste like.  yes, it's expensive for what it really is, just standard good korean food, but when you're running low on options, you'll take what you can get.
author: Adela K.

description: This was truly one of the worst experiences I've had at a Korean restaurant.  My family and I (all Korean) went and the ban chan was terrible, the service completely indifferent and the soups awful. I've never just walked out but I was tempted. Would do a negative rating if possible.
author: Pamela Y.

description: really good korean food. the service was excellent. it was worth every penny. my friend and i ordered a soup and noodle dish and that really got us filled up.
author: Lynn P.

description: I visited here on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. The restaurant was relatively quiet. The service was excellent and the kimchee delicious. The main course was dolsat bibimbap and it was incredible. Prices a little high, but within reason. Yummy.
author: merle s.

description: Hadn't eaten much in the way of Korean food before trying Korea House. Good experience, turned me on to trying more. Pajon was very good, no.4 bibimbat also good, bulgogi good too. The busload of little white bowls with assorted pickled what-nots and spicy goodness sealed the deal. 4 people, well-fed and liquored for just over $100. Solid. Eat at Korea House.
author: Brandon F.

description: SUPER friendly staff. Not being Korean I wouldn't know how authentic Korean food would taste like, but it seems like it would definitely be close to it. I don't like spicy food, so I chose to have rib eye, kalbi, bul gol gi, marinated chicken barbeque dishes, which were fantastic and great to share. I love trying out the side dishes (the potato one is great, I asked for more, and they brought back lots of it). It's great to have lunch with friends in here, it's never busy when we're in here which is great! They served us complimentary pancakes (which I thought we were special, but it turns out everyone gets them, but they're super good). Soup is good, rice is cooked perfectly! When I'm craving Korean food, I always stop by! Prices are reasonable!
author: Lily L.

description: Good barbeque, good service, and not too crowded. The Kalbi is excellent - by far the best thing we had.  The kimchee is so fermented here it's practically carbonated. Overall I had a great dining experience.
author: foodbot c.

description:
In terms of decor and ambience, the New Korea House has a modest charm. Where the taste and quality of the food is concerned, however, New Korea House leaves much to be desired.  The kalbi and jigae dishes at New Korea House impart a taste that I associate with mass-produced food. The flavor is passable but far from distinctive.  

You can discern a great deal about a Korean restaurant by the variety and quality of its side dishes. On the plus side, NHK offers a variety of side dishes. Unfortunately, this abundance does not make up for their rather lackluster quality. The care taken in preparing dishes is invariably reflected in taste, and the NHK side dishes conform to this view. I would cite the fact that NHK serves its bean sprouts with the roots attached as one example. Since the norm in Korean cuisine is to detach the roots of each individual sprout, I was a bit turned off by, since neglecting to detach the root is considered somewhat unsanitary, since the roots were entrenched in the dirt when harvested. I was also less than impressed with the fact that some of NKH's other side dishes tasted less than fresh. In particular, the bindae-duk was hard and brittle, rather than soft, which indicated to me that it had perhaps been made on a previous day, rather than made and served fresh on that occasion.

There are certain culinary niceties that derive from being Korean and eating Korean food throughout one's life, so I suspect that the niceties that I've mentioned will go unnoticed by most non-Korean diners.  NKH is a notch above Brothers, since NKH's food is less greasy, but the overall difference in quality between NKH and Brothers is slight and thus doesn't support the disparity in price, since eating at NKH is twice as expensive as dining at Brothers.

NKH and Brothers are both decent, but both places pale in comparison to the quality, taste, and authenticity of the food at Seoul Garden. SG is a more pricey than NKH, but the dishes at SG reflect a meticulous attention to detail that is undeniably reflected in the taste and flavor of the entrees. In fast-food terms, I would posit Brothers as analogous to Jack In the Box, NKH as akin to Burger King, and Seoul Garden as tantamount to a delectable, albeit more pricey hamburger that one might be served at a posh hotel or resort. In retail terms, Brothers is the equivalent of Gap, as NKH is to JCrew, and Seoul Garden would be to Bloomingdales.
author: John O.

description: kal-bi & bulgogi were tough & freezer burned.  This place used to be really tasty.  I don't know what happened.  On the plus side the kimchee was good, and the waiter was very helpful and friendly.
author: Bob D.

description: i'm giving this place 5 stars because i went in sick as a dog, ordered the delicious samgyetang, and woke up this morning feeling 100% better. like magic! also, this place is awesome because they're generous with their banchan which is delicious, especially the o-deng (fishcake) and kimchi (which i'm VERY picky about).
author: stella k.

description: i thought the ban-chans (side dishes) were pretty good, a nice selection of kimchi and other veggie goodies - it all tasted pretty fresh.  they also did a good job with the veggie dol sot bibim bap - basically rice mixed with veggies in a very hot stone bowl so you get a crunchy crusty layer of rice at the bottom of the bowl.  sometimes the bowls are not hot enough, so the crust doesn't form, but no such issues here.   i didn't like the beef broth so much, it was quite salty...
author: wendy p.

description: no reservations needed, tasty Korean in easy going setting, kimchi well done
author: N.R. G.

description: just average, compared to the korean restaurants in south bay or a couple in oakland. but what other choices do we have? there aren't many korean places in the city.
author: Evan P.

description: if this is the place upstairs it is the one i have been eating at for a very long time. the owner is kinda eccentric. i see him sitting downstairs drinking scotch and smoking. he has this really long hair. he also owns the other one up the street. anyhow, good consistent food. the pork in the red spicy sauce is always a favorite as is the soondubu (spelling is off I know) with beef. we also like the big pancake with green onions, oysters and beef. korean restaurants in LA are way better, but in SF this place is good. there is also a great place in berkeley on telegraph in a mini mall called Koryo that is good. funny story about that place. a friend was eating there a few years back and some guys came in to rob the place at gunpoint. as the person at the cash register was getting out the money this old korean woman runs out of the kitchen in her slippers with a cleaver charging for the guys so they don't steal the money. Well another employee restrained her and they took off with the money. my friend was convinced they were going to shoot her. very scary - oh well what do you expect. oakland...
author: Thomas K.
